title: Assessing Maximum Employment
speaker: Governor Adriana D. Kugler
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph='This is a long-form essay written by James B. Bullard, President and CEO of the Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis, on the concept of maximum employment, also known as the natural rate of unemployment or u*. The essay provides an overview of the current understanding of maximum employment, its measurement, and its implications for monetary policy.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='**Maximum employment is a time-varying concept**: Bullard notes that early economists recognized that the natural rate of unemployment can change over time.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='**Estimating maximum employment requires advanced statistical techniques**: The author discusses various methods used to estimate u*, including demographic trends, labor force composition, and unemployment duration.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='**The relationship between unemployment rates and maximum employment is complex**: Bullard explains that the trend component of the unemployment rate (u*) may not be as strongly cyclical as the overall unemployment rate.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='**Temporary layoffs are a key feature of labor market dynamics**: The essay highlights the importance of temporary layoffs in understanding labor market behavior, particularly during economic downturns.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='**Maximum employment estimates can inform monetary policy decisions**: Bullard argues that estimates of u* can provide useful information for policymakers to set interest rates and implement monetary policies.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="**Perry (1970)**: George L. Perry's paper 'Changing Labor Markets and Inflation' is cited as an early example of estimating time-varying maximum employment.", theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph="**Friedman (1968)**: Milton Friedman's concept of a 'natural rate' of unemployment is discussed, although the author notes that this term has become somewhat controversial.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="**Hall and Kudlyak (2023)**: Robert E. Hall and Marianna Kudlyak's paper on the active role of the natural rate of unemployment challenges the weaker cyclicality of u* relative to the overall unemployment rate.", theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Overall, the essay provides a comprehensive overview of the current understanding of maximum employment, its measurement, and its implications for monetary policy decisions.', theme='employment')]

title: Thank You, John
speaker: Governor Christopher J. Waller
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph='Kydland and Prescott then showed that if, on the other hand, the central bank could commit to following a rule to set policy, then it could not renege on its promises. As a result, inflation would stay low while yielding the same outcomes for output and employment.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='In 1983, Robert Barro and David Gordon used the Kydland–Prescott example to study reputation building by the central bank.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph="Up until Rogoff's work, the underlying assumption had been that the central bank was trying to maximize social welfare and that its preferences were aligned with those of society.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="It was around that time that I read Alberto Alesina's paper on 'partisan business cycles.' In that paper, he assumed there were different political parties, each having different preferences about inflation and unemployment.", theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='I now introduce John Taylor and his work into the story, which coincided with the beginning of my own research career.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='In 1983, having read the Barro and Gordon paper, I started working on reputation-building strategies as part of my Ph.D. dissertation research.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph="That is when I went back and read John Taylor's discussion of the Barro and Gordon paper in the Journal of Monetary Economics.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="As I read that sentence, I thought, 'How does society build credibility into the institution instead of relying on the credibility of an individual?' That one sentence that John wrote in 1983 set me off on a 20-year journey studying central bank design.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='But commitment to most things in life is easier said than done. Even rules can be abandoned if it is optimal to do so.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='In the absence of commitment, can the central bank do anything to enhance the credibility of its promise to keep inflation low?', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The traditional argument for discretionary monetary policy was that any policy choice that a rule would recommend could be replicated by discretion, especially when policymakers are aware of the rule, but not vice versa.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Reneging on promises made by discretionary policymakers, they argued, is much easier than reneging on a policy rule, which is a way to commit to future actions.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Kydland and Prescott provided a simple and appealing model at the end of their paper. The model had an incentive for the central bank to renege on its promise to keep inflation low, since doing so would expand the economy and lower unemployment.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='So where did it lead me?', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="Around that time, Ken Rogoff published his paper on what he referred to as 'conservative' central bankers.", theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='This type of institutional design issue was one that I was interested in researching.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="But as I read Rogoff's work, it suggested that society consisted of people who had a variety of views about inflation, meaning that they would also have different views on the tradeoff between inflation and output stability.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='So I tried to endogenize the heterogeneity in preferences.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='I assumed that board members were appointed by the winning party of an election to serve for multiple periods.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph="My research showed that by having an independent policy board set monetary policy, social well-being was improved relative to Alesina's results.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='To conclude, I have come full circle in my professional life—from first reading that sentence that John wrote in 1983 to researching central bank independence and central bank boards for 20 years to then becoming a central bank board member, which led me here today.', theme='other')]

title: Opening Remarks on Productivity Dynamics
speaker: Governor Lisa D. Cook
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph='Before that, I would like to briefly discuss a topic I see as critical to the future path of the economy: productivity growth.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The challenge for Federal Reserve policymakers was clear: Move inflation back toward its 2 percent target while maintaining the health of the labor market.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Two notable factors were the unwinding of pandemic-era conditions that previously constrained the supply of both goods and labor in conjunction with restrictive monetary policy that contributed to a moderation in aggregate demand.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Prior to the pandemic, from 2007 to 2019, productivity growth in the business sector averaged 1.5 percent annually. title: Four Guides for the Journey Ahead
speaker: Governor Lisa D. Cook
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph="Huge congratulations to Michigan State University's James Madison College Class of 2025!1 It is an honor to speak to this inspiring and talented graduating class. Before I address the graduates, I would like to thank those who helped you get here: the parents, grandparents, siblings, aunts and uncles, friends, teachers, and mentors. Congratulations and thank you to all who lifted up the Class of 2025.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="As a professor's kid and as an MSU professor, I have come to treasure commencements as important milestones. It is wonderful to be with you today. The flowers are starting to bloom in Beal Garden, the lawns around Beaumont Tower are turning the perfect shade of Spartan green, and the ducklings are making their appearance on the Red Cedar. After another chilly winter, campus is reaching peak beauty—just in time for you to leave Michigan State.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='I am full of optimism about everything that lies ahead of you. Despite any sense of angst you may feel about moving on from Madison, I hope that you are filled with optimism, too. Spring is a time of new beginnings. You are ready for the next step. Today marks both the completion of a tremendous accomplishment, and an exciting new beginning.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='When I was in your shoes, graduating from Spelman College, I remember feeling unsure of what the world would have in store for me. I did not imagine I would be a member of the Federal Reserve Board of Governors, or even an economist.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Today, you are leaving the safe harbor of Case Hall and East Lansing, ready to depart on your next adventure. As you do, I would like to offer four guides for you to navigate your journey ahead: hope, curiosity, persistence, and a commitment to public service.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Hope is a value instilled in me from a very young age. I saw my parents and family members face difficult challenges. They persevered because they held out hope that their actions would lead to a better future, not only for themselves, but for me and my sisters, our community, and ultimately all of society.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='As James Madison graduates, I know each of you has some corner of the world in which you have made a difference or wish to make a difference. It could have been through debate, JMC Senate, ASMSU, 4-H, ROTC, peer mentoring, Fed Challenge, a public service sorority or fraternity, or Model UN, among many other organizations.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Curiosity is magical, but it takes vigilance, practice, and study to avoid stagnation, and to reach new insights. Curiosity will lead you to wonderful opportunities if you trust its guidance.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='That leads me to my third suggestion for your journey ahead: be persistent. As Madison graduates, you know about preparation. To be persistent in your efforts, you need to continually prepare yourself for the next steps, even if you do not know the destination.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Historically, Madison graduates have entered public service jobs immediately after graduation in large numbers, including with the Peace Corps, Teach for America, nonprofits, and local, state, and federal agencies.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Graduates—Spartans—you are entering the wider world, one filled with pressing needs, and countless opportunities. As you make your way, let hope be your constant companion. Heed your curiosity. Honor deep knowledge and thorough, persistent preparation.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='I urge you to plumb the depths of the deep oceans, where you will find the great questions that excite, challenge, and motivate you. You will face rough waters, the route will change, and your destination is not entirely known.', theme='other')]

title: Economic Outlook
speaker: Chair Jerome H. Powell
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph='At the Fed, we are always focused on the dual-mandate goals given to us by Congress: maximum employment and stable prices.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Inflation has come down a great deal but is running a bit above our 2 percent objective.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The labor market is at or near maximum employment.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph="Turning to the incoming data, we will get the initial reading on first-quarter GDP in a couple of weeks. title: 2025 Distinguished Alumna Award Acceptance Remarks
speaker: Governor Lisa D. Cook
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph='I know there is a lot going on in the news at the moment, so let me just start by saying that I do not plan to discuss policy or the current economic situation this evening.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='No matter when you attended Cal or how long you have been away, I think we can all agree that Berkeley is a special place that stays in your heart.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="The wonderful food served as a perfect canvas upon which to share ideas. Sometimes that was having dinner at each other's apartments, and sometimes it was slipping over to the cafeteria between Bechtel and Evans to have lunch with my friends in engineering and computer science.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='From these lunches and many other conversations at Berkeley, I learned the value of exchanging ideas and the free disposal of ideas. When I asked him to advise me, he was hesitant. So, he presented me with a challenge. I hope you continue to carry that spirit in all you do here in Washington and beyond.', theme='other')]

title: A Tale of Two Outlooks
speaker: Governor Christopher J. Waller
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph='This text appears to be a speech delivered by Christopher J. Waller, a member of the Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC), on the topic of tariffs and their potential effects on the US economy.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='1. **The new tariff policy is a significant shock**: The recently imposed tariffs are one of the biggest shocks to affect the US economy in many decades.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='2. **Uncertainty about future policy and its effects**: The future of the tariff policy, as well as its possible effects, is still highly uncertain.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='* Inflation could rise significantly (by 1-1/2 to 2 percentage points) over the next year or so, with a peak close to 5 percent on an annualized basis.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='* Economic growth would slow significantly, and unemployment would rise by several tenths of a percentage point this year and approach 5 percent next year.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='4. **Temporary effects expected**: The inflationary effects of higher tariffs are expected to be temporary, and the author expects inflation to return to a more moderate level in 2026.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='* In the large tariff scenario, the FOMC might need to cut rates sooner and to a greater extent than previously thought to mitigate the effects of tariffs on output and employment.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='* In the smaller tariff scenario, the effect on inflation would be significantly smaller (around 3 percent), and the author expects inflation expectations to remain anchored.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Overall, the speech suggests that the FOMC will need to be flexible in responding to the uncertain effects of the new tariff policy, with a focus on mitigating its negative impacts on output and employment.', theme='other')]

title: AI, Fintechs, and Banks
speaker: Governor Michael S. Barr
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph="Today, I'd like to speak about responsible innovation in the context of generative artificial intelligence (Gen AI) in banking and how bank–fintech partnerships may accelerate the integration of the technology and banking.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Of course, one reason is that banks are being appropriately cautious in the highly regulated environment in which they operate. Let me highlight some key reasons.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Gen AI has benefits for document analysis, which could be applied to improve credit underwriting.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph="These enhancements have the potential to enable decisions that are faster and more informed—although with some attendant risks as I've discussed previously.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Gen AI-based analytic tools can build on existing algorithmic trading capabilities by harnessing an enormous knowledge base in both the public and private domains.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Fintechs have financial and time constraints. Early funding rounds provide limited time and resources to demonstrate outcomes and drive fintechs to find effective, quick solutions, which often involve creative uses of cutting-edge technology.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Gen AI may have benefits for consumers and businesses through better, cheaper, and faster financial services; however, to harness the upsides of Gen AI, banks, fintechs, and regulators all have a role to play in helping to ensure that the risks are managed.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="Fintechs are generally young companies with a clean tech stack and don't have to integrate new technology into old infrastructure. title: What Roles Should the Private Sector and the Federal Reserve Play in Payments?
speaker: Governor Christopher J. Waller
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph='The key question I want to address today is, what roles should the private sector and the Federal Reserve play in payments?', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='As a strong believer in the benefits of a capitalist system, I hold the view that it is generally the private sector that can most reliably and efficiently provide goods and services to the economy.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='I have applied that same question to issues ranging from bank regulation to monetary policy. For an example in the payments area, three years ago there was an increase in public discussion about creating a new payment instrument called a central bank digital currency (CBDC).', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='In other words, what market failure or inefficiency demands this specific intervention?', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='I want to focus on the important roles the private sector and the Federal Reserve play in our ever-evolving payment system.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The early U.S. payment system suffered from incomplete markets.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='This in turn led to a more complete national clearing and settlement process.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='For example, porters in New York City would deliver checks and exchange them for gold or other coins and then transport that "specie" to the payee.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='In modern economic language, the NYCH became a coordination mechanism that improved clearing by getting banks to clear and settle payments in a well-organized manner.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='It also reduced asymmetric information about the quality of member balance sheets.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='And financial panics, sometimes driven by gaps and problems in check clearing, were a regular feature of the latter 19th and early 20th century.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Depositors and investors lost confidence in certain New York banks that had been combined into large, complex, and opaque trust companies that were not members of the NYCH.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The Second Bank of the United States was created in 1816 and, due to its federal charter, it was able to create a national system for clearing checks and banknotes.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='When the charter for the Second Bank lapsed, clearing and settlement of banknotes and checks fell back to state-chartered banks.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The New York Clearing House Association (NYCH) was founded in 1853 and served as a central location for the clearing process.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='This contributed to the motivation to establish the Federal Reserve and its role in payments.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Fast forward to today, and we are once again in an era of rapid change and innovation in money and payments.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="I'll start by discussing the important roles that the private sector now plays in the payment system and in the evolution of payments under way.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The private sector connects consumers and businesses to the payment system, with financial institutions competing to provide services to their customers.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph="But just as was the case in the time of Warburg, there remain problems in payments that can't be fully resolved by the private sector.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Compared with many other countries where a small number of large banks dominate, the United States has thousands of banks and credit unions.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph="One recent example of an area in which we're playing such a coordination role is in instant payments.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='With respect to new and emerging technologies in finance, I can think of two ways in which the private sector is uniquely positioned to develop and deploy them while the government is not well suited to do so.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='If problems emerge, as they did with check clearing in the 19th century, then government can play a constructive role in overcoming them.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='American entrepreneurship and technical prowess have generated exciting innovations in payments, and they will continue to do so.', theme='other')]

title: Centralized and Decentralized Finance: Substitutes or Complements?
speaker: Governor Christopher J. Waller
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph='Let\'s start with the economics of trading. Most financial trades are "pairwise" in that the seller of an object needs to find a buyer of that exact object.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Another name for intermediaries is middlemen. Why would we pay a middleman? In their paper from nearly 40 years ago, Ariel Rubenstein and Asher Wolinsky described it eloquently: "What makes the middlemen\'s activity possible is the time-consuming nature of the trade, which enables middlemen to extract surplus in return for shortening the time period that sellers and buyers have to wait for a transaction."', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='It is for these reasons that banks arose as early as in ancient Mesopotamia to carry out some of these functions.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='However, these arrangements are not without drawbacks. An obvious drawback of intermediation from the perspective of those wishing to trade is that those middlemen must get paid. That is, there are transaction costs.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='An early crypto-asset—Bitcoin—was developed to function in a world in which trust among individuals did not exist.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='I think of the crypto ecosystem as consisting of three parts: a store of value (or money), a medium of exchange, and a unit of account.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='However, there are other uses emerging from these technologies that look more like complements to centralized finance.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The bottom line is that things like DLT, tokenization, and smart contracts are just technologies for trading that can be used in defi or also to improve efficiency in centralized finance. That is why I see them as complements.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Stablecoins are another important innovation in defi.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='I think a balanced view of expeditious disruption and long-term sustainability is merited.', theme='other')]

title: Statement by Governor Michelle W. Bowman
speaker: Governor Michelle W. Bowman
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph="On Wednesday, September 18, 2024, I dissented from the Federal Open Market Committee's (FOMC) decision to lower the target range for the federal funds rate by 1/2 percentage point to 4-3/4 to 5 percent. In my view, however, a smaller first move in this process would have been a preferable action.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The U.S. economy remains strong, with solid underlying growth in economic activity and a labor market near full employment. Although hiring appears to have softened, layoffs remain low. I see the normalization in labor market conditions as necessary to help bring wage growth down to a pace consistent with 2 percent inflation given trend productivity growth. My reading of labor market data has become more uncertain due to increased measurement challenges and the inherent difficulty in assessing the effects of recent immigration flows. I am also taking signal from continued solid growth in the spending data, especially consumer spending, reflecting a healthy labor market.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Despite Progress, Inflation Remains a Concern', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Inflation remains above our 2 percent goal, as core personal consumption expenditures prices are still rising faster than 2.5 percent from 12 months earlier. speaker: Governor Christopher J. Waller
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph="At the University of Notre Dame, Notre Dame, Indiana\nThank you, Eric, and thank you for the opportunity to speak to you today.1 My topic is the outlook for the U.S. economy and the implications for monetary policy, a set of judgements that have, of course, been influenced by this morning's jobs report.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Looking back at the economic data over the first six months of 2024, it portrayed an economy slowly cooling and not showing signs of significant weakening. The labor market had been gradually moderating for the past year or so, and although inflation rose in the first quarter, it then retreated in the second, and there was a widespread view heading into the second half of the year that the FOMC was on track to achieve a much desired but unusual "soft landing."', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph="The ups and downs in the data over time highlight what I consider the right approach to meeting the FOMC's dual mandate goals—I believe we should be data dependent, but not overreact to any data point, including the latest data. When we faced a period of banking instability in the spring of 2023, there were calls from some to stop rate hikes despite inflation still running over 5 percent.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="Today's jobs report continues the longer-term pattern of a softening of the labor market that is consistent with moderate growth in economic activity, the details of which I will get into in a moment. As I said at the outset, considering the progress we have made on getting inflation back to target, I believe that the balance of risks is now weighted more toward downside risks to the FOMC's maximum-employment mandate.", theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='While this is a correlation that certainly bears attention, I want to make a few cautionary points about relying on such rules in deciding that a recession has begun. As we have seen in the recent past with other supposedly reliable recession rules, such as an inverted yield curve, there is more to forecasting economic outcomes than the relationships between a couple of variables.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="The employment cost index grew at an annualized rate of 3.5 percent from March to June, and the 12-month change was 3.9 percent for private sector workers, the lowest since late 2021.4 Average hourly earnings, reported in today's jobs report, rose at a three-month annualized pace of 3.8 percent in August, the same as the 12-month change.", theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Looking across the components of inflation, one can see the breadth of the disinflation. Over 50 percent of categories in the total and core market baskets had annualized monthly inflation less than 2.5 percent in August.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Now let me discuss the implications of this outlook for monetary policy. As I said at the outset, considering the achieved and continuing progress on inflation and moderation in the labor market, I believe the time has come to lower the target range for the federal funds rate at our upcoming meeting.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Determining the pace of rate cuts and ultimately the total reduction in the policy rate are decisions that lie in the future. As of today, I believe it is important to start the rate cutting process at our next meeting.', theme='other')]

title: Interlinking Fast Payment Systems
speaker: Governor Christopher J. Waller
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph='The technology-driven payments revolution in India has been enabled by a public-private partnership to build the "technology stack" of digital platforms that has broadened financial inclusion and done so at low costs.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Now that fast payment systems have been established around much of the globe—in over 70 countries and climbing—attention is turning to how these newer systems could potentially enhance global payments.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The G20 roadmap addresses a new topic that payments industry stakeholders have been circling around for years—more cost-effective and timely cross-border payments for consumers and businesses.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Faster and cheaper cross-border payments Not all frictions that slow payments down are bad. Certain frictions are purposely built into the global payment system for compliance and risk-management reasons.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='In addition, can we assume that all parties to a cross-border transaction want faster payments? The fundamental friction in any transaction is that the seller of an object—a can of soup, an hour of labor, or a good manufactured for export—wants to receive their money as fast as possible.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Suppose we do want to incentivize senders by lowering costs of faster payments—whose responsibility is it to do that?', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='In the United States we have experience with offering low-cost international ACH payments. We provided direct ACH linkages from the United States to Europe and Canada, but after more than 20 years, the banks were not using it, and we stopped the service.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Practical aspects of interlinking fast payment systems We know from basic economic theory that payment systems are similar to other networks in that greater participation is necessary for the network to grow and increase value to its users.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Building out domestic networks has been done in different ways. In some countries the central bank has authority to mandate participation, notably in Brazil with the successful Pix system.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='We have seen widespread adoption of the FedNow Service in just a little over a year since implementation, with close to 1,000 depository institutions on the network including many of the largest banks that will drive origination volume.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='To send an ISO message seamlessly from one country to another across a technical link, operators need to coordinate and align on common practices.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='We should consider that new multilateral arrangements for interlinking could potentially address some of the challenges that I have outlined.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='To sum up, overall, I do see the value of a coordination role for the public sector to improve cross-border payments, an effort in which the Federal Reserve has been and will continue to be heavily engaged.', theme='other')]

(2022)**: Analyzes the impact of supply chain disruptions on inflation.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='3. **Blanchard and Bernanke (2023, 2024)**: Explores the relationship between monetary policy and inflation in different economies.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="Overall, Powell's speech emphasizes the complexities of managing inflation during a period of rapid economic growth and supply chain disruptions. title: Opening Remarks
speaker: Governor Christopher J. Waller
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph="The evolving nature of money and banking creates new channels through which financial markets and institutions can affect the economy, with implications for all five of the Federal Reserve's functions, which are monetary policy, financial stability, supervision and regulation, payment systems, and consumers and communities.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Many of the concepts underlying such economic interactions have for years been the study of this workshop. When I was research director at the Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis, I put together several iterations of this gathering. As the organization of the workshop has passed to a new generation, I continue to find it to be a leading venue for studying the economic mechanisms through which money, financial markets, contracts, and institutions affect economic activity and economic welfare.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='If I had to describe the work that has been presented at this conference over the last 20-plus years, I would say it focuses on the economics of exchange and payment. Walrasian supply and demand models describe how an equilibrium quantity and price are determined but it is silent on two key questions: how do the goods get from seller to buyer and how is payment made from buyer to seller?', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='This is not just a theoretical issue that is only relevant to economists in ivory towers. Payments and the exchange process are multibillion-dollar businesses and private sector firms are constantly innovating in this area to overcome the types of frictions that are well-known to this group.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Keeping with the tradition of studying exchange and payment, several papers to be presented this year focus on how frictions in financial markets, such as asymmetric information or asset illiquidity, matter for the transmission and implementation of monetary policy as well as unemployment and inflation.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Similarly, it is great to continue seeing work studying frictional intermediation in asset markets and the implications for asset prices and the efficient sharing of risk. These contributions push the frontier of our knowledge, facilitate our understanding of real-world complexities, and inform policy thinking.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="The workshop's focus on broader financial stability issues is also very important. Financial stability vulnerabilities, such as run risk, excessive leverage, and bubbly valuations, could amplify the effect of adverse shocks, potentially resulting in big economic losses and a slowdown in economic activity.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Understanding the mechanisms that allow these vulnerabilities to grow and transmit stress to the rest of the financial system requires rigorous theoretical research and solid micro-foundations. Over the course of this week, we will hear interesting work on this topic that includes research questions such as how a central bank can balance interventions for financial stability and interventions to achieve a certain stance of monetary policy, how banks take risks, and understanding the risk of runs on banks, non-banks, and stablecoins.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Other concepts are newer and more novel. As the monetary and financial ecosystem has evolved, so has this workshop, bringing together many perspectives and modeling approaches to money and banking theory and its applications.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="This year's workshop continues in that innovative spirit, keeping an eye on the future of money and banking. The papers to be presented span areas including decentralized ledgers, exchanges for crypto assets, and the impact of certain protocols on financial stability.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='An important point to remember this week is that no single field of study can give the answers to all of the big questions we face relating to the evolution of money and banking. Commingling of insights and techniques from monetary theory, finance theory, and other fields is vital in studying the complex interactions of modern financial systems.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="Without further ado, let's get started. I hope you have a great week of engaging discussions, and I'm sure we will learn a lot from this year's workshop.", theme='other')]

title: Liquidity, Supervision, and Regulatory Reform
speaker: Governor Michelle W. Bowman
tags:
[ThemeTag(paragraph='**Regulatory Reform**
1. The bank regulatory system has undergone significant transformation since the passage of the Dodd-Frank Act.
2. The current system has resulted in significantly increased liquidity and bank capital, new stress testing and resolution planning requirements, and other improvements designed to promote bank resiliency.
3. Before proposing regulatory reform measures, it is essential to reflect on the causes that contributed to the failures of SVB and Signature Bank.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='**Supervisory Process**
1. The current narrow approach to rulemaking focuses on a specific reform without considering the broader framework or context within which these rules exist.
2. This approach creates a corresponding narrowness when thinking about the consequences of regulatory reform.
3. An efficient regulatory system can build resilience both for bank safety and soundness and financial stability.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='**Leverage Ratio**
1. The current 5% leverage ratio applies to U.S. global systemically important banks, commonly referred to as the enhanced supplementary leverage ratio (or eSLR).
2. This rule constraint has been identified as a potential disruption to Treasury market intermediation.
3. Addressing this known leverage rule constraint is crucial before future stresses emerge.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='**Regulatory Process**
1. Passing regulations under the Administrative Procedure Act requires agencies to follow specific notice-and-comment rulemaking procedures.
2. Rulemaking entails publishing rationales for agency action and seeking public input, which serves an essential purpose in promoting better agency decision-making.
3. The use of public Board meetings should be continued for matters of significant public interest.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='**Closing Thoughts**
1. Accountability is facilitated by understanding facts, identifying how elements of the banking system perform over time and during stress, and taking ownership of identified problems with targeted reforms.
2. Effective reform requires a deep understanding of facts, careful identification of how elements of the banking system perform over time and during stress, and a commitment to take ownership of identified problems with targeted reforms that are commensurate with underlying risks.', theme='other')]

title: Getting Closer
speaker: Governor Christopher J. Waller
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph="After significant progress in 2023 toward the Federal Open Market Committee's (FOMC) price-stability goal, inflation jumped in the first quarter.", theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Then, in the second quarter, data on inflation and the labor market moderated in a way that suggests progress toward price stability has resumed.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph="A signal of possible slowing in economic activity comes from the Institute for Supply Management's (ISM) survey of purchasing managers for non-manufacturing firms.", theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='One development in the past few months with significant implications for monetary policy is that labor supply and demand have finally come into rough balance.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The unemployment rate has risen from a 50-year low to 4.1 percent, still low in historical terms but the highest since late 2021.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='So what lies ahead for the labor market? Right now, the labor market is in a sweet spot—employment growth is not excessive when accounting for immigration, nominal wage growth is near the rate consistent with price stability,', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph="But data in recent months has been reassuring. Last week's consumer price index (CPI) report was the second month of very good news.", theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='For policymakers, this was also welcome news.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="So, after disappointing data to begin 2024, we now have a couple of months of data that I view as being more consistent with the steady progress we saw last year in reducing inflation, and also consistent with the FOMC's price stability goal.", theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Now let me turn to the implications of this data for monetary policy.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='On the one hand, it is essential that monetary policy get inflation down to a sustained level of 2 percent.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='With those two risks in mind, let me lay out three scenarios for the economy this year that would result in leading me to different views about appropriate policy.', theme='other')]

title: Opening Remarks
speaker: Governor Michelle W. Bowman
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph="As many of you may recall, at last year's Fed Listens event here in Chicago, we discussed youth employment and joining the labor force following the pandemic, which were especially inspiring.", theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='So, in that spirit, today is not only a wonderful opportunity to continue this important conversation in the Seventh District, but also an opportunity to dig deeper into issues that affect local families through the childcare industry, working parents, and employers.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Austan and I enjoyed getting to know our panelists better earlier today, and I am looking forward to learning more about their experiences through the upcoming panels and discussions.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='As you all know, Fed officials and economists review a vast amount of economic data on a regular basis.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='A better understanding of a wide variety of this type of data, from the considerations families face in making spending decisions (including the costs of childcare) to factors weighed by business owners in applying for loans and offering benefits to help attract top talent, all provide better insight into our data collection.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph="Earlier, I had the pleasure to meet each of the panelists you'll hear from today. title: Promoting an Inclusive Financial System
speaker: Governor Michelle W. Bowman
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph='An economy that works for everyone necessarily includes a more inclusive financial system. Together, our work to promote initiatives that further this work will enable greater access to financial services.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='We published the 11th annual report in May. title: Financial Inclusion: Past, Present, and Hopes for the Future
speaker: Vice Chair for Supervision Michael S. Barr
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph="Financial inclusion is central to the Federal Reserve's mission of promoting a strong and stable financial system and a healthy economy that works for everyone.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='I have spent much of my career in the public sector and academia working on topics related to financial inclusion.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Looking over the past few decades, significant progress has been made in improving financial inclusion, including progress on many of the issues that will be discussed at this conference.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Advancing the Goals of Financial Inclusion The goal of financial inclusion is to improve access to affordable financial services that meet the needs of individuals and businesses.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Banks are playing a pivotal role in innovating to serve low- and moderate-income households, sometimes in partnership with financial technology companies, or fintechs.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The Importance of Durable Inclusion Innovations in banking services are important to improving financial inclusion. But to have a durable impact on society, innovations must be adopted responsibly.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Use of Alternative Data We do see great promise to improve financial access when innovation is done responsibly.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Community Reinvestment Act: Past, Present, and Future Let me turn now to the importance of the Community Reinvestment Act (CRA) and its role in advancing financial inclusion.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The Future of Financial Inclusion Given the importance of innovation to the goal of financial inclusion, I am grateful that we have been able to gather so many experts on topics related to it.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Conclusion In closing, my hope is that these kinds of efforts, as well as continued innovation in the banking system, can bring us closer to a time when all families and communities in our country have adequate access to credit and financial services on fair, affordable, transparent, and accessible terms.', theme='other')]

title: Some Reasons for Optimism about Inflation
speaker: Governor Adriana D. Kugler
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph='The economy is slowing down, which will help bring inflation back under control.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='There is a prospect of higher productivity growth, which could lead to lower inflation without a significant slowdown in economic activity or employment.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The current stance of monetary policy is sufficiently restrictive to cool the economy and bring inflation back toward 2 percent without a sharp contraction in economic activity or labor market deterioration.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='There are some tentative signs that growth in other countries, such as Europe, is picking up from a soft patch last year, which could help mitigate global economic risks that could spill over to the US economy.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='These factors lead me to believe that inflation will come down slowly and sustainably, and I expect it to become appropriate to begin easing policy sometime later this year.', theme='inflation')]

title: Innovation in the Financial System
speaker: Governor Michelle W. Bowman
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph='Regulators must balance protection with innovation: The regulatory framework should protect households and businesses from risks while allowing innovation to flourish.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Innovation is essential for a more efficient and effective financial system: Bowman argues that a more innovative financial system can provide better services, increase competition, and improve stability.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The regulatory perimeter is permeable: Activities and risks can shift between regulated banks and other parts of the financial system, so regulators must consider the broader financial system in their approach.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Regulators should promote innovation through transparency and open communication: This includes providing clear guidance, incorporating innovation into the regulatory agenda, and encouraging interaction between industry and regulators.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="A 'regulatory sandbox' can facilitate experimentation and testing: Regulators can allow some degree of testing and experimentation to foster innovation while maintaining safety and soundness standards.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The most unfortunate approach would be to prohibit or discourage innovation: This could lead to new financial stability risks as activity migrates to areas with lower regulatory standards and less transparency.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="Overall, Bowman's speech emphasizes the need for regulators to strike a balance between protection and innovation, and to create an environment that encourages responsible innovation while maintaining safety and soundness standards.", theme='other')]

title: Lessons from the American Economic Association Summer Program

title: A New Class of Trailblazers
speaker: Governor Lisa D. Cook
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph="Thank you, Dr. O'Neal. It is an honor to be here to celebrate with you—the Girls Global Academy's first-ever graduating class. This is a momentous achievement and occasion.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='And a very special congratulations to the Girls Global Academy Class of 2024! Soon you will embark on new journeys. I understand that many of you are going on to college in the fall, including one of you heading to my alma mater, Spelman College.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The Class of 2024 stands out. This is not only because you are the first, but also because you achieved so much all while overcoming extremely challenging circumstances by starting high school during the pandemic.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Four years ago, all of you could have taken a more well-marked route. title: Little by Little, Progress Seems to be Resuming.
speaker: Governor Christopher J. Waller
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph='After a run of great data in the latter half of 2023, it seemed that significant progress on inflation would continue and that rate cuts were not far off. However, the first three months of 2024 threw cold water on that outlook, as data on both inflation and economic activity came in much hotter than anticipated.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph="But more recent data on the economy indicate that restrictive monetary policy is helping to cool off aggregate demand and the inflation data for April suggests that progress toward 2 percent has likely resumed. Central bankers should never say never, but the data suggests that inflation isn't accelerating, and I believe that further increases in the policy rate are probably unnecessary.", theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='One month does not constitute a trend, but this data suggests that policy is doing its job to moderate aggregate demand, which will support renewed progress in lowering inflation.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Now let me turn to the labor market. The labor market is still relatively strong and supporting a solid pace of job creation, but after progress in bringing demand and supply into better balance in 2023, this rebalancing seemed to stall at the beginning of this year.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Then in the past month or two, the easing of demand, relative to supply seems to have resumed. The hiring rate, reported by the Labor Department, slowed relative to the previous three months.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Job creation fell from 315,000 in March to 175,000 in April. A big reason for the decline was a sharp drop in the pace of job creation by state and local governments that is unlikely to be repeated, but private sector job creation also fell, another indication that demand for workers continues to slow.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph="Wage growth is still a bit higher than I believe is needed to be consistent with our 2 percent target, but it's not that high and recent average hourly earnings data suggest that wage growth is moderating.", theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Just like the data on economic activity, I see the labor market data supporting renewed progress in lowering inflation, so now let me turn to the outlook for inflation.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="Last week's report on consumer price index (CPI) inflation in April was a welcome relief after three months without progress toward 2 percent. That said, the progress was so modest that it did not change my view that I will need to see more evidence of moderating inflation before supporting any easing of monetary policy.", theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Headline CPI inflation rose 0.31 percent month over month. That barely budged the 12-month total CPI inflation reading to 3.4 percent in April from 3.5 percent in March.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph="Accounting for price data from the report last week on the producer price index, forecasts are predicting both monthly headline and core inflation based on personal consumption expenditures, the FOMC's preferred gauge, rose a bit less than CPI last month.", theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Looking across these estimates, they suggest three-month annualized core PCE inflation could decline around 1 percentage point to about 3.4 percent as the outsized January increase rolls off the 3-month average.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Before I say more about the implications for policy, this seems like a good moment to make a few points about a bedrock principle of monetary policy—data dependence. The appropriate setting of monetary policy requires understanding how the economy is performing and some idea of where we think it is going.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="I am bringing this up because I hear from some quarters the claim that the FOMC has become 'overly data dependent.' This is a phrase that honestly doesn't make much sense to me but is apparently supposed to mean that we are over-reacting to data and allegedly sending confusing messages about the stance of monetary policy.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="I don't see how that argument applies to the views of the FOMC, if one looks at the Summary of Economic Projections (SEP). Between the March SEP in 2023 and March 2024 SEP, the Committee median was relatively consistent in projecting around three rate cuts in 2024.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="Let me now turn to the implications for monetary policy of my outlook for the U.S. economy. With the labor market as strong as it is, my focus remains bringing inflation down toward the FOMC's 2 percent goal.", theme='other')]

title: Welcoming Remarks on the International Role of the U.S. Dollar
speaker: Governor Christopher J. Waller
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph='', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Thank you, Beth Anne, and thank you for the opportunity to speak to you today.1 I would like to welcome everyone to this Third Conference on the International Roles of the U.S. Dollar, which is jointly organized by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York and the Federal Reserve Board.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='When people talk about the "dollar," they are referring to a number of roles it plays on the world stage—including a physical currency used worldwide, financial assets denominated or redeemable in U.S. dollars, or a settlement unit used in transactions.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Participants in the first and second installments of this conference discussed the different roles the dollar plays in the global economy and how the primacy of the dollar benefits not only the United States but also the rest of the world. U.S. households, for instance, benefit from lower transaction and borrowing costs, while U.S. businesses and the U.S. government benefit from deep financial markets, including a large pool of creditors and investors.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Households and businesses in foreign economies also benefit from access to this broad pool of lenders and investors, which reduces their financing costs and fosters global economic growth.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Despite all the benefits the dollar provides the United States and global economies and the efforts to mitigate some of the financial stability challenges posed by its dominant role, there has, for some time, been commentary predicting that the dollar is destined for demise—potentially an imminent demise.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Such predictions have not materialized.2 The dollar remains, by far, the most widely used currency across a variety of metrics, including as a store of value and a medium of exchange.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph="However, the role of the United States in the world economy is changing, and finance is always changing, so I think it is important for policymakers to regularly consider if and why the dollar's role might change as well.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='This conference is a good venue to discuss some of the challenges and opportunities for the international use of the dollar in this ever-changing financial landscape. For instance, one of those challenges is the complex relationship between the dollar and geoeconomics, commonly defined as the interplay between economic and geopolitical tools and objectives.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="Rising geopolitical tensions, sanctions against Russia, China's efforts to bolster usage of the renminbi, and economic fragmentation all can affect the international use of the dollar, most visibly as a store of value and reflected in its use in official foreign exchange reserves.", theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph="These same factors can also affect the dollar's role as a medium of exchange, such as in its use in trade invoicing, global banking, international debt issuance, and foreign exchange transactions.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="Linda Goldberg will present a paper addressing the effects of geoeconomic tensions, focusing on the dollar's use in official foreign exchange reserves. Linda and her coauthors find that financial sanctions and geopolitical distance from the United States are associated with lower dollar shares in foreign exchange reserves.", theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph="Looking more broadly, Ryan Chahrour will present work exploring the potential effects of escalating conflict and protectionism on the dollar's dominance in connection with efforts to promote the use of other currencies such as the renminbi. He and his coauthors find that both sanctions and policies that directly support the international role of the renminbi may reduce the prominence of the dollar if these sanctions and policies are long-lasting.", theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph="The shifting cross-border payments landscape—including the rapid growth of digital currencies—could also pose challenges to the dominant role of the U.S. dollar. Angelo Ranaldo will provide an overview of aspects of that payments landscape, focusing on the world's largest multicurrency cash settlement system for foreign exchange, the Continuous Linked Settlement payment system, and its role in facilitating cross-border payments by reducing settlement risk.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='In the panel moderated by Michelle Neal this afternoon, the panelists will take a broader look at the current landscape of cross-border payment systems and how new technologies such as central bank digital currencies and faster transactions could potentially affect U.S. dollar usage and global capital flows.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Stijn Claessens, in his keynote address, will expand on similar themes and pose questions that still need to be explored by researchers engaged on this topic.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='While recognizing that the U.S. dollar may face some challenges to its dominance in the future, we, as policymakers, are also attuned to the potential financial stability challenges that the current broad use of the U.S. dollar can pose for financial systems in the United States and the rest of the world.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='For example, past experiences show that foreign shocks can transmit to the United States when investors and governments seek a safe haven to protect the value of their assets in periods of stress.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Such a "flight to the dollar" means that dollars are in especially high demand in funding markets around the globe during these episodes, as we saw during the Global Financial Crisis and the financial turmoil at the outset of the COVID-19 pandemic.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The Federal Reserve supports the use of dollars internationally through our liquidity facilities, including the central bank liquidity swap lines, which provide foreign central banks with the capacity to deliver U.S. dollar funding to institutions in their jurisdictions.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Scott Davis and Moritz Lenel will discuss the effectiveness of these swap lines in their respective papers. Using different approaches, they find that the availability of U.S. dollars through central bank swap lines mitigates the appreciation of the dollar with respect to other currencies in episodes of stress and reduces deviations from covered interest rate parity.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='This evidence suggests that the central bank swap lines not only ensure that credit continues to flow to U.S. households and businesses, but also that these swap lines have effects that enhance financial stability and, thus, the standing of the U.S. dollar as the dominant global currency.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='In closing, I would like to reiterate the importance of understanding how changes in the global landscape may affect the central role of the dollar in the global economy and financial system.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='I also want to thank you for taking the time to join the discussion over the next two days. This conference brings together world-class researchers, practitioners, and policymakers dedicated to understanding and addressing these important topics.', theme='other')]

title: On the Road Ahead, Cherish the Detours
speaker: Governor Adriana D. Kugler
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph="I tell you this because I am probably an unlikely person to have been appointed to the Federal Reserve Board, as the first Latin policymaker in the Fed's history. I was raised in Colombia and came to the United States at age 15, speaking almost no English.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Some of you probably came to the University of Virginia (UVA) and Batten knowing exactly what you wanted to do, with a clear view of the path to get there. Some of you probably settled on that goal and that path over the course of your studies.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="It is reassuring, and very tempting, to set one's sights on one and only one goal and to stay strictly focused on the path to get there. Any map will show the most direct route from Charlottesville to Washington—just take a right turn at Gainesville, right?", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='As I said earlier, this approach to your career planning might contradict some very good advice from your professors and advisers, and maybe from your own parents, on how best to use the great advantage of your education at the Batten School.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="My point with all this biography is to show how the crucial professional experiences in my life have come from keeping my options open, being open to new opportunities, and taking risks. It is reassuring, and very tempting, to set one's sights on one and only one goal and to stay strictly focused on the path to get there.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Be open to those possibilities. Be ready to try new things. One of the things you may gain from this approach is discovering talents and abilities that you may not know you had.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='To invoke a principle of economics, trying new things and considering new possibilities may help you discover your comparative advantage. Discovering a comparative advantage in this way is really just about learning more about yourself, a more general goal for life that I would recommend to everyone.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='You may be surprised at how often the winding road brings you back to old landmarks you may have previously visited, but now with a stronger set of tools for providing service.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='My own career so far has followed a winding road. It is certainly not what I expected when I was sitting where you are sitting today.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='But there are other destinations, and other ways to get where you are going, that may make the journey more enriching and rewarding.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Be open to all that. Congratulations, again, to the Class of 2024, and the best of luck wherever the road takes you.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='It is with that latter point in mind that I am going to tell you about my own experience and the importance of allowing yourself to take risks and follow your own path as you pursue a career in public service.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='And, importantly, I have chosen to take risks along the way. Yet what was always a constant was my commitment to use my technical expertise to tackle poverty and social challenges.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='I want to emphasize that my career was not linear or perfectly planned, but rather I have chosen to take detours.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Any map will show the most direct route from Charlottesville to Washington—just take a right turn at Gainesville, right?', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Trying new things and considering new possibilities may help you discover your comparative advantage.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='For decades, I spent much of my career in academia pursuing answers to my big questions on poverty by doing research and teaching at universities.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='I want to emphasize that my career was not linear or perfectly planned, but rather I have chosen to take detours.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Any map will show the most direct route from Charlottesville to Washington—just take a right turn at Gainesville, right?', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Stepping into these institutions pushed me out of my comfort zone and into the world of policy and discussions about what it took to prepare for Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) meetings while I was a grad student immersed in a highly technical PhD. program.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='I know as students, many of you have already done internships and searched for these opportunities around policymaking, and I want to tell you that this is exactly what will make you grow moving forward.', theme='other')]

title: Payments Innovation, Technical Standards, and the Federal Reserve's Roles
speaker: Governor Christopher J. Waller
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph='As payments technology advances at a rapid pace, technical standards must also evolve.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The check clearing infrastructure at the time, however, was regional, creating a patchwork network reliant on correspondent banks to move and clear checks across regions, often at high cost and with long delays.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Immediately after 9/11, planes were grounded, and check payments, which were still largely paper-based, could not be processed.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Innovators see an opportunity for enhancements in payments, whether through the introduction of new capabilities or finding ways to alleviate frictions such as speed, cost, and accessibility.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='While achieving goals like network scale and interoperability is a complex problem, technical standards are one part of the solution to support consistent communication among existing and emerging technologies.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Technical standards—such as those developed within the International Organization for Standardization (ISO)—are voluntary, open, and consensus-based.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Considerations and Lessons Learned... title: Growth and Change at Community Development Financial Institutions
speaker: Governor Lisa D. Cook
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph="It is also wonderful to see that many more Americans are becoming aware of CDFIs. A CDFI in Arkansas, People Trust, was featured in the 2023 short film 'The Barber of Little Rock.' That documentary was nominated for an Oscar at this year's Academy Awards. In the film, the founder talks about how the People Trust name is inspired by potential borrowers, some of whom had been turned away by other institutions and want to prove they are trustworthy, creditworthy, and able to run successful businesses.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='CDFIs are having a moment off the silver screen, too. A significant portion of the federal funding directed to community development activities during the height of the pandemic flowed through CDFIs. These investments exemplify how CDFIs can meet increased demand while managing rapid growth through expanded capitalization.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Why Are CDFIs Important? As all of you in the room know, CDFIs represent a range of institution types, including banks, credit unions, loan funds, and venture capital funds. They provide loans to entrepreneurs to start or expand businesses, families to purchase their first homes, healthy food retailers to operate in food deserts, community health centers to service low-income communities, and they also support many other community and economic development activities.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="Termed by some as 'financial first responders,' CDFIs have the creativity, mission, and funding structures to respond to needs through customized products and services for the people and communities they serve. CDFIs are a critical source of financing for organizations working on the front lines of community development.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='When speaking about CDFIs, it is essential to highlight whom they serve and where they work. CDFIs frequently work with historically underserved populations and communities. Roughly 20 percent of CDFIs are headquartered in counties with persistently high poverty rates, and 40 percent are located in communities of color.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Therefore, it is encouraging to see that the industry is growing both in terms of number of certified CDFIs and total assets held. From 2018 to the start of 2023, the number of certified CDFIs rose 40 percent and assets have nearly tripled, according to research from the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="Interest in CDFI products and services also continues to grow. The Federal Reserve Bank of Richmond's 2023 CDFI Survey indicates that nearly three-quarters of CDFI respondents experienced an increase in demand for their products from 2022 to 2023.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="Despite growth in demand, many CDFIs still face challenges in today's economic environment, especially as it relates to meeting the needs of the communities they serve. I emphasize that the communities CDFIs serve are ones that were disproportionately impacted by business and school closures as well as negative health outcomes resulting from the pandemic.", theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='First, demand is outpacing the supply of capital. While there has been an influx of federal funding for CDFIs, much of that is tied to pandemic-related relief programs and other programs with specific purposes.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Second, the increasing cost of lending capital makes extending affordable credit to their low- and moderate-income borrowers more difficult.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Third, CDFIs are not immune to the challenges associated with hiring and retaining staff, and managing labor costs, that are faced by many employers in a tight job market.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='How the Federal Reserve System Supports CDFIs The Board and regional Reserve Banks have long understood the unique value of CDFIs. CDFIs are key partners to our Reserve Bank Community Development programs and integral members of our Board and Reserve Bank Community Development Advisory Councils.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="As mentioned, CDFIs were key providers of PPP funding in low- and moderate-income communities during the pandemic. The Federal Reserve's PPP Liquidity Facility created more opportunities for banks and CDFIs to leverage funding in our most vulnerable communities impacted by the pandemic.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="Another key area of the Federal Reserve's support for CDFIs is research, which is an area of interest for several of the Reserve Banks. In particular, I would like to take a moment to acknowledge the stellar research efforts of our host, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, related to the growth of the CDFI industry and the origination and sale of loans by CDFIs.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='And in my role here at the Federal Reserve, I am proud of the many ways the entire System has supported the timely and important work of CDFIs. I look forward to continuing this vital partnership.', theme='other')]
