title: Economic Outlook
speaker: Governor Lisa D. Cook
tags:
[ThemeTag(paragraph='I would like to start with a discussion of the U.S. economy, including the implications of international developments, and then talk about my approach as a policymaker and how I view the current stance of monetary policy.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The Labor Market
I will begin with the labor market, which is very strong. Employment rebounded much more swiftly post-pandemic than it did during previous recoveries and has continued to grow at a rapid pace of about 440,000 jobs a month so far this year.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph="Inflation
On the price stability side of the Fed's mandate, inflation remains stubbornly and unacceptably high, and data over the past few months show that inflationary pressures remain broad based.", theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The data on actual inflation, however, have showed a slower decline than I had anticipated, and I am seeking to better understand the reasons.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Much of the surge in inflation over the past year was rooted in the incomplete recovery of aggregate supply from pandemic-related shutdowns. Global supply chain disruptions had especially wide-reaching effects.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='U.S. gasoline prices have fallen more than $1 per gallon since June, reflecting the fall in oil prices and refinery margins and helping to slow the monthly increases in headline consumer prices.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Although supply constraints in goods appear to be easing, we cannot assume that improvement will be steady. Globally, at least one potential snag is the possible reduction in Russian oil supply later this year when European sanctions come into full force.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Consumer prices continue to rise rapidly over a broad range of services as demand for services recovers. Continued strong wage increases will likely put further upward pressure on service price inflation.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The widespread nature of the inflation pressures suggests that the overall economy is very tight, with constrained supply continuing to fall short of demand.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='While there is heterogeneity across countries, high inflation is a global phenomenon. And financial conditions also have tightened abroad, as foreign central banks have raised policy rates.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph="My Approach to Policymaking
The role of policymaker robs economists of one of the profession's great joys, which is to simply ruminate or expound on the vagaries of economics. In my new role, I must make judgments on the economy, weighing new information against existing theories, and translate those judgments into appropriate policy action.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='To a large extent, my own research and experiences shape my views on policy. My research on economic growth has given me an appreciation for the dual mandate and the importance of economic and financial stability for fostering innovation and growth.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Paying close attention to the data is key, which, of course, includes readings on inflation and the labor market. But we must be humble about our ability to draw firm conclusions and prepare for inevitable surprises.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='In considering whether standard models remain appropriate, one focus for me is the well-known long and variable lag between monetary policy actions and their effect on the real economy and on inflation.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='I believe that uncertain times require a risk-management approach to policy-setting—looking not just at the expected outcomes, but also considering the most salient risks in setting the policy stance.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='My Perspective on Monetary Policy
How do these experiences and the principles of data dependence and risk management influence my views on current monetary policy?', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='In our current economy, with a very strong labor market and inflation far above our goal, I believe a risk-management approach requires a strong focus on taming inflation.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Front-loading has several positive features. It puts monetary restraint into place more quickly to reduce demand while supply is constrained.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='At some point, as we continue to tighten monetary policy, it will become appropriate to slow the pace of increases while we assess the effects of our cumulative tightening on the economy and inflation.', theme='inflation')]

title: The Economic Outlook with a Look at the Housing Market
speaker: Governor Christopher J. Waller
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph="My subject is the outlook for the U.S. economy and inflation, and the Federal Reserve's efforts to get inflation under control.", theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Recent data on economic activity suggest that after a slight contraction in gross domestic product in the first half of this year, the economy is posed for modest but below-trend growth in the latter half.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Since I last spoke about the economic outlook on September 9, we have received two important pieces of data on inflation for August, consumer price index (CPI) and the price index for personal consumption expenditures (PCE).', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='This is not the inflation outcome I am looking for to support a slower pace of rate hikes or a lower terminal policy rate than projected in the September 2022 SEP.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Let me turn to the troubling persistence of inflation. In the past couple of inflation reports, housing services has been a major contributor to measured inflation.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='There has been a considerable imbalance in the supply and demand for housing for some time.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Housing demand increased strongly in the years leading up to the pandemic, sustained by relatively low interest rates and growing household incomes.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Despite the risk of a material correction in house prices, several factors help reduce my concern that such a correction would trigger a wave of mortgage defaults and potentially destabilize the financial system.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Because people still need a place to live, demand for rental housing has remained quite strong.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The measures of inflation that receive the most attention in the United States attempt to measure the prices of goods and services consumed by households. For housing, this means measuring the price of consuming the shelter and other services provided by a home.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph="So now let's consider the implications of this picture of the current and future housing market for overall inflation and monetary policy.", theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='As we think about policy actions for the remainder of the year, one can look at the Summary of Economic Projections released by the FOMC at our meeting last month.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='I anticipate additional rate hikes into early next year, and I will be watching the data carefully to decide the appropriate pace of tightening as we continue to move into more restrictive territory.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph="In considering what might happen to alter my expectations about the path of policy, I've read some speculation recently that financial stability concerns could possibly lead the FOMC to slow rate increases or halt them earlier than expected.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='One factor that is likely helping to stabilize the financial system is the existence of monetary policy tools which could serve as a backup source of liquidity in times of financial stress.', theme='other')]

title: Technology’s Impact on the Post-Pandemic Economy
speaker: Governor Philip N. Jefferson
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph='Today I would like to continue the discussion you have been having about tech-enabled responses to the pandemic. Then I would like to delve a bit further into what those pandemic-related disruptions have meant for economic activity at the microlevel and how the changes of the past few years affect how I view the outlook for the macroeconomy.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Technology-Enabled Solutions to Pandemic Disruptions\nTurning to the subject of this conference, there is no question that technology helped households and businesses to adapt and adjust in many ways to the disruption brought about by the pandemic. Those adaptations—from enabling people to keep working to helping businesses stay open—undoubtedly prevented worse outcomes.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Likewise, the labor market showed great adaptability in the rapidity and relative ease that many sectors showed in shifting to remote working. Of course, that did not translate to all areas of employment, such as those jobs that require person-to-person interaction.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The shift to remote and hybrid learning, however, was difficult, but without technology, learning during lockdown might have ceased entirely. In some cases, schools were closed for only a few weeks or months, and the entire in-person learning apparatus was replaced with technology-enabled remote learning.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The payments system has also seen an acceleration in alternative online and mobile payment methods as well as contactless payment options. We all remember the onset of the pandemic, when social distancing became imperative and delivery and curbside pickup became the norm for many.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='These are just a few of the examples you have been discussing, and there are many more. The pandemic, and the tech-enabled responses to it, changed the economy in fundamental ways that will likely not revert.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='As I look ahead, I am considering how those changes affect the outlook, and I would like to speak a bit about how I see the economy evolving as we move forward.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The labor market remains strong, as can be seen across a variety of measures, from the low unemployment rate to the high quits rate, which illustrates the confidence of workers who are willing to leave their jobs in pursuit of better ones.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='With still-strong labor demand and sluggish labor supply, the job market remains very tight. Workers are moving between jobs more rapidly than in the past, putting upward pressure on wages.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Nonetheless, inflation remains elevated, and this is the problem that concerns me most.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph="Inflation creates economic burdens for households and businesses, and everyone feels its effects. It can also change people's expectations about how long lasting price rises will be.", theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph="An important outcome of the shifts you have been discussing, from firms' production patterns and distribution mechanisms to consumers' purchasing decisions, is that inflation dynamics likely changed also.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Restoring price stability may take some time and will likely entail a period of below-trend growth.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='It is too soon to say whether the pandemic and the changes it brought—many of which this conference has covered—are going to be permanent or ebb as time goes by.', theme='other')]

title: Global Financial Stability Considerations for Monetary Policy in a High-Inflation Environment
speaker: Vice Chair Lael Brainard
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph='At “Financial Stability Considerations for Monetary Policy,” a research conference organized by  the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System and  the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, New York, New York ', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='I want to start by thanking Anna Kovner, Rochelle Edge, and Bill Bassett for organizing this conference. The current global environment highlights the importance of having strong analytic and empirical foundations to understand financial stability considerations for monetary policy, and the research presented today will help strengthen those foundations.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Inflation is very high in the United States and abroad, and the risk of additional inflationary shocks cannot be ruled out. In August, CPI (consumer price index) inflation on a 12-month basis was 8.3 percent in the United States, 9.9 percent in the United Kingdom, 9.8 percent in Sweden, 9.1 percent in the euro area, 8.7 percent in Mexico, 7.0 percent in Canada, and 5.7 percent in Korea.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Central banks facing high inflation are tightening monetary policy rapidly to damp demand and bring it into alignment with supply, which is constrained in a variety of sectors.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Many central banks around the world have pivoted monetary policy strongly in order to maintain anchored expectations and forestall second-round effects from high inflation becoming embedded in wage and price setting.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='At a global level, monetary policy tightening is also proceeding at a rapid pace by historical standards. Including the Federal Reserve, nine central banks in advanced economies accounting for half of global GDP have raised rates by 125 basis points or more in the past six months.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='It will take some time for the global tightening to have its full effect in many sectors. While the effect on financial conditions tends to be immediate or even anticipatory, the effects on activity and price setting in different sectors may occur with a lag.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="In contrast, spillovers through exchange rate channels tend to go in opposite directions. The Federal Reserve's broad nominal U.S. dollar index has appreciated over 10 percent year to date.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='We are attentive to financial vulnerabilities that could be exacerbated by the advent of additional adverse shocks.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='For some emerging economies, high interest rates in combination with weaker demand in advanced economies could increase capital outflow pressures, particularly commodity importers facing higher commodity prices and weaker exchange rates.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='This is especially true at times when fiscal, macroprudential, and monetary buffers are more limited.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='With respect to macroprudential buffers, nearly all of the jurisdictions that built countercyclical capital buffers before the pandemic released those buffers at the outset of the pandemic, and the buffers have not been fully replenished so far.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='And of course, monetary policy is focused on restoring price stability in a high-inflation environment.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph="The Federal Reserve's policy deliberations are informed by analysis of how U.S. developments may affect the global financial system and how foreign developments in turn affect the U.S. economic outlook and risks to the financial system.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='High inflation imposes significant hardships by eroding purchasing power, especially for those households that spend the greatest share of their incomes on essentials like food, housing, and transportation.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='In the modal outlook, monetary policy tightening to temper demand, in combination with improvements in supply, is expected to reduce demand–supply imbalances and reduce inflation over time.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='It will take time for the full effect of tighter financial conditions to work through different sectors and to bring inflation down.', theme='other')]

title: Welcoming Remarks

title: Bringing Inflation Down
speaker: Vice Chair Lael Brainard
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph="Over the past year, inflation has been very high in the United States and around the world (figure 1). High inflation imposes costs on all households, and especially low-income households. The multiple waves of the pandemic, combined with Russia's war against Ukraine, unleashed a series of supply shocks hitting goods, labor, and commodities that, in combination with strong demand, have contributed to ongoing high inflation.", theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph="While last year's rapid pace of economic growth was boosted by accommodative fiscal and monetary policy as well as reopening, demand has moderated this year as those tailwinds have abated. A sizable fiscal drag on output growth alongside a sharp tightening in financial conditions has contributed to a slowing in activity.", theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The concentration of strong consumer spending in supply-constrained sectors has contributed to high inflation. Consumer spending is in the midst of an ongoing but still incomplete rotation back toward pre-pandemic patterns.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='In addition to the fiscal drag and tighter financial conditions, high inflation—particularly in food and gas prices—has restrained consumer spending by reducing real purchasing power.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Since the very elevated prices at the pump in June, the nationwide average price of a gallon of regular unleaded gasoline has declined every day throughout July and August, most recently falling below $4 a gallon, according to the American Automobile Association.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="In contrast, food price pressures continue to worsen, reflecting Russia's continuing war against Ukraine, as well as extreme weather events in the United States, Europe, and China.", theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Core inflation—inflation excluding volatile food and energy prices—also moderated in July.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='How long it takes to move inflation back down to 2 percent will depend on a combination of continued easing in supply constraints, slower demand growth, and lower markups, against the backdrop of anchored expectations.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Reductions in markups could also make an important contribution to reduced pricing pressures.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Using the available macroeconomic data, it is difficult to directly measure the impact of changes in mark-ups on price inflation.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='As we follow through on our plan to move monetary policy to an appropriately restrictive stance, the effect of the increased policy rate and pace of balance sheet shrinkage should put downward pressure on aggregate demand, particularly in interest-sensitive sectors like housing.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Since pivoting last year, our actions and communications have tightened financial conditions significantly and at a much more rapid speed than earlier cycles.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='It may take some time for the full effect of these tighter financial conditions to work their way through the economy.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='At some point in the tightening cycle, the risks will become more two-sided.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='We are in this for as long as it takes to get inflation down.', theme='inflation')]

title: Progress on Fast Payments for All: An Update on FedNow
speaker: Vice Chair Lael Brainard
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph="The payment system is a critical part of America's infrastructure that touches everyone.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="Fostering a safe, efficient, and widely accessible payments infrastructure has been a central part of the Fed's mission since the very beginning.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The FedNow Service will transform the way everyday payments are made throughout the economy, bringing substantial gains to households and businesses through the ability to send instant payments at any time on any day, and the funds being immediately available to recipients to make other payments or manage cash flow efficiently.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Immediate availability of funds could be especially important for households managing their finances paycheck to paycheck or small businesses with cash flow constraints. Having the capacity to manage money in real time could help households avoid costly late payment fees or free up working capital for small businesses to finance growth.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph="To deliver on the promise of a payment system for the future, the Federal Reserve has made a substantial commitment to the FedNow platform, which has benefited from the innovative technologies and approaches proven by global technology companies that are vital for today's always on digital economy.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='We have also invested heavily in stakeholder engagement to ensure readiness for service adoption through efforts like the pilot program, the FedNow Explorer resource, the FedNow Community, the service provider showcase, and the FedNow Early Adopter Workshop.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Just as the Federal Reserve has made a substantial commitment to our new instant payment infrastructure, we are calling on industry stakeholders to do the same.', theme='employment')]

title: Monetary Policy and Price Stability
speaker: Chair Jerome H. Powell
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph="The Federal Open Market Committee's (FOMC) overarching focus right now is to bring inflation back down to our 2 percent goal.", theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Price stability is the responsibility of the Federal Reserve and serves as the bedrock of our economy. Without price stability, the economy does not work for anyone.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Reducing inflation is likely to require a sustained period of below-trend growth.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Inflation is running well above 2 percent, and high inflation has continued to spread through the economy.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='We are moving our policy stance purposefully to a level that will be sufficiently restrictive to return inflation to 2 percent.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Restoring price stability will likely require maintaining a restrictive policy stance for some time.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The historical record cautions strongly against prematurely loosening policy.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="Committee participants' most recent individual projections from the June SEP showed the median federal funds rate running slightly below 4 percent through the end of 2023.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='In particular, we are drawing on three important lessons.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The first lesson is that central banks can and should take responsibility for delivering low and stable inflation.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='It may seem strange now that central bankers and others once needed convincing on these two fronts, but as former Chairman Ben Bernanke has shown, both propositions were widely questioned during the Great Inflation period.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="The second lesson is that the public's expectations about future inflation can play an important role in setting the path of inflation over time.", theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='If the public expects that inflation will remain low and stable over time, then, absent major shocks, it likely will.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='During the 1970s, as inflation climbed, the anticipation of high inflation became entrenched in the economic decisionmaking of households and businesses.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="One useful insight into how actual inflation may affect expectations about its future path is based in the concept of 'rational inattention.'", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='That brings me to the third lesson, which is that we must keep at it until the job is done.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='History shows that the employment costs of bringing down inflation are likely to increase with delay, as high inflation becomes more entrenched in wage and price setting.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Our aim is to avoid that outcome by acting with resolve now.', theme='other')]

title: Technology, Innovation, and Financial Services
speaker: Governor Michelle W. Bowman
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph='Technology Is Changing Financial Services', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Federal Reserve Support for Innovation', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='For the past few years, I have been working to assist banks to address the challenges brought by the process of partnering with a third-party service provider.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Last year at this time, the federal banking agencies released a guide designed to assist community banks to assess risks in constructing and considering relationships with fintech companies.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='And lastly, this past September, the Federal Reserve published a paper detailing industry perspectives and experiences on the different types of partnerships between community banks and fintech companies.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Crypto-Assets', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Federal Reserve staff is working to articulate supervisory expectations for banks on a variety of digital asset-related activities, including', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Earlier this week, we released supervisory guidance addressing banks that are engaging in or seeking to engage in crypto-asset related activities.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Artificial Intelligence', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="The Federal Reserve is taking a similar approach with respect to banks' use of AI.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Payments: FedNow and Central Bank Digital Currencies', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='My expectation is that FedNow addresses the issues that some have raised about the need for a CBDC.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Novel Charters and Access to Federal Reserve Account Services', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Before I wrap up, let me touch on one more topic that relates to innovation in bank charter types.', theme='other')]

title: Fighting Inflation in Challenging Times
speaker: Governor Michelle W. Bowman
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph="I'll start with a recap of the decision from July's Federal Open Market Committee meeting and then move on to my thoughts about the current economic uncertainty and challenges that lie ahead. The number one challenge, of course, is inflation, which continues to be much too high, and a heavy burden for households and businesses.", theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Inflation continued to climb in June, reaching 9.1 percent as measured by the consumer price index. This is yet another concerningly high reading, and it set another 40-year record high despite the expectation of many forecasters that inflation had peaked earlier in the year.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Regardless of the source of the inflationary pressure, the Federal Reserve has a duty to bring inflation down to our 2 percent target. This duty is mandated by Congress to carry out monetary policy that results in price stability—meaning low and stable inflation.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='I see a significant risk of high inflation into next year for necessities including food, housing, fuel, and vehicles.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The supply problems pushing up inflation seem likely to persist.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph="Based on current economic conditions and the outlook I just described, I supported the FOMC's decision last week to raise the federal funds rate another 75 basis points. I also support the Committee's view that 'ongoing increases' would be appropriate at coming meetings.", theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='On the other side of our dual mandate, maximum employment, we continue to see a tight labor market, though there are some emerging signs that would support expectations of loosening.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='One aspect of the job market that has not recovered is labor force participation. Based on the pre-pandemic trend, there are nearly four million people who are still sitting out of a strong labor market.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='My base case is for a pickup in growth during the second half of this year and for moderate growth in 2023.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='With my outlook out of the way, let me turn to another of my responsibilities at the Fed, which is bank regulation and supervision.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="I am sure that we will have the opportunity to discuss many issues of interest to you during our discussion, but I'd like to mention a pending rulemaking that would update the Community Reinvestment Act.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Of course, my comments about the benefits of public participation in rulemaking apply beyond the CRA proposal, and there are other regulatory topics on the horizon that would benefit from robust engagement.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='I should also briefly mention three other regulatory topics of interest to all banks, including those here today.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="First, the Fed's LIBOR proposal is currently out for comment on a short timeline. That proposal implements the recently passed LIBOR Act by providing default rules for certain contracts that use the soon to be discontinued reference rate.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='I will conclude with a brief comment on supervision. While the trend of returning to on-site bank examination is continuing, progress has been somewhat slow.', theme='other')]

title: Strengthening the CRA: A Conversation with Representatives of Native Communities
speaker: Vice Chair Lael Brainard
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph='As of the most recent 2019 data, over 16 percent of Native Americans are unbanked—three times higher than the rate for all U.S. households.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='In part, the large share that is unbanked reflects low access to a bank branch. As of 2021, majority-Native American counties have an average of only two and a half bank branches—less than one-tenth the 26-branch overall average for all counties nationwide.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Native small businesses often struggle to access capital: CRA small business and small farm lending per capita in majority-Native American census tracts is only about a quarter of that in majority-White-non-Hispanic tracts.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The interagency CRA proposal was informed by consultation with Native representatives through roundtables, listening sessions, meetings, and comment letters.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='First, the proposal provides greater incentives for community investments in Native Land Areas by providing enhanced clarity and specificity about what activities qualify for CRA credit.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The proposed activities in Native Land Areas cover four specific place-based categories: revitalization; essential community facilities; essential community infrastructure; and disaster preparedness and climate resiliency.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The proposal also provides clarity for Native community development financial institutions (CDFIs) and minority depository institutions (MDIs).', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='In another important change, the proposal would result in greater CRA activity outside of where banks have branches and physical locations in order to address unmet needs in communities that have more limited access to bank branches.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph="To this end, we also propose evaluating the impact and responsiveness of a bank's community development activities through a series of specific qualitative factors, with activities benefitting Native communities as one of those specific factors.", theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='In addition, now that many banks conduct significant lending and investments outside of their branch networks, it is important to ensure CRA accounts for these different business models.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="Finally, the proposal would continue to emphasize a bank's performance in the local communities where it maintains branches, regardless of their performance in other areas.", theme='employment')]

title: Monetary Policy in a World of Conflicting Data
speaker: Governor Christopher J. Waller
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph="Waller begins by acknowledging that inflation has been high for some time and that it is essential to bring it down to the Fed's target rate of 2%. He notes that the labor market is strong, with low unemployment rates and historically high job vacancies.", theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Waller argues that monetary policy needs to be more restrictive to curb demand and reduce inflationary pressures. He supports another 75-basis-point increase in the federal funds rate at the July meeting, bringing it close to neutral (a level that neither stimulates nor restricts demand).', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Waller expects further rate increases will be needed to make monetary policy truly restrictive, but these will depend on incoming data. He anticipates a decline in inflation as actual and anticipated hikes by the Fed cool demand for products and labor.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph="The Fed's medium-term economic outlook suggests a soft landing is possible, with total PCE inflation falling from its current elevated level to 2.2% by the end of 2024. Unemployment is expected to rise to 3.7% at the end of this year and 4.1% by the end of 2024.", theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Waller acknowledges that there are some risks, such as future pandemic-related disruptions and global economic pressures related to the war in Ukraine, which could affect the economy and policy decisions.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The key points from this speech are:', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='1. **Monetary Policy**: The Fed needs to be more restrictive to curb demand and reduce inflationary pressures.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='2. **Future Rate Hikes**: Further rate increases will be needed to make monetary policy truly restrictive, but these will depend on incoming data.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='3. **Economic Outlook**: A soft landing is possible, with total PCE inflation falling from its current elevated level to 2.2% by the end of 2024.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='4. **Risk Considerations**: There are risks related to future pandemic-related disruptions and global economic pressures.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="Overall, Waller's speech emphasizes the need for continued policy tightening to bring down inflation and achieve a soft landing in the economy.", theme='inflation')]

title: Crypto-Assets and Decentralized Finance through a Financial Stability Lens
speaker: Vice Chair Lael Brainard
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph='The text is a speech by Lael Brainard, Governor of the Federal Reserve Board, discussing the potential risks and benefits of digital assets, including cryptocurrencies and stablecoins.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='1. **Risk of runs**: Stablecoins, which are pegged to fiat currency, are highly vulnerable to runs, where investors withdraw their funds quickly.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='2. **Fragmentation or dominance**: The market for stablecoins is currently fragmented among several players, but there is a risk that one stablecoin might become dominant, posing a threat to financial stability.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='3. **Regulation needed**: Brainard argues that well-regulated stablecoins could bring additional competition to payments and enhance financial stability.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='4. **Central bank digital currency (CBDC)**: She suggests that a CBDC could provide a neutral trusted settlement layer in the future crypto financial system, enhancing stability.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='5. **Risk management and compliance**: The speech highlights the importance of risk management and compliance in the digital asset market, noting that intermediaries must bear costs to ensure safety and prevent crime.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="Overall, Brainard's speech emphasizes the need for careful consideration and regulation of digital assets to mitigate potential risks and maximize benefits.", theme='other')]

title: The Outlook for Inflation and Monetary Policy
speaker: Governor Michelle W. Bowman
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph='I will touch on some of the banking issues I expect are on your minds, but one of the biggest issues for everyone right now is inflation, what the Fed is doing to get inflation under control, and the implications for your businesses, your customers, and your communities.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Inflation is the highest we have seen in the United States in 40 years and so far it shows little sign of moderating. At the same time, the economy is growing at a moderate pace, and the labor market is extremely tight, as indicated by a variety of measures including reports of many employers unable to find workers despite significantly raising wages.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph="Inflation is a significant challenge for everyone, but it hits lower- and moderate-income people the hardest, since they spend a larger share of their incomes on necessities and often have less savings to fall back on. Inflation is also a burden for businesses that must somehow balance unpredictable costs while setting prices that aren't so high that they discourage customers from purchasing.", theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Inflation that continues at these levels is a threat to sustained employment growth and to the overall health of the economy.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The inflation data show that, after moderating slightly for a short time, price increases for motor vehicles have picked up again, energy prices rose sharply in May, and prices for food have risen more than 10 percent from a year ago.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph="One important factor that we often point to in driving today's spending decisions and inflation outlook are expectations of future inflation. Near-term expectations tend to rise as current inflation increases, but when inflation expectations over the longer-term—the next 5 to 10 years—begin to rise, it may indicate that consumers and businesses have less confidence in the Fed's ability to address higher inflation.", theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The benefits from a tight labor market are easy to see—the U.S. economy continued to add jobs at a pace of 400,000 per month for the past three months, which is remarkable considering the low number of people looking for work.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Job creation signals strong labor market demand, particularly in the current environment, with a large number of available jobs and fewer job seekers.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='While the strong job market has brought some of these workers back into the workforce, it seems that many are still waiting or may not return, meaning that labor shortages will likely persist in many sectors of the economy.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph="I've laid out many of the challenges, so now let me talk about what the Federal Reserve is doing to get inflation under control. In the face of inflation that continues to be much too high and in light of the recent high readings, the FOMC raised the federal funds rate by 75 basis points at our most recent meeting last week.", theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph="I strongly supported the FOMC's decision last week, and I expect to support additional rate increases until we see significant progress toward bringing inflation down.", theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph="The case for further rate hikes is made stronger by the current level of the 'real' federal funds rate, which is the difference between the nominal rate and near-term inflation expectations. With inflation much higher than the federal funds rate, the real federal funds rate is negative, even after our rate increases this year.", theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='While I expect that the labor market will remain strong as the FOMC continues to tighten monetary policy, these actions do not come without risk. But in my view, our number one responsibility is to reduce inflation.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph="As a step toward that goal, I also supported the Committee's action to begin reducing the Fed's balance sheet, which is providing unneeded economic stimulus making inflation worse.", theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='In closing, I know that inflation, and our efforts to lower it, may present challenges for banks.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="I look forward to hearing your thoughts on these issues, and I look forward to our discussion. Thanks again for the invitation to join you this week—it's great to be here with you to discuss these and other important matters.", theme='other')]

title: Lessons Learned on Normalizing Monetary Policy
speaker: Governor Christopher J. Waller
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph='At “Monetary Policy at a Crossroads,” a panel discussion hosted by the Dallas Society for Computational Economics, Dallas, Texas', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='This week, the Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) took another significant step toward achieving our inflation objective by raising the Federal Funds rate target by 75 basis points.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph="In addition to the Federal Reserve's emergency lending programs, the monetary policy actions taken during this time were deemed extraordinary.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="Let's start at the beginning, when the United States was faced with the economic shock from COVID-19.", theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='All these actions were taken to support liquidity in the financial system and keep credit flowing to households, businesses and state and local governments.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='So, by requiring substantial further progress toward maximum employment to even begin the process of tightening policy, one might argue that it locked the Committee into holding the policy rate at the zero lower bound longer than was optimal.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='My takeaway is that a less restrictive tapering criteria would have allowed more flexibility to taper “sooner and gradually,” as opposed to the relatively “later and faster” approach that occurred.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='It can be argued that this meant getting the economy back to its 2019 state with very low unemployment and inflation near 2 percent.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='So, it should not have been a surprise that the policy rate would rise fast in 2022.', theme='other')]

title: Welcoming Remarks
speaker: Chair Jerome H. Powell
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph="The Federal Reserve's strong commitment to our price stability mandate contributes to the widespread confidence in the dollar as a store of value. To that end, my colleagues and I are acutely focused on returning inflation to our 2 percent objective.", theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Good morning, and welcome to the inaugural conference on the International Roles of the U.S. Dollar. Thank you all for participating and for lending your expertise on this important topic.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="The dollar's international role holds multiple benefits. For the United States, it lowers transaction fees and borrowing costs for U.S. households, businesses, and the government.", theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The wide use of the dollar globally can also pose financial stability challenges that can materially affect households, businesses, and markets.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='To summarize, I would like to stress the importance of the dollar to the U.S. and global economies and financial markets.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='It is critical that we understand the channels, connections, and effects of the role of the dollar.', theme='other')]

title: Risk in the Crypto Markets
speaker: Governor Christopher J. Waller
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph="The main issue in crypto-asset regulation isn't how to protect sophisticated crypto-investors; it's how to protect the rest of us.", theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Every aspect of them has expanded, from protocols and platforms, to instruments and intermediaries.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='High volatility is the rule, not the exception; fraud and theft occur regularly, often at large scale.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph="Crypto and DeFi may be new, but these kinds of freewheeling markets aren't.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Entry is often cheap, and exit is often swift. Competition can be fierce.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph="The argument goes, why should anyone bring regulation into a space that's not asking for it?", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="Let's focus on crypto-asset users, who are a very different group than just a few years ago.", theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph="Some of these users are seasoned professional investors, but others, of course, are not—they're attracted to a new and complicated market by curiosity...", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='New retail users, by definition, do not have crypto experience.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='What happens in the aftermath of these losses? On an individual level, one possibility is a dispute between the intermediary and its customers over poor due diligence...', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='This leads us to the main reason, in my view, that society wants to regulate new and poorly understood markets for financial products.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='In summary, financial regulation is typically demanded (1) by financial intermediaries as a form of liability protection...', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='On the contrary: Large-scale losses can easily occur even if these investors are getting the information they need to make decisions and are otherwise following the rules.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph="If we want to allow broad access to the crypto ecosystem, then the question isn't about what experienced users of that ecosystem want—it's about what the rest of the public needs...", theme='other')]

title: Commencement Remarks
speaker: Vice Chair Lael Brainard
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph='High inflation is our most pressing challenge. That is why we are taking strong actions that will bring inflation back down.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph="As central bankers, we don't think of inflation or unemployment as blue or red. We focus on data and proven solutions, and our mission is to serve all Americans.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Price stability is of greatest importance for lower-income families because they spend more than three-quarters of their paychecks on essentials like groceries, gas or bus fare, and rent—more than double the 31 percent spent by higher-income households.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph="The risk that turbulence will strike is always present, as I have learned from the many financial crises that have punctuated my own career. In the past decade alone, our communities have contended with the devastation of the Global Financial Crisis, the European Debt Crisis, the COVID-19 pandemic, and now the burden on stretched household budgets from Russia's war of aggression against Ukraine.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Maximum employment and stable low inflation benefit all Americans but are particularly important for those earning less.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='That is why we are taking strong actions that will bring inflation back down.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph="Ninety years ago, the first woman Cabinet Secretary, Frances Perkins, convinced a skeptical Franklin Roosevelt that unemployment insurance wasn't a handout but a smart investment.", theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='When there is the will to do so, with the support of Congress, we can and must use our tools to help protect families, businesses, and their communities from crisis and make the broader economy more resilient so it rebounds faster.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Maximum employment and stable low inflation benefit all Americans but are particularly important for those earning less.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Price stability is of greatest importance for lower-income families because they spend more than three-quarters of their paychecks on essentials like groceries, gas or bus fare, and rent—more than double the 31 percent spent by higher-income households.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='High inflation is our most pressing challenge. That is why we are taking strong actions that will bring inflation back down.', theme='inflation')]

title: Welcoming Remarks
speaker: Chair Jerome H. Powell
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph='Many of you are aware of the Center for Indian Country Development (CICD), our national institute dedicated to helping tribes reach their full economic potential.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Tribal leaders nationwide have also joined recent listening sessions to discuss the impacts of inflation.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Other Federal Reserve partnerships with Indian Country include initiatives on access to credit; Native community development financial institutions;', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The best insight and analysis come from people who live and work in communities and have an inside view of the struggles and opportunities within.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='input from tribal stakeholders has been invaluable to informing the important work of modernizing the Community Reinvestment Act, which was incorporated into the recently published proposal that we are looking forward to getting comments on.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='We also value the growing representation of tribal voices on our boards of directors and advisory councils at Reserve Banks, helping us to better understand economic conditions in Indian Country.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Tribal leaders nationwide have also joined recent listening sessions to discuss the impacts of inflation. title: Reflections on Monetary Policy in 2021
speaker: Governor Christopher J. Waller
tags:
[ThemeTag(paragraph='May 06, 2022
Governor Christopher J. Waller
At the 2022 Hoover Institution Monetary Conference, Stanford, California
I want to thank the organizers for inviting me to speak here today.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Let me start by reminding everyone of two immutable facts about setting monetary policy in the United States.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Back in September and December 2020, respectively, the Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) laid out guidance for raising the federal funds rate off the zero lower bound and for tapering asset purchases.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='A few months later, in March 2021, I made my first submission for the Summary of Economic title: High Inflation and the Outlook for Monetary Policy
speaker: Governor Michelle W. Bowman
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph='At the American Bankers Association Community Banking Conference, Palm Desert, California\nBefore we get to our conversation on community banking, I would like to briefly discuss my outlook for the U.S. economy and my view of appropriate monetary policy.\x101 As I see it, the main challenge for monetary policy now is to bring inflation down without harming the ongoing economic expansion.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Inflation is much too high. Last year I noted that inflationary pressures associated with strong demand and constrained supply could take longer to subside than many expected. Since then, those problems have persisted and inflation has broadened, reaching the highest rate that Americans have faced in forty years.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='In the near term, I expect that uncomfortably high inflation will persist at least through the first half of 2022. We may see signs of inflation easing in the second half of the year, but there is a substantial risk that high inflation could persist.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='My base case is that inflation will moderate later this year, which will depend, in part, on appropriate actions by the Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC). But with wage growth lagging behind inflation for the past year, many families may find it challenging to make ends meet and continued rising home prices will likely prevent many from entering the housing market.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph="Now let me turn to the implications of this outlook for monetary policy. In my view, conditions in the labor market have been and are currently consistent with the FOMC's goal of maximum employment, and as such, my focus has been on the persistently high inflation.", theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='In our most recent monetary policy statement—which was released following our January meeting—we indicated that "with inflation well above 2 percent and a strong labor market," we expected that it would "soon be appropriate to raise the target range for the federal funds rate."2 I fully supported that assessment,', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='I expect that these steps will contribute to an easing in inflation pressures in the coming months, but further steps will likely be needed this year to tighten monetary policy.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Turning to the labor market, which continues to tighten, indications are that the Omicron infection surge earlier this year has not left a negative imprint on the economy or slowed job creation. I expect to see continued strength in the job market this year, with further gains in employment, and my hope is that more Americans return to the labor force and find work.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The strength in job creation is a big positive for those seeking employment and for their families. Even with the improving labor market, I still hear from businesses that qualified workers are difficult to find, and labor shortages remain a drag on hiring and on economic growth.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='In addition, rising costs and hiring difficulties continue to be burdens for small businesses.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='I intend to support prompt and decisive action to lower inflation, and today I will explain how the Fed is pursuing this goal.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='In January, the Consumer Price Index rose to a 12-month rate of 7.5 percent, which, consistent with other recent monthly readings, was even higher than expected.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='And continued tightness in the labor market indicates that upward pressure on wages and other employment compensation is not likely to moderate soon.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The adoption of technology and innovation is really at the heart of the major issues facing community banks. We see banks, fintech companies, and tech firms exploring various technologies to enhance their payments systems, expand consumer access, improve back-office operations, and create new financial products and services.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='This interest and the increasing interest in crypto- and digital assets have created a need to work together with the other federal banking agencies to give the industry better and more useful regulatory feedback as banks consider approaches to integrating crypto- and digital asset related activities into their service offerings.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Evolving financial services, a sharper focus on efficiency and timeliness in the industry, and the rapid increase in technology advances have also led the Federal Reserve to explore the potential benefits and risks of a central bank digital currency (CBDC).', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Another area of intense interest is the expansion of financial activities beyond the traditional chartered banking institution construct.', theme='other')]

title: Opening Remarks
speaker: Chair Jerome H. Powell
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph='The pace of technological change and innovation over the last decade has led some to argue that we are on the brink of a fourth industrial revolution—a digital revolution. Certainly, rapid innovation, including through the application of advanced digital technologies, machine learning, artificial intelligence, and big data, is revolutionizing the financial sector.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Furthering the efforts around the Federal Reserve System to harness the power of innovation, I am delighted to welcome the opening of the New York Innovation Center. Located at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, in the heart of the most important financial center in the world, this Innovation Center will draw on the expertise at the bank, in the Federal Reserve System, and from the broader financial community, as well as experts around the world to analyze and bring technology to bear on improving the global financial system.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Increasing the synergies of the New York Innovation Center will be its strategic partnership with the BIS Innovation Hub, recently established to foster dialogue, collaboration and knowledge-sharing among central banks and other authorities and institutions. In particular, the partnership will support our analysis of digital currencies—including central bank digital currencies; help to improve our current payment system—with a particular focus on making cross-border payments faster and less expensive; and it will provide new tools to aid our supervision of the financial system.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Linking up with the BIS in this way will enhance our ability to collaborate with central banks around the world and will ensure that the best and most up-to-date information, research, and practices are flowing freely. Since its inception in January 2020, I have served as head of the BIS Innovation Hub Advisory Committee and am very pleased that the Federal Reserve will be able to partner with the Hub in this important way.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='So I want to extend my thanks to President Williams, Agustin Carstens, and all those that worked on the establishment of this center. And I look forward to the advances of both these institutions in supporting innovation in service to the safety and soundness of the financial system.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The Federal Reserve has a mandate to understand and, in some cases, manage these changes, but it also has a responsibility to be at the forefront of change to deliver to the American people—and the international community—a reliable, efficient, and inclusive monetary and financial system.', theme='other')]

title: Opening Remarks
speaker: Chair Jerome H. Powell
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph="To kick off today's discussions, I would like to touch briefly on these subjects from two distinct perspectives. First, I will discuss some of the ways we at the Federal Reserve approach issues of persistent economic inequities. Then I will review some of how we as central banks are addressing the issues around diversity and inclusion in economics as institutions and employers.", theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Policymaking Taking the first of these topics, we know, of course, that an economy is healthier and stronger when as many people as possible are able to work. If entrenched inequities prevent some Americans from participating fully in our labor markets, not only will they be held back from opportunities, but our economy overall will not realize its potential.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='In the later years of the long expansion that ended with the pandemic, the benefits of employment continued to spread more widely and to reach those at the margins of the economy. Prior to the pandemic, unemployment was at 50‑year lows. Wages had been moving up, and meaningfully so, especially on the lower ends of the pay scale.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Most entrenched inequities are beyond the power of monetary policy to address. The specific goals given to us by Congress, however, to foster achievement of our dual mandate of maximum employment and price stability, form the foundation of a strong and stable economy.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="It was with this in mind that my colleagues and I on the Federal Open Market Committee, as part of last year's update to the Fed's monetary policy framework, defined maximum employment as a broad and inclusive goal. This innovation recognizes that a strong labor market delivers broad-reaching benefits and extends those benefits in particular to low- and moderate-income communities.", theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='While monetary policy does not target any particular group of people, when we assess whether we are at maximum employment, we purposely look at a wide range of indicators, and we are attentive to disparities in the labor market, rather than just the headline numbers.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Diversity in Economics Next, I would like to turn to an issue facing many of us at this conference—namely, how central banks as institutions and employers grapple with and confront diversity and inclusion within economics. Collectively, we are among the largest employers in the field of economics, which both affects our own workplaces and affords us an opportunity to help influence and shape the evolution of the profession.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Throughout my career, in both the public and the private sectors, I have seen that the best and most successful organizations are often the ones that have a strong and persistent commitment to diversity and inclusion. These organizations consistently attract the best talent, by investing in and retaining a world-class workforce.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='I know that the central banks represented here today are indeed working diligently to do just that. At the Fed, we are hosting events like this one, where high-quality economic research is brought to bear. We are working to foster an inclusive workplace environment where staff can feel comfortable at work and to promote a similarly inclusive culture within the profession.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='We are working to broaden our reach by recruiting at historically black colleges and universities and Hispanic-serving institutions, as well as by hosting events to promote career opportunities at the Fed.', theme='employment')]

title: Opening Remarks
speaker: Chair Jerome H. Powell
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph="Good morning. I am pleased to welcome everyone to today's conference on gender and the economy. Thank you for being here, for participating, and for lending your expertise on this important topic.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='We have gathered an impressive lineup of speakers and panelists, who will address a range of timely and important issues.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="Research The speakers and panelists will be exploring a wide range of topics, from a historical review of gender issues and the economy to how someone's education options—and the financing of those choices—affect that person's early career and financial stability.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The Pandemic and Gender The pandemic widened deep-rooted inequities in our economy. Along racial, gender, and socioeconomic lines, those least able to bear it, unfortunately, were those who were most affected.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='In a reversal of previous recessions, women suffered more from job losses in the COVID-19 recession than men. In April 2020, the unemployment rate for women was 16.1 percent, compared with 13.6 percent for men.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph="Increased childcare responsibilities during the pandemic also affected many parents' working lives. These are vital issues not just to the economy, but to families across the country.', theme='other')]

title: Goodbye to All That: The End of LIBOR
speaker: Vice Chair for Supervision Randal K. Quarles
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph="What to read on a long plane flight is a prosaic but insistent problem that has reappeared: what to read on a long plane flight. Like most of you, I try to get some work done—but, also like most of you, out of an amalgam of security concerns and indolence, I often don't succeed.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Now that business travel has started to pick back up as we emerge from the COVID event, a prosaic but insistent problem has reappeared: what to read on a long plane flight.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="And given that introduction, I'm sure you have now guessed what I intend to talk to you about today: LIBOR, the benchmark formerly known as the London Interbank Offered Rate.", theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Earlier this year, however, things changed, and changed significantly. Two things happened which together make clear that LIBOR will no longer be available for any new contracts after the end of this year, just 86 days from now.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='So, now there was a definitive and immovable date fixed for the end of LIBOR. However, the second thing that happened made clear that long before that end date in 2023, LIBOR would not be available for any new contracts after the end of this year.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='If LIBOR will not be available for new contracts, what is the point of IBA continuing to provide USD LIBOR quotes until mid-2023?', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='What is LIBOR, and Why is it Going Away? title: Welcoming Remarks
speaker: Chair Jerome H. Powell
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph="It's a pleasure to be here, albeit in a very different format than we're used to. The downside is that we don't get to connect in quite the same way as we do in person. title: Outlooks, Outcomes, and Prospects for U.S. Monetary Policy
speaker: Vice Chair Richard H. Clarida
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph='The recovery to date has been surprising, and it is plausible—indeed, probable—that more surprises are in store.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='I expect the labor market by the end of 2022 will have reached my assessment of maximum employment if the unemployment rate has declined by then to the SEP median of modal projections of 3.8 percent.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph="Given this outlook and so long as inflation expectations remain well anchored at the 2 percent longer-run goal—which, based on the Fed staff's common inflation expectations (CIE) index, I judge at present to be the case and which I project will remain true over the forecast horizon—commencing policy normalization in 2023 would, under these conditions, be entirely consistent with our new flexible average inflation targeting framework.", theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The support to aggregate demand from fiscal policy—including the more than $2 trillion in accumulated excess savings accruing from (as yet) unspent transfer payments—in tandem with appropriate monetary policy, can fully offset the constraint that the ELB imposes on the ability of an inflation-targeting monetary policy, acting on its own and in the absence of sufficient fiscal support, to restore, following a recession, maximum employment and price stability while keeping inflation expectations well anchored at the 2 percent longer-run goal.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="In coming meetings, the Committee will again assess the economy's progress toward our goals. As we have said, we will provide advance notice before making any changes to our purchases.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The recovery to date has been surprising, and it is plausible—indeed, probable—that more surprises are in store.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="Given this outlook and so long as inflation expectations remain well anchored at the 2 percent longer-run goal—which, based on the Fed staff's common inflation expectations (CIE) index, I judge at present to be the case and which I project will remain true over the forecast horizon—commencing policy normalization in 2023 would, under these conditions, be entirely consistent with our new flexible average inflation targeting framework.", theme='inflation')]

title: Welcoming Remarks
speaker: Governor Michelle W. Bowman
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph="Welcome, and thank you for joining us to discuss a number of topics important to the nation's economy.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='This focus of this series on an inclusive recovery holds special importance as we think about the uneven economic effects from the pandemic.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Yet while the spread of the virus universally upended our personal lives, our employment situations frequently dictated our ease of adaption.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="In November of last year, for instance, almost half of workers with a college degree or more said that they worked entirely from home, according to the Board's Survey of Household Economics and Decisionmaking (SHED).", theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Public policy actions, including those taken by the Congress and the Federal Reserve, aimed to provide support to households and employers in the wake of these unprecedented disruptions.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='As we continue on the path to recovery, it is time to consider what the labor market may look like post–COVID-19.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The record number of job openings in May is a very promising sign that opportunities are increasing, and I think that development bodes well for both households and the country.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='I believe that data, evidence, and research can help policymakers and practitioners think more clearly about the implications for improving economic outcomes for everyone.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="To help think about some of these questions, today's discussion should be particularly informative, and I hope that the research presented is useful to you in your work.", theme='other')]

title: Disclosures and Data: Building Strong Foundations for Addressing Climate-Related Financial Risks
speaker: Vice Chair for Supervision Randal K. Quarles
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph='', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The FSB published last Wednesday a Climate Roadmap that presents a comprehensive and coordinated plan to address climate-related financial risks.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Given the global nature of climate change, this demands a coordinated international effort.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="The FSB's roadmap dovetails with the ongoing work of the G20 Sustainable Finance Working Group (SFWG) to develop a broader sustainable finance roadmap.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Today, in my role as Chair of the FSB, I would like to focus on the two foundational components of the FSB roadmap: disclosures and data.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The FSB was an early leader in bringing attention to the importance of reliable, entity-level disclosures to assess and manage climate-related financial risks and opportunities.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Now it is time to build on that work. It will be useful to establish a globally consistent baseline standard for climate-related disclosures.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The G20 Presidency, in developing its 2021 work program, asked the FSB to encourage more consistency in disclosure practices.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The International Financial Reporting Standards Foundation (IFRS), in consultation with other international organizations, will develop a set of standards, starting initially with climate and building upon these TCFD recommendations.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph="The initial focus of the IFRS will be on climate standards, while allowing for interoperability with individual jurisdictions' frameworks, that may go beyond climate-related impacts.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Consistency in one-way disclosures would provide a needed avenue for accurate and appropriate risk assessment and comparability to assess investment decisions.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph="The need for high quality, reliable data doesn't stop at firms' disclosures, however.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="Our data needs include data on the underlying drivers of physical and transition risk and financial institutions' exposures.", theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='This is not an easy task. The current lack of usable data is a reflection of difficulties in transforming existing information on the drivers of climate risk into reliable metrics that quantify financial risks.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The FSB is working with international bodies, such as the International Monetary Fund, and other international groupings, such as the Network for Greening the Financial System (NGFS), to assess climate data gaps and to identify steps to address them.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The FSB, as laid out in its roadmap, has taken on a critical role in coordinating and carrying forward work that will make the global financial system more resilient to the threats posed by climate change.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph="Our Climate Roadmap leverages the FSB's strength as a coordinating body, provides some structure to the vast amount of work on climate-related financial risks currently going on internationally, and clarifies interdependencies between workstreams and between issues.", theme='other')]

title: Building Economic Resilience in Communities

title: Jet Flight, Mail Bags, and Banking Regulation

tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph='This is a long and detailed speech by an official from the Federal Reserve, likely Chair Powell or another high-ranking official, discussing the state of the US banking system in response to the COVID-19 pandemic.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='1. **Efficiency improvements**: The speaker highlights that the regulatory framework for banks has been improved over the last four years, with a focus on safety and soundness.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="2. **COVID-19 test**: The pandemic provided a significant test of the banking system's resilience. Despite unprecedented economic shocks, banks maintained their capital levels, strengthened their liquidity positions, and served as a source of strength to the economy.", theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='3. **Capital and liquidity**: Banks built capital during the COVID event, with aggregate common equity tier 1 capital ratios exceeding pre-COVID levels. Liquidity positions were also strengthened through an influx of deposits and reserves.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='4. **Stress tests**: The speaker notes that stress tests conducted in June 2020 indicated that banks would have been able to withstand even more severe economic scenarios without the substantial fiscal assistance provided to the rest of the economy.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='5. **Volcker Rule changes**: The speaker highlights changes made to the implementation of the Volcker rule, which have allowed banks to invest in communities and support innovative growth while still adhering to the intent of the rule.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Some additional observations:', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="1. **Comparison to airlines**: The speaker draws a comparison between the banking system's resilience during the COVID-19 pandemic and the airline industry's performance after implementing efficiency improvements.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='2. **Systemic vulnerabilities**: The speech acknowledges that not all parts of the financial system performed well, with notable concerns raised about non-bank entities such as prime money funds and commercial paper markets.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='3. **Lessons learned**: The speaker highlights lessons learned from the COVID-19 pandemic experience, including the effectiveness of the stress capital buffer framework in ensuring bank resilience.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Overall, this speech suggests that the US banking system has demonstrated a high degree of resilience during an unprecedented global shock, with significant improvements to its regulatory framework contributing to this outcome.', theme='other')]
