March and April.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='This recession was by far the deepest one in postwar history, but it also may go into the record books as the briefest recession in U.S. history.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The flow of macrodata received since May has been surprisingly strong, and GDP growth in the third quarter is estimated by many forecasters to have rebounded at perhaps a 25 to 30 percent annual rate.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='This development is especially noteworthy when set in relief against the surge in new COVID-19 cases that were reported this summer in a number of U.S. states and the coincident flatlining in a number of high-frequency activity indicators that we follow to track the effect of the virus on economic activity.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Although spending on many services continues to lag, the rebound in the GDP data has been broad based across indicators of goods consumption, housing, and investment.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='These components of aggregate demand have benefited from robust fiscal support—including the Paycheck Protection Program and expanded unemployment benefits—as well as low interest rates and efforts by the Federal Reserve to sustain the flow of credit to households and firms.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='In the labor market, about half of the 22 million jobs that were lost in the spring have been restored, and the unemployment rate has fallen since April by nearly 7 percentage points to 7.9 percent as of September.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='I remind you that in the spring, many voices questioned what good rate cuts, forward guidance, asset purchases, and lending programs could do in an economy in which people do not venture out to buy cars or build houses and in which companies do not invest to augment their capital stock.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Well, the data show us that with rates low, credit available, and incomes supported by fiscal transfers, the answer is—at least so far—that they do build houses, buy cars, and order equipment and software.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='That said, the COVID-19 recession threw the economy into a very deep hole, and it will take some time, perhaps another year, for the level of GDP to fully recover to its previous 2019 peak.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='It will likely take even longer than that for the unemployment rate to return to a level consistent with our maximum-employment mandate.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph="However, it is worth highlighting that the Committee's baseline projections summarized in the most recent Summary of Economic Projections foresee a relatively rapid return to mandate-consistent levels of employment and inflation as compared with the recovery from the Global Financial Crisis (GFC).", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='In particular, the median Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) participant projects that by the end of 2023—a little more than three years from now—the unemployment rate will have fallen to 4 percent, and PCE (personal consumption expenditures) inflation will have returned to 2 percent.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Following the GFC, it took more than eight years for employment and inflation to return to similar mandate-consistent levels.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='My baseline outlook is close to these projections, but I must also acknowledge that the economic outlook is unusually uncertain, and, moreover, that the ultimate course the economy follows will depend on the course of the virus, social-distancing norms, and mitigation efforts put in place to contain it.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='At our September FOMC meeting, the Committee made important changes to our policy statement that upgraded our forward guidance about the future path of the federal funds rate, and that also provided unprecedented information about our policy reaction function.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='We indicated that, with inflation running persistently below 2 percent, our policy will aim to achieve inflation outcomes that keep inflation expectations well anchored at our 2 percent longer-run goal.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph="We said that we expect to maintain an accommodative stance of monetary policy until these outcomes—as well as our maximum-employment mandate—are achieved, and also that we expect it will be appropriate to maintain the current 0 to 1/4 percent target range for the federal funds rate until labor market conditions have reached levels consistent with the Committee's assessments of maximum employment.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='We also stated that the Federal Reserve will, over coming months, continue to increase our holdings of Treasury securities and agency mortgage-backed securities at least at the current pace to sustain smooth market functioning and help foster accommodative financial conditions, thereby supporting the flow of credit to households and businesses.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The September FOMC meeting was the first since the Committee approved in August our new Statement on Longer-Run Goals and Monetary Policy Strategy and adopted a new policy framework.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="In our new framework, we acknowledge that policy decisions going forward will be based on the FOMC's estimates of 'shortfalls [emphasis added] of employment from its maximum level'—not 'deviations.'", theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='This language means that going forward, a low unemployment rate, in and of itself, will not be sufficient to trigger a tightening of monetary policy absent any evidence from other indicators that inflation is at risk of moving above mandate-consistent levels.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='With regard to our price-stability mandate, while the new statement maintains our definition that the longer-run goal for inflation is 2 percent, it elevates the importance—and the challenge—of keeping inflation expectations well anchored at 2 percent in a world in which an effective-lower-bound constraint is, in downturns, binding on the federal funds rate.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph="To this end, the new statement conveys the Committee's judgment that, in order to anchor expectations at the 2 percent level consistent with price stability, it 'seeks to achieve inflation that averages 2 percent over time,' and—in the same sentence—that therefore 'following periods when inflation has been running persistently below 2 percent, appropriate monetary policy will likely aim to achieve inflation moderately above 2 percent for some time.'", theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph="As Chair Powell indicated in his Jackson Hole remarks, we think of our new framework as an evolution from 'flexible inflation targeting' to 'flexible average inflation targeting.'", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='While this new framework represents a robust evolution in our monetary policy strategy, this strategy is in service to the dual-mandate goals of monetary policy assigned to the Federal Reserve by the Congress—maximum employment and price stability—which remain unchanged.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Concluding Remarks', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='While economic recovery since the spring collapse has been robust, let us not forget that full economic recovery from the COVID-19 recession has a long way to go.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph="However, it is worth highlighting that the Committee's baseline projections summarized in the most recent Summary of Economic Projections foresee a relatively rapid return to mandate-consistent levels of employment and inflation as compared with the recovery from the Global Financial Crisis (GFC).", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='In particular, the median Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) participant projects that by the end of 2023—a little more than three years from now—the unemployment rate will have fallen to 4 percent, and PCE (personal consumption expenditures) inflation will have returned to 2 percent.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Following the GFC, it took more than eight years for employment and inflation to return to similar mandate-consistent levels.', theme='other')]

title: Recent Economic Developments and the Challenges Ahead
speaker: Chair Jerome H. Powell
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph='The Pre-COVID Economy', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Most economic forecasters expected the expansion and its benefits to continue, and with good reason. There was no economy-threatening asset bubble to pop and no unsustainable boom to bust.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='It also seemed likely that the sectors most affected by the pandemic—those relying on extensive in-person contact—would face a long and difficult path to recovery.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The Recession and Nascent Recovery', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='What have these policies managed to accomplish so far?', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='First, the substantial fiscal aid has given vital support to households. The rise in transfers supported necessary spending and contributed to a sharp increase in household saving.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Second, aid to firms—in particular, the Paycheck Protection Program—and the general boost to aggregate demand have so far partly forestalled an expected wave of bankruptcies and lessened permanent layoffs.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Third, after briefly seizing up in March, financial markets have largely returned to normal functioning, albeit in the context of extensive ongoing policy support.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='While the combined effects of fiscal and monetary policy have aided the solid recovery of the labor market so far, there is still a long way to go.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The burdens of the downturn have not been evenly shared. The initial job losses fell most heavily on lower-wage workers in service industries facing the public—job categories in which minorities and women are overrepresented.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The Road Ahead', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The recovery has progressed more quickly than generally expected. The most recent projections by FOMC (Federal Open Market Committee) participants at our September meeting show the recovery continuing at a solid pace.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='We should continue do what we can to manage downside risks to the outlook.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='A second risk is that a prolonged slowing in the pace of improvement over time could trigger typical recessionary dynamics, as weakness feeds on weakness.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The expansion is still far from complete.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Given this audience, I would be remiss were I not to mention our review of our monetary policy strategy, tools, and communications, which concluded recently with our adoption of a flexible average inflation-targeting regime.', theme='other')]

title: Modernizing and Strengthening CRA Regulations: Hearing from Community Banks
speaker: Governor Lael Brainard
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph='We recognize that community banks play a vital role in the communities you serve. Your insights into local conditions and your long-standing customer relationships afford you a deep understanding of the needs and characteristics of the households and small businesses in your communities, and enable you to meet their credit needs effectively.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The value of these relationships has never been more evident than during this crisis—a fact that my colleague, Governor Michelle Bowman, highlighted yesterday when she said "it is no surprise that community banks are standing shoulder to shoulder with their customers, on the front lines." Governor Bowman referred to an Independent Community Bankers of America (ICBA) report that cites preliminary data on the Paycheck Protection Program that community banks have been the main source of lending for minority-owned small businesses during the pandemic and noted the same is true for veteran-owned businesses.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='As you know, last week, the Federal Reserve Board unanimously voted to approve an Advance Notice of Proposed Rulemaking (ANPR) on the Community Reinvestment Act (CRA).3 The ANPR is built on ideas advanced by stakeholders. Throughout this process, the ICBA has been an important source of information, which has provided the Federal Reserve valuable insights into the unique role and needs of community banks as you invest in your communities.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Throughout our outreach, we consistently heard from both bankers and community groups that they value the CRA and that they want to see it improved and updated. This was important feedback as we contemplated how to modernize the regulations, while still staying true to the core purpose of the statute to meet the broad range of banking needs in low- and moderate-income (LMI) communities and address inequities in credit access.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Our first major goal for the ANPR was to strengthen the regulations in alignment with the CRA statute. This means strengthening the regulations to ensure that a wide range of LMI banking needs are being met.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='It also entails promoting financial inclusion by, among other things, providing credit for activities in areas with unmet needs outside of assessment areas, such as Indian Country. Additionally, we aim to create incentives for investment in minority depository institutions and community development financial institutions, many of whom are ICBA members.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='We know that banking has evolved over the past 25 years, so we also sought to update standards in light of changes to banking over time, including mobile and internet banking.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Our second major goal for the ANPR was to provide greater certainty, tailor regulations, and minimize burden. The ANPR seeks feedback on several approaches designed to make the rules clearer, more transparent, and less subjective.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='For example, the proposed metrics for the retail test and the community development test would provide more clarity and transparency on how bank ratings are determined. In talking with community banks, Federal Reserve staff and I also heard about the need for clearer standards and greater limitations on the size of assessment areas—especially for small banks operating just in a portion of a large county or only making a few loans in a part of a county.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The ANPR offers ideas to provide greater clarity in response to these concerns.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Importantly, the ANPR proposes to tailor CRA to bank size and business model. In discussing CRA reform with bankers and community organizations, it has been clear that there is a need for a tailored approach for small banks and better outcomes for rural communities.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Small retail banks could continue to have their retail lending activities evaluated under the current framework, or they could elect to be evaluated under the proposed retail lending metric.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Additionally, the ANPR minimizes data collection and reporting burden by relying on existing data as much as possible, as well as exempting small banks from deposit and certain other data collection requirements.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='We also heard from stakeholders like ICBA that rural areas, and banks in rural areas, have particular needs. Therefore, the ANPR proposes providing incentives for banks in rural areas to participate in beneficial civic and other nonprofit activities (e.g., serving on a board of a civic institution) that may not have a primary purpose of community development.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='In closing, we look forward to modernizing the CRA in a way that strengthens the regulations to advance the core purposes of the statute, while providing greater certainty, tailoring regulations, and minimizing burden.', theme='inflation')]

title: Mortgage Market Regulation and Access to Mortgage Credit
speaker: Governor Michelle W. Bowman
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph='', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The COVID-19 Pandemic and Homeownership in the U.S.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Fortunately, work is under way to relieve that burden, and I will highlight one effort in particular. But before I do, let me provide some context by reviewing the current state of the economy and its effect on homeowners and would-be homeowners.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The COVID-19 pandemic is having a profound effect on individuals and families across the U.S. and throughout the world.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Fortunately, the housing market as a whole is a bright spot for the economy.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Mortgage Regulations and Access to Mortgage Credit', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='However, even during this period of strong performance in the housing market, access to affordable mortgage credit remains a barrier to homeownership for some borrowers, due in part to regulatory burden.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Homeownership is as important to communities as it is to individuals, and access to credit for rural and low-to-moderate income communities often depends on community banks.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Many leaders of small community banks have told me that the compliance costs for originating smaller mortgages are prohibitive, and that the staffing and training required to meet the strict requirements are extraordinary in relation to the limited number of mortgages they originate.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Reducing mortgage compliance burden would allow community banks to better meet the critical need for home lending in their communities.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='One Area to Consider in Easing Burden', theme='other')]

title: Community Banks Rise to the Challenge
speaker: Governor Michelle W. Bowman
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph='The origination fees and interest income from PPP (Paycheck Protection Program) lending have fueled some of this improvement, with many community banks reporting substantial loan growth as a result of the program.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph="Regulatory burden is considered one of the most significant threats to community banks' existence.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The nation has suffered its sharpest drop in economic activity in history, but recent data suggest a rapid recovery.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Asset prices remain vulnerable to significant price declines if the pandemic worsens.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Continued monetary and targeted fiscal policy support will likely be needed to ensure a smooth recovery.', theme='other')]

title: Strengthening the CRA to Meet the Challenges of Our Time
speaker: Governor Lael Brainard
tags:
[ThemeTag(paragraph="The Advance Notice of Proposed Rulemaking (ANPR) on the Community Reinvestment Act (CRA) is a proposal by the Federal Reserve and other banking regulators to modernize the CRA regulations. The goal is to strengthen the law's ability to promote community development and increase access to credit for low- and moderate-income individuals.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='1. **Update Eligible CRA Activities:** Propose updating and clarifying which community development activities qualify under the CRA.
2. **Streamline Reporting Requirements:** Exempt small banks from deposit and certain other data collection requirements.
3. **Tailor Assessment Areas:** Provide small banks in rural areas with greater clarity and flexibility when defining facility-based assessment areas.
4. **Focus on Communities:** Emphasize the importance of community development activities that benefit low- and moderate-income (LMI) communities.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="1. **25 years since last revision**: The CRA has not been updated in 25 years, so it's essential to get reform right.
2. **Strong stakeholder support**: Stakeholders have expressed strong support for the agencies to work together to modernize the CRA.
3. **Community development and access to credit**: Strengthening the CRA will promote community development and increase access to credit for LMI individuals.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='1. **Comment period:** The extended 120-day comment period allows time for thoughtful feedback from a broad set of stakeholders.
2. **Feedback on proposals:** Provide input on the proposed updates, streamlining reporting requirements, and tailoring assessment areas.
3. **Stakeholder engagement:** Continue to engage with the Federal Reserve and other banking regulators through various channels.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='1. **Review comments**: The Federal Reserve will review comments from stakeholders and analyze options for greater impact.
2. **Convergence on a consistent approach**: The agencies aim to converge on a stronger, transparent, and tailored approach to the CRA that has broad support among stakeholders.', theme='other')]

title: The Federal Reserve’s New Monetary Policy Framework: A Robust Evolution
speaker: Vice Chair Richard H. Clarida
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph='The Statement on Longer-Run Goals and Monetary Policy Strategy was revised in 2020, with several key changes.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='**Inflation Targeting**: The statement now explicitly mentions inflation targeting, which involves setting a specific inflation target (2% in this case) to guide monetary policy decisions.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='**Symmetry**: The statement reaffirms the importance of symmetry in monetary policy decisions, ensuring that policies are applied equally to periods of above-target and below-target inflation.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='**Operational Inflation Range**: The FOMC will aim for inflation outcomes moderately above 2% when inflation has been running persistently too low, solidifying longer-run inflation expectations at 2%.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph="**Commitment to Goals**: The revised statement emphasizes the Federal Reserve's commitment to achieving its dual mandate goals (maximum employment and price stability) in a more explicit manner.", theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='**Use of Full Range of Tools**: The FOMC will use its full range of tools to achieve its goals, including setting interest rates, buying or selling securities, and other mechanisms as needed.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='**Enhanced Transparency**: The statement highlights the importance of clear Federal Reserve communications in an uncertain economic environment, aiming to provide greater clarity and transparency about monetary policy decisions.', theme='other')]

title: New Economic Challenges and the Fed's Monetary Policy Review
speaker: Chair Jerome H. Powell
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph='The Federal Reserve System has updated its Statement on Longer-Run Goals and Monetary Policy Strategy.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='* Key Changes:', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='** Employment Goal:** The Committee will seek to promote maximum employment, recognizing that estimates of this level are highly uncertain and may be influenced by various factors, including changes in population demographics.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='** Monetary Policy Strategy:** The Committee will use its monetary policy tools to achieve the inflation and employment goals, with a focus on using interest rates at the effective lower bound to support the economy during periods of low inflation or recession.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='* Rationale:', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='**Lessons from History:** The Committee notes that in the past, high and variable inflation has been a significant challenge for monetary policy.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph="**Productivity Growth:** The Committee acknowledges that productivity growth has slowed since the early 2000s, which may affect the economy's ability to generate jobs.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='**Demographic Changes:** The Committee recognizes that changes in population demographics can impact labor force participation and employment.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='* Community Engagement:', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='**Fed Listens Events:** The Federal Reserve System hosted a series of Fed Listens events in 2019 to engage with communities and gather feedback on the proposed updates to the Statement.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='**Public Input:** The Committee received input from various stakeholders, including academics, policymakers, and community leaders.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='* Theoretical Framework:', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="**Inflation Targeting:** The Committee's approach is based on inflation targeting principles, which involve setting an explicit inflation target and using monetary policy tools to achieve it.", theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph="**Flexible Inflation Targeting:** The Committee's strategy incorporates elements of flexible inflation targeting, which allows for some flexibility in achieving the inflation target during times of economic stress.", theme='other')]

title: The Pandemic’s Effect on the Economy and Banking
speaker: Governor Michelle W. Bowman
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph="The Pandemic's Effects on the Economy and Banking", theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph="Among Kansas's major industries, oil and gas production and equipment manufacturing have been hurt by the worldwide slump in energy demand. Aviation manufacturing has been hit hard by the downturn and by the uncertainty over the recovery in air travel.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Turning to employment, nationwide, we know that the initial job losses were heavily concentrated among the most financially vulnerable, including lower-wage workers, young people, women, and minority groups.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Households were in a generally strong financial position at the beginning of this year, but the restrictions implemented to fight COVID-19 resulted in an unprecedented spike in unemployment, which likely led to a number of families finding it difficult to keep up with their payment obligations.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Understanding the financial stress this could place on many borrowers, the Fed and other federal regulators implemented guidance to encourage banks to work with their borrowers.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="It is encouraging to see that even those sectors most heavily affected by the crisis are finding ways to innovate. Stores are adjusting hours and ramping up delivery, restaurants are changing menus and creating outdoor space, distilleries shifted from making bourbon to hand sanitizers, and independent businesses that hadn't previously relied heavily on technology are now using it to stay connected to customers and regulate workflow.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Looking ahead, the economic outlook will continue to evolve quickly. We experienced a pronounced and very welcome bounceback in national retail spending and housing activity over the early summer months.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="The Fed's Response to the Pandemic", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="Now let me turn to the Federal Reserve's role in the government's response to the pandemic. During the initial phase of the crisis, we took a number of actions to stabilize financial markets that came under intense stress.", theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='One federal stimulus program that relied heavily on the participation and expertise of community bankers is the Paycheck Protection Program (PPP). Working through banks, the PPP program has delivered more than $500 billion to small businesses to help them weather the storm.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The PPP was created to help small businesses keep their employees on staff, and the Main Street Lending program is designed to support lending to mid-sized businesses through the recovery.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Together, these policy actions have helped stabilize financial markets, boost consumer and business sentiment, and assist millions of households and thousands of businesses harmed by the response to the pandemic. Credit markets, which had seized up earlier this year, have resumed functioning.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='In our other role as a prudential regulator and bank supervisor, the Federal Reserve took several steps intended to reduce burden on banks and help them focus on the needs of their customers and communities.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="As we continue to support the recovery and work to ensure that supervision and examination is as effective and efficient as possible, I think it's important to hear directly from you, who are actually working in the economy, about the conditions facing your communities and any challenges impeding your ability to meet the needs of your customers.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Conditions for Smaller Banks', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='This audience knows better than most that smaller banks entered the pandemic in strong condition. At the end of 2019, over 95 percent of community and regional banks supervised by the Fed were rated a 1 or 2 under the CAMELS rating system.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph="Overall, community and regional banks remain well positioned to continue to extend credit and play an essential role in supporting our nation's recovery from the effects of COVID-19.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The Road Ahead', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="Like many native Kansans, I am an eternal optimist, so let me end my formal remarks on a hopeful note. While the road ahead is highly uncertain, and we don't yet know when the economy will return to its previous strength.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='We will closely watch economic and financial conditions, and we will use our monetary policy tools to respond as appropriate to pursue our dual mandate of maximum employment and price stability.', theme='employment')]

title: Brief Remarks
speaker: Governor Michelle W. Bowman
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph="The suffragettes didn't only achieve something for women. Through their efforts, our country became a stronger democracy by extending the full opportunity for women to be counted and to take part in the political process.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="The passage of the 19th Amendment in 1920 enabled women to directly participate in selecting our country's leaders.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="None of us singled out today would be here without the extraordinary efforts of those who secured the vote for women. In my case, it was serving as Kansas's first female State Bank Commissioner, and the first person to serve on the Federal Reserve Board in the role designated by Congress for someone with community banking experience.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="In 1861, Kansas granted women a limited right to vote in school district elections; and, by 1867, Kansas became the first U.S. state to hold a statewide referendum on women's suffrage.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The participation of women in the political and policymaking process brings a broader perspective.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='I approach our monetary policy deliberations in a similar way. Our actions in response to the recent pandemic have clearly benefited from this perspective, as we understand how the varying state and local approaches have affected economic conditions across the nation.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='In closing, it is appropriate that during this election season we honor the women who secured that right, first in Kansas, and then through their campaign to ratify the 19th amendment. The greatest tribute to those women, and the best way to honor their legacy, is to vote.', theme='other')]

title: An Update on Digital Currencies
speaker: Governor Lael Brainard
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph="It is a pleasure to participate in San Francisco's Innovation Office Hours. The Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco is a leader of our engagement with the tech community. And the Federal Reserve's Innovation Office Hours serve as an important forum to engage on innovation in the financial system with financial institutions, fintechs, technology companies, nonprofits, and other stakeholders.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The COVID-19 pandemic is taking a tremendous toll on communities across America, especially households and small businesses with the least resources to weather the storm.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='More broadly, banks, fintech companies, and technology firms are all exploring the use of innovative technologies to enhance payments efficiency, expand financial inclusion, speed up settlement flows, and reduce end-user costs.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='With these important issues in mind, the Federal Reserve is active in conducting research and experimentation related to distributed ledger technologies and the potential use cases for digital currencies.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph="We have been conducting in-house experiments for the last few years, through means that include the Board's Technology Lab, which has been building and testing a range of distributed ledger platforms to understand their potential opportunity and risk.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The objectives of our research and experimentation across the Federal Reserve System are to assess the safety and efficiency of digital currency systems, to inform our understanding of private-sector arrangements, and to give us hands-on experience to understand the opportunities and limitations of possible technologies for digital forms of central bank money.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Separately, a significant policy process would be required to consider the issuance of a CBDC, along with extensive deliberations and engagement with other parts of the federal government and a broad set of other stakeholders.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='In addition to these experiments, the Federal Reserve continues to collaborate with and learn from other central banks. We are participating in the CBDC coalition of central banks.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='More broadly, the Federal Reserve looks forward to increased international engagement on matters related to innovation and technological change that impact central banks and those we serve.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Let me conclude by noting that innovation is central to our work. We remain committed to understanding how technological advances can help the Federal Reserve carry out our core missions, as well as how they are changing the ways that banks, payments, and financial markets operate.', theme='other')]

title: The Future of Retail Payments in the United States
speaker: Governor Lael Brainard
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph='The COVID-19 pandemic has heightened the urgency and importance of delivering a resilient instant payment system that is accessible to all Americans.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The rapid expenditure of the COVID emergency relief payments highlights the critical urgency of immediate access to funds for the many households and businesses managing cash-flow constraints.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='An instant payment infrastructure ensures the funds are available immediately, which could be especially important for households on fixed incomes or living paycheck to paycheck...', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Consumers and businesses across the country want and expect instant payments, and the banks they trust should be able to provide this service securely.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='In order to minimize time to market, additional features of the FedNow Service would be introduced in phases after launch.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Some newer payment services, while providing what has the look and feel of an instant payment experience for consumers, in fact rely on legacy infrastructure that actually settles transactions on a deferred basis...', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Ultimately, the FedNow Service can be a catalyst for innovation in the market by providing a neutral platform on which the private sector can build to offer safe, efficient instant payment services to users across the country.', theme='other')]

title: Navigating Monetary Policy through the Fog of COVID
speaker: Governor Lael Brainard
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph='The Fed aims to pivot from providing stabilization to supporting a full recovery in employment and returning inflation to its 2% objective on a sustained basis.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Brainard acknowledges that the recovery will face headwinds for some time, making it essential to maintain a sustained commitment to accommodation and additional fiscal support.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The Fed will use forward guidance, asset purchases, and other tools to provide necessary accommodation, particularly given the effective lower bound on interest rates.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Brainard emphasizes that monetary policy should aim to support inflation expectations consistent with inflation centered on 2% over time, rather than preemptively withdrawing support based on a historically steeper Phillips curve.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The Fed acknowledges that additional fiscal support will be necessary to support the recovery.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The dense fog of COVID-related uncertainty shrouding the outlook means that the recovery likely will face headwinds for some time, calling for a sustained commitment to accommodation.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Monetary policy should seek to achieve employment outcomes with the kind of breadth and depth that were only achieved late in the previous recovery.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph="Overall, these remarks highlight the Fed's commitment to supporting the economy during this challenging period and its willingness to adapt its monetary policy approach to address emerging risks.", theme='other')]

title: Global in Life and Orderly in Death: Post-Crisis Reforms and the Too-Big-to-Fail Question
speaker: Vice Chair for Supervision and Chair of the Financial Stability Board Randal K. Quarles
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph="Good afternoon ladies and gentlemen. I would like to thank the Exchequer Club for hosting this event, and I look forward to future events taking us back to the luncheon discussions at the Mayflower Hotel, as has been the club's tradition now for over half a century.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The containment measures of the COVID event represent the biggest test that the financial system has faced since the global financial crisis of 2007-08. After years of reforms, we now face a real life stress test even more severe than those previously hypothesized.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph="We saw many examples of a 'dash for cash,' with firms drawing down their lines of credit with banks, and the indiscriminate sale of assets by investors in order to obtain liquidity.", theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Credit spreads have narrowed for both investment-grade and high-yield bonds, markets are functioning in an orderly manner, and credit provision to the economy has held up.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='However, the COVID event is not behind us yet. Many households and businesses remain under pressure.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Banks entered the current crisis in a much stronger position than they did the global financial crisis. They are much better capitalized and more liquid than back in 2008.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='It has also enabled banks to play a central role in measures to support the flow of credit to the economy.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='We know that the financial system will face more challenges. The corporate sector entered the crisis with high levels of debt and has necessarily borrowed more during the event.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='And many households are facing bleak employment prospects.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The next phase will inevitably involve an increase in non-performing loans and provisions as demand falls and some borrowers fail.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Too-Big-to-Fail Reforms Have Made Banks More Resilient and Able to Support the Economy', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The G20 Leaders endorsed a package of reforms to tackle these two problems for systemically important banks.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="This brings us to the FSB's evaluation of too-big-to fail reforms. I should note at the outset that the analysis was conducted before the onset of the COVID event.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Significant Progress in Making Banks Resolvable', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Before the global financial crisis, the resolution of failing banks was a niche subject. In hindsight, most authorities around the world had given it far too little attention.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The official sector is providing a rapid and coordinated response to support the real economy, maintain financial stability, and minimize the risk of market fragmentation.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Too-Big-to-Fail Reforms Have Made Banks More Resilient and Able to Support the Economy', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Reforms Are Achieving Their Policy Objectives But More Work Is Needed', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The FSB evaluation provides evidence that the reforms are indeed achieving their objectives.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='There is, of course, more to do. The benefits of reforms cannot be realized unless they are operationalized.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The financial landscape is also changing, and the FSB needs to be responsive.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='There may be lessons for us to learn about the framework that we need to apply to this sector, which is different from—and less developed than—the one used for banks.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Finally, we want to hear from you. Our consultation closes on 30 September.', theme='other')]

title: The Adaptability of Stress Testing
speaker: Vice Chair for Supervision Randal K. Quarles
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph='Today, I\'d like to talk to you about how banking regulation and supervision is adjusting to the unprecedented economic challenges posed by the coronavirus outbreak and especially the containment measures taken in response, which together we call the "COVID event."', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Our requirements include capital buffers that are designed to be drawn down in periods of stress, in addition to minimum capital requirements.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph="We didn't have the time or the comprehensive data to run a complete and updated COVID event stress test.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="Given the changing economic circumstances and the need to act quickly, we didn't publish these three economic paths in advance and ask banks to model their exposures to them.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='We think it makes the most sense to share with the public some of what we have learned when we publish the results of our stress testing process on Thursday of next week.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="To be more precise, this portion of our disclosure, based on the results of the February 2020 scenario, will be identical in all material ways to last year's stress test disclosure.", theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Because of the limitations I described in examining the three downside risk paths for the economy, our disclosure of the sensitivity analysis will not provide firm-specific results.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Our largest banks entered the COVID event in a position of strength, with high levels of capital and liquidity, and they have demonstrated that strength in the support they have provided to the economy during a crisis.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Before the COVID event over 70 percent of the capital distributions of global systemically important banks, for example, came in form of share repurchases, which ceased in March.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Let me conclude by reiterating that stress tests remain a valuable tool, even in this time of extreme uncertainty.', theme='other')]

title: Introductory Comments
speaker: Chair Jerome H. Powell
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph='It is not lost on me that we are meeting on Juneteenth amid a renewed reckoning of racial injustice. The pandemic has again exposed a range of troubling inequalities, most of them of long standing. As the national discussion continues, it is critical to remember that equity includes access to education, work, and economic opportunity. I am reminded that Dr. King delivered his "I Have a Dream" speech, just a few short blocks from the Federal Reserve, at a rally whose full title was the March on Washington for Jobs and Freedom.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="We meet today amid the immense hardship and suffering the coronavirus has caused. Lives and livelihoods have been lost, and uncertainty looms large. We are all grateful to our frontline health-care workers who put themselves in harm's way every day and to the essential workers helping us meet our needs. While we are all affected, the burden has fallen disproportionately on those least able to bear it.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Before the virus swept across the globe, the American economy was in a good place. We were experiencing the longest expansion on record, and unemployment had reached historic lows. However, that is a national average that can gloss over stark realities. That economic good fortune had eluded pockets across the country, including Youngstown. A particular cruelty of the pandemic has been its disproportionate effects on many areas that were already suffering.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='We will make our way back from this, but it will take time and work. Some of the most valuable information we get from these discussions is how people are working to create growth. Your feedback can be an invaluable example for other communities with similar challenges. The Lordstown closure served as a reminder of how interconnected local economies can be, and other areas have experienced similar losses. Your work on diversifying the economy, on skills development, on small business support programs, and in so many other areas can all serve as models for others to replicate.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph="The path ahead is likely to be challenging. But given the opportunity, I'll always bet on the American people and on the kind of community resolve and dedication we're hearing about today. I'm looking forward to your insight and to hearing more about how you've been working to revitalize Youngstown's economy.", theme='other')]

title: U.S. Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy (via prerecorded video)
speaker: Vice Chair Richard H. Clarida
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph='It is my pleasure to meet virtually this evening with the members and invited guests of the Foreign Policy Association (FPA).1 I am truly honored to receive the Foreign Policy Association Medal.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='While the coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic has taken a tragic human toll measured in terms of lives lost and suffering inflicted, the pandemic has also inflicted a heavy toll on the levels of activity and employment in the U.S. economy, as a direct result of the necessary public health policies put in place to mitigate and control the spread of the virus.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='In my baseline view, while I do believe it will likely take some time for economic activity and the labor market to fully recover from the pandemic shock, I do project right now that the economy will resume growth starting in the third quarter. In terms of inflation, my projection is for the COVID-19 contagion shock to be disinflationary, not inflationary...', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='At the Federal Reserve, we take our dual-mandate obligations of maximum employment and price stability very seriously, and, since March 3, we have deployed our entire toolkit to provide critical support to the economy during this challenging time.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='These programs are designed to offer backstop sources of funding to the private sector, and just the announcement that these backstop facilities would soon be launched appears to have bolstered confidence in capital markets...', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="The Fed's statutory authority grants us lending powers, not spending powers. The Fed is not authorized to grant money to particular beneficiaries, to meet the payroll expenses of small businesses, or to underwrite the unemployment benefits of displaced workers.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Fortunately, the fiscal policy response in the United States to the coronavirus shock has been both robust and timely. In four pieces of legislation passed in just over two months, the Congress voted $2.9 trillion in coronavirus relief, about 14 percent of GDP.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The coronavirus pandemic poses the most serious threat to maximum employment and, potentially, to price stability that the United States has faced in our lifetimes...', theme='employment')]

title: Opening Remarks
speaker: Chair Jerome H. Powell
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph="We've held many Fed Listens events over the past 16 months, and it's important to note that these conversations aren't just a nice way to talk to people from around the country, although they are that.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="You give us perspective on the economic realities that don't show up on a spreadsheet. You help us see those complex sets of data that analyze the American economy through the eyes of the people, businesses, and communities that make up the American economy.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='So this is a valuable exercise for us. And an enjoyable one as well, so we truly do appreciate it on a number of levels.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The Reserve Banks are also continuing to host conversations in communities across the country to help capture economic realities on the ground.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='We are in the midst of an economic downturn without modern precedent. It was sudden, and it is severe. It has already erased the job gains of the past decade and has inflicted acute pain across the country.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The pain of this downturn is compounded by the upending of normal life, along with great uncertainty about the future.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Policies that address the resumption of economic activity are the province of elected officials at all levels of government, in close consultation with public health and medical professionals.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The feedback we get from our community and business contacts has always been crucial in how we conduct monetary policy. In extraordinary times such as these, it takes on even greater importance.', theme='other')]

title: U.S. Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy
speaker: Vice Chair Richard H. Clarida

title: Introductory remarks for the Fed Listens panel on the COVID-19 pandemic
speaker: Governor Lael Brainard
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph='We have heard that maximum employment is not captured in a single national average, it brings vital benefits, and it takes a very long time to arrive in many neighborhoods.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='We have heard that inflation matters: Households at different life stages and in different places are balancing the cost of living against their earnings, while businesses are balancing wages and other costs against their pricing power.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='When we embarked on this listening journey, little did we know that our nation would experience the heartache and hardship associated with the COVID-19 pandemic—an emergency unprecedented in modern times.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Last year, we heard from small businesses that were expanding their workforces and investing in their communities. Today, many of those same businesses are running low on cash reserves and struggling to make rent and payroll—especially those in consumer services, such as restaurants and retail.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Last year, national unemployment had fallen to its lowest point in over five decades. Today, unemployment has surged to levels not seen since the Great Depression.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Last year, historically challenged groups were gaining a foothold in the workforce, and employers were investing in training and loosening job eligibility requirements. Today, the fallout from the COVID pandemic has cruelly hit groups with thinner financial cushions the hardest—workers in the lowest quarter of earnings, people of color, low and moderate income communities, and women disproportionately employed in services jobs.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph="As we think about how the Federal Reserve's tools and presence in communities around the country could best provide stability at this trying time and strong support for the recovery to come, we are turning again to many of the same voices we heard from earlier to learn how the COVID pandemic has affected your communities and what lies ahead.", theme='other')]

title: Current Economic Issues
speaker: Chair Jerome H. Powell
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph='The coronavirus has left a devastating human and economic toll in its wake as it has spread around the globe.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Some sectors of the economy have been effectively closed since mid-March. People have put their lives and livelihoods on hold, making enormous sacrifices to protect not just their own health and that of their loved ones, but also their neighbors and the broader community.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='We are seeing a severe decline in economic activity and in employment, and already the job gains of the past decade have been erased. Since the pandemic arrived in force just two months ago, more than 20 million people have lost their jobs.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Among people who were working in February, almost 40 percent of those in households making less than $40,000 a year had lost a job in March.1', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='This downturn is different from those that came before it. Earlier in the post–World War II period, recessions were sometimes linked to a cycle of high inflation followed by Fed tightening.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='There was no economy-threatening bubble to pop and no unsustainable boom to bust. The virus is the cause, not the usual suspects—something worth keeping in mind as we respond.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='To date, Congress has provided roughly $2.9 trillion in fiscal support for households, businesses, health-care providers, and state and local governments—about 14 percent of gross domestic product.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The Fed takes actions such as these only in extraordinary circumstances, like those we face today. For example, our authority to extend credit directly to private nonfinancial businesses and state and local governments exists only in "unusual and exigent circumstances" and with the consent of the Secretary of the Treasury.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The overall policy response to date has provided a measure of relief and stability, and will provide some support to the recovery when it comes. But the coronavirus crisis raises longer-term concerns as well.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='A prolonged recession and weak recovery could also discourage business investment and expansion, further limiting the resurgence of jobs as well as the growth of capital stock and the pace of technological advancement.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='We ought to do what we can to avoid these outcomes, and that may require additional policy measures. At the Fed, we will continue to use our tools to their fullest until the crisis has passed and the economic recovery is well under way.', theme='other')]

title: Welcoming Remarks for Investment Connection – Response to COVID-19: Colorado
speaker: Governor Lael Brainard
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph='The COVID-19 pandemic has created an economic and public health crisis, which has caused tremendous hardship, in particular for our most vulnerable communities.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='That is why I join you here today.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='I would like to thank you for your commitment to meeting the needs of low- and moderate-income communities, especially in these extraordinary times.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The Community Reinvestment Act (CRA) is a powerful tool to bring stakeholders together to find solutions that serve the needs of low- and moderate-income communities.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Investment Connection has attracted a wide range of proposals to meet community development needs, including asset building and financial education, community facilities, small business development/microlending, neighborhood stabilization/affordable housing, and workforce development.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Since its inception, seven additional Reserve Banks have held or plan to hold Investment Connection events in their respective districts.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='To better understand what is happening on the ground, and how the Federal Reserve can use its full range of tools to address this crisis, it is important to hear from direct service providers. That is why I join you here today.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='I am proud that the Federal Reserve has been supporting your work, and we are always open to hearing how we can continue to do so going forward.', theme='other')]

title: COVID-19 and the Economy
speaker: Chair Jerome H. Powell
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph='The coronavirus has spread quickly around the world, leaving a tragic and growing toll of illness and lost lives. This is first and foremost a public health crisis, and the most important response is coming from those on the front lines in hospitals, emergency services, and care facilities.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='We are moving with alarming speed from 50-year lows in unemployment to what will likely be very high, although temporary, levels.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='All of us are affected, but the burdens are falling most heavily on those least able to carry them. It is worth remembering that the measures we are taking to contain the virus represent an essential investment in our individual and collective health.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The recently passed Cares Act is an important step in honoring that commitment, providing $2.2 trillion in relief to those who have lost their jobs, to low- and middle-income households, to employers of all sizes, to hospitals and health-care providers, and to state and local governments.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The Fed can also contribute in important ways: by providing a measure of relief and stability during this period of constrained economic activity, and by using our tools to ensure that the eventual recovery is as vigorous as possible.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='To those ends, we have lowered interest rates to near zero in order to bring down borrowing costs. We have also committed to keeping rates at this low level until we are confident that the economy has weathered the storm and is on track to achieve our maximum-employment and price-stability goals.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Some essential financial markets had begun to sink into dysfunction, and many channels that households, businesses, and state and local governments rely on for credit had simply stopped working. We acted forcefully to get our markets working again, and, as a result, market conditions have generally improved.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Many of the programs we are undertaking to support the flow of credit rely on emergency lending powers that are available only in very unusual circumstances—such as those we find ourselves in today—and only with the consent of the Secretary of the Treasury.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='I would stress that these are lending powers, not spending powers. The Fed is not authorized to grant money to particular beneficiaries. The Fed can only make secured loans to solvent entities with the expectation that the loans will be fully repaid.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Our emergency measures are reserved for truly rare circumstances, such as those we face today. When the economy is well on its way back to recovery, and private markets and institutions are once again able to perform their vital functions of channeling credit and supporting economic growth, we will put these emergency tools away.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='None of us has the luxury of choosing our challenges; fate and history provide them for us. Our job is to meet the tests we are presented. At the Fed, we are doing all we can to help shepherd the economy through this difficult time.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='When the spread of the virus is under control, businesses will reopen, and people will come back to work. There is every reason to believe that the economic rebound, when it comes, can be robust.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='I want to close by thanking the millions on the front lines: those working in health care, sanitation, transportation, grocery stores, warehouses, deliveries, security—including our own team at the Federal Reserve—and countless others.', theme='other')]

title: U.S. Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy
speaker: Vice Chair Richard H. Clarida
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph="In its 11th year of a record expansion, the U.S. economy is in a good place. The labor market remains strong, economic activity is increasing at a moderate pace, and the Federal Open Market Committee's (FOMC) baseline outlook is for a continuation of this performance in 2020.", theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The disruption there could spill over to the rest of the global economy. But it is still too soon to even speculate about either the size or the persistence of these effects, or whether they will lead to a material change in the outlook.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='I believe this shift was well timed and has been providing support to the economy and helping to keep the U.S. outlook on track.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Monetary policy is in a good place and should continue to support sustained growth, a strong labor market, and inflation returning to our symmetric 2 percent objective.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='In January 2019, my FOMC colleagues and I affirmed that we aim to operate with an ample level of bank reserves in the U.S. financial system.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Let me emphasize that we stand ready to adjust the details of this program as appropriate and in line with our goal, which is to keep the federal funds rate in the target range desired by the FOMC, and that these operations are technical measures not intended to change the stance of monetary policy.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='We will continue reporting on our discussions in the minutes of FOMC meetings and will share our conclusions with the public when we complete the review later this year.', theme='other')]

title: Monetary Policy Strategies and Tools When Inflation and Interest Rates Are Low
speaker: Governor Lael Brainard
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph='The speech discusses the current state of monetary policy and the need for a new strategy in light of changing economic conditions.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='**Key points:**', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='1. **Effective Lower Bound (ELB) Challenge**: The speaker emphasizes that the ELB challenge is becoming increasingly relevant, as interest rates have approached or even fallen below zero.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='2. **Unconventional Monetary Policy**: The speech discusses the effectiveness and limitations of unconventional monetary policy tools, such as quantitative easing (QE), forward guidance, and yield curve control (YCC).', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='3. **New Tools**: The speaker highlights that a combination of asset purchases and forward guidance can add roughly 3 percentage points of policy space.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='4. **Average Inflation Targeting**: The speech touches on the idea of average inflation targeting as a potential tool to combat chronic low inflation, but notes its limitations.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='5. **Financial Stability**: The speaker emphasizes the importance of considering financial stability when implementing monetary policy, particularly in light of the ELB challenge.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='**Recommendations:**', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='1. **Proactive Use of Expanded Toolkit**: The speaker suggests that proactive use of an expanded toolkit needs to be coupled with a new strategy that achieves average inflation outcomes of 2% along with maximum employment over time.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='2. **Medium-Term Yield Curve Ceilings and Forward Guidance**: The speech proposes the use of medium-term yield curve ceilings, in combination with forward guidance on the policy rate, as a tool to provide additional accommodation at the medium end of the yield curve.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='**Conclusion:**', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The speech concludes that monetary policymakers must adapt their strategies to address the ELB challenge. The recommended approach involves proactive use of an expanded toolkit, including asset purchases and forward guidance, in conjunction with a new strategy that prioritizes achieving average inflation outcomes of 2% along with maximum employment over time.', theme='inflation')]

title: Financial Markets and Monetary Policy: Is There a Hall of Mirrors Problem?
speaker: Vice Chair Richard H. Clarida
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph='Thank you to the conference organizers for inviting me here to discuss what former Chair Bernanke has famously referred to as a "hall of mirrors" problem: a situation in which a central bank\'s reaction function and financial market prices interact in economically suboptimal and potentially destabilizing ways.1 In my remarks today, I will lay out the way I think about the interplay between financial markets and monetary policy, with a focus on how I myself seek to integrate noisy but often correlated signals about the economy that I glean from models, surveys, and financial markets.2', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="First, because of Friedman's long and variable lags, monetary policy should be—and, at the Fed, is—forward looking. Policy decisions made today will have no effect on today's inflation or unemployment rates, so good policy needs to assess where the economic fundamentals are going tomorrow to calibrate appropriate policy today.", theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Thus, central banks and financial markets are looking at the same data on macro fundamentals to make inferences about the future path of the economy, and, of course, any decisions on the policy path made by the central bank will influence asset prices through the discount factor.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Second, because key variables that are crucial inputs for conducting monetary policy—such as r*, u*, and expected inflation, to name just three—are both unobserved and time varying, responsible monetary policy requires informed views about how these variables evolve over time as well as a humility and an appreciation for the uncertainties surrounding baseline views, however well informed they might be.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Third, when trying to make an inference about unobserved variables like r* or expected inflation, it is generally a good idea to seek data from multiple signals correlated with the variable of interest, so long as the signals themselves are not perfectly correlated with one another.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Data Dependence As I have written before, monetary policy needs to be—and, at the Fed, is— "data dependent" in two distinct ways.4 Policy should be data dependent in the sense that incoming data indicate the position of the economy relative to the ultimate objectives of price stability and maximum employment.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Monetary policy, however, also needs to be data dependent in the second sense—that incoming data contain signals—that can enable the central bank to update its estimates of r* and u* in order to obtain its best estimate of the destination to which the economy is heading.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='In addition to u* and r*, an important input into any monetary policy assessment is the state of inflation expectations. One of the robust messages from the DSGE (dynamic stochastic general equilibrium) literature on optimal monetary policy is that, away from the effective lower bound, optimal monetary policy will not eliminate all inflation volatility—there are always shocks—but will, under rational expectations (RE), deliver average, and under RE, expected, inflation equal to the target.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Financial Data and Monetary Policy Let me now discuss in more detail how I use a form of model averaging to combine financial market data with data from surveys and econometric models to inform my thinking about the evolution of two key inputs to monetary policy: r* and long-run expected inflation.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='For example, a "straight read" of interest rate futures prices provides one source of high-frequency information about the destination for the federal funds rate expected by market participants.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Quotes from the Treasury Inflation-Protected Securities (TIPS) market can provide valuable information about both r* and expected inflation. TIPS market data, together with nominal Treasury yields, can be used to construct measures of "breakeven inflation" or inflation compensation that provide a noisy signal of market expectations of future inflation.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='In both of the examples I have just discussed, the medium-frequency evolution of market-based, survey-based, and model-based estimates of r* and expected inflation have, over time, tended to move broadly together.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='In conclusion, while my colleagues and I are attuned to the potential for a hall of mirrors problem, in my experience this affliction is one the Federal Reserve guards against and does not suffer from.', theme='other')]

title: Spontaneity and Order:  Transparency, Accountability, and Fairness in Bank Supervision
speaker: Vice Chair for Supervision Randal K. Quarles
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph="It's a great pleasure to be with you today at Yale Law School to deliver this Dean's Lecture.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The themes and goals of this speech are objectives I will be pursuing over the next year and should resonate for this audience.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Twenty years ago when I was in private practice, a lecture on bank supervision would have been my cue to pull out my BlackBerry and start checking my emails.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='This division of labor is important for lawyers and policymakers to think about deeply because the processes of regulation and supervision are necessarily different in crucial respects.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Supervision, by contrast, implements the regulatory framework through close engagement with the particular facts about particular firms:', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Given the strong public interest in the safe, sound, and efficient operation of the financial industry and the potential for hair-raising and widespread adverse social consequences of private misjudgment or misconduct in that industry, close and regular supervision of this sort can help us all sleep restfully.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='In granting to agencies such as the Fed the significant power to write regulations, Congress has codified a regulatory process that emphasizes transparency.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Not everything that government does, however, can be accomplished in exactly the same way that regulations are written. One of these things is bank supervision.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Banks are subjected to supervision, in addition to regulation, as an additional form of government oversight because of their complexity, opacity, vulnerability to runs, and indispensable role in the economy, enabling payments, transmitting monetary policy, and providing credit.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='This is a crucial point: supervision is most effective when expectations are clear and supervision promotes an approach to risk management that deters bad behavior and decisions by banks.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="I don't believe the Federal Reserve has communicated as clearly as it could with the banks we supervise. More transparency and more clarity about what we want to achieve as supervisors and how we approach our work will improve supervision,", theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Let me briefly touch on some of the specific changes I will pursue, and which flow from the themes I have just discussed.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='First, I would mention that we should pursue a clear and transparent standard that aligns our supervisory portfolios,', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Second, as I have discussed throughout my time at the Board, I continue to look for ways to make our stress tests more transparent without making them game-able and without diluting their potency as a supervisory tool.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph="Third, and principally as a transparency endeavor, I would endorse creating a word-searchable database on the Board's website with the historical interpretations by the Board and its staff of all significant rules.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The changes to supervision since the crisis have made the financial system stronger and more resilient than it was before.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Equally obviously, however, these suggestions would strengthen our practice of supervision and increase the vigor and credibility of our supervisors.', theme='other')]
