title: A Conversation on Central Banking Issues
speaker: Governor Jerome H. Powell
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph='Thank you for inviting me here today. I should say at the outset that the views that I offer are my own and not necessarily those of any other member of the Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC).', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='My view is that forward guidance has generally been effective in providing support for the economy at a time when the federal funds rate has been pinned at its effective lower bound.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='In my view, forward rate guidance has helped reduce medium and longer-term interest rates, and by doing so has provided meaningful support for the economy.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='First, by increasing public understanding and market confidence in the path of rates, guidance has helped reduce term premiums.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Second, by communicating that rates would remain lower for longer than market participants might otherwise have expected, guidance has lowered medium- and longer-term rates through the expectations channel.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Finally, even when guidance has initially been well aligned with market expectations, it has reduced the likelihood that rate expectations will subsequently shift upward in ways that the Committee does not intend.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Event studies as well as market-implied quotes and surveys corroborate the view that guidance has reduced medium- and longer-term interest rates and has held down volatility as well.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='To be sure, there have also been times when forward guidance and market expectations have diverged, with resulting spikes in volatility.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Our forward guidance has evolved over time--from qualitative, to date-based, to quantitative guidance, and from largely unconditional to state-contingent guidance explaining how the Committee will react to future economic outcomes.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='In March 2009, the Committee offered the qualitative guidance that it expected to hold the federal funds rate near zero "for an extended period."1', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='In August 2011, the Committee moved to date-based guidance, saying that it expected to hold the rate near zero at least until mid-2013.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The FOMC has provided various forms of forward guidance since 2009, both for rate policy and for asset purchases.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='More recently, at the March 2014 FOMC meeting, as the 6-1/2 percent unemployment threshold approached, the Committee offered new guidance that contained qualitative and time-based elements but retained the state-contingent nature of the threshold guidance.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The Committee said that, in determining how long to hold the federal funds rate near zero, it "will assess progress--both realized and expected--toward its objectives of maximum employment and 2 percent inflation"; it also indicated that, in making this assessment, it would take into account a wide range of information.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Based on its assessment of these factors, the Committee indicated, "that it likely will be appropriate to maintain the current target range for the federal funds rate for a considerable time after the asset purchase program ends."', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The Committee stated that it "anticipates that, even after employment and inflation are near mandate-consistent levels, economic conditions may, for some time, warrant keeping the target federal funds rate below levels the Committee views as normal in the longer run."', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Committee members have differing thoughts on why that may be the case.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="Turning briefly to asset purchases, since last December's FOMC meeting, the Committee has reduced asset purchases in a series of measured steps from a pace of $85 billion a month to its current pace of $45 billion per month.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="If incoming information continues to broadly support the Committee's expectation of ongoing improvement in labor market conditions and inflation moving back toward its longer-run objective, these measured steps would continue and asset purchases would come to an end in the fourth quarter of this year.", theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Market expectations seem to be well aligned with this guidance.', theme='other')]

title: Commencement Remarks
speaker: Chair Janet L. Yellen
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph='Such curiosity led Eric Kandel, here at NYU, to his lifetime goal, to discover the chemical and cellular basis of human memory.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='A second tool for lifelong intellectual growth is a willingness to listen carefully to others.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="Yankee Stadium is a natural venue for another lesson: You won't succeed all the time.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="There is an unfortunate myth that success is mainly determined by something called 'ability.' But research indicates that our best measures of these qualities are unreliable predictors of performance in academics or employment. Psychologist Angela Lee Duckworth says that what really matters is a quality she calls 'grit'--an abiding commitment to work hard toward long-range goals and to persevere through the setbacks that come along the way.", theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='One aspect of grit that I think is particularly important is the willingness to take a stand when circumstances demand it. Such circumstances may not be all that frequent, but in every life, there will be crucial moments when having the courage to stand up for what you believe will be immensely important.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='My predecessor at the Fed, Chairman Ben Bernanke, demonstrated such courage, especially in his response to the threat of the financial crisis. To stabilize the financial system and restore economic growth, he took courageous actions that were unprecedented in ambition and scope. He faced relentless criticism, personal threats, and the certainty that history would judge him harshly if he was wrong. But he stood up for what he believed was right and necessary.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Having dwelt for a moment on failure and grit, let me turn to the deeper meaning that underpins grit and can carry us beyond failure. The hard work of building a life that makes a difference is much easier to sustain when you are passionate about what you pursue.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Finally, I hope that you can find joy in the lives you choose. You are completing one important phase of your life today and embarking on an amazing new adventure. Serious decisions about life surely lie ahead, but take the time to savor the joys, large and small that come along the way.', theme='other')]

title: Remarks on Women's History Month
speaker: Chair Janet L. Yellen
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph="It's an honor and a pleasure for me to be here with you to mark Women's History Month, which itself has some history behind it.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="March 8, 1911 was the first International Women's Day, and it was 1980 when President Carter established National Women's History Week. In 1987, Congress acted to make that week a full month.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Women, of course, are also a part of history for the other 11 months of the year. And I would add that women were influencing the course of history long before 1980, or 1911. But I am glad that there is, each year, a time when we pause to think about the role of women, because history is more than simply what happened, and more than what women and men did to make it happen.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='History is what we remember about those deeds. It is the lessons we have taken from the past and the knowledge we draw on to live today and to shape the future.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="For me, one lesson from history is that it is no coincidence that America's great success in the past century came as women steadily increased their participation in every aspect of society. Starting with gaining the vote, just a few years before International Women's Day, 'The American Century,' as it's sometimes known, was also a century of progress for women.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="One reason America's example is influential elsewhere is because progress toward these ideals has been accompanied by great success in broadly raising living standards. And I think our economic success has been due in substantial part to the fuller participation and contribution of women to the economy.", theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Their increasing participation in the workforce, particularly after 1970, was a major factor in sustaining growing family incomes. Making fuller use of the talents and efforts of women in the workplace has made us more productive and prosperous.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='If I were to apply this lesson, I would hope that our nation continues to reap the benefits of greater participation by women in the economy and that we do everything that we can to foster that participation.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Women have made great progress in many occupations and professions, but lag in others. In my own profession, there has been a gradual increase in the share of women in economics, but women still remain underrepresented at the highest levels in academia, in government and in business.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph="There are doubtless numerous reasons for this, and in fact economists themselves are among those engaged in trying to understand the factors that explain why more women aren't rising to higher levels.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='I hope we continue to seek this understanding, in my field and others where women are in the minority, because the benefits of greater participation for women, it seems to me, are clear and substantial.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph="As we continue to make progress in recovering from the Great Recession, our country is going to need the best efforts, ideas and talent it can muster to succeed in an increasingly competitive global economy. If women's history can shape the future, I hope that it inspires America to take those steps we can take to draw forth these contributions from all Americans.", theme='other')]

title: Remarks at the Ceremonial Swearing-in
speaker: Chair Janet L. Yellen
tags:
[ThemeTag(paragraph='March 05, 2014
Chair Janet L. Yellen
At the Federal Reserve Board, Washington, D.C.

       Good afternoon. Thank you Dan, and thank you to everyone gathered here and others throughout the System who are listening in.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='
       To members of Congress, Secretary Lew and others from the administration and fellow financial regulatory agencies who are with us today, welcome to the Federal Reserve. Many friends and family of mine are here, including my spouse, George, my brother, John, and my sister-in-law, Alison. I am honored also to welcome back former Chairman Greenspan.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='
       I want to particularly thank President Obama for the honor of being asked to lead the Federal Reserve and carry on its important work. When I accepted his offer, I promised the president I would do my very best, working with my Fed colleagues, to help restore the health of the economy and promote a strong and stable financial system.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="
       I am repeating this promise, in this distinguished company and to all others listening because that is what this ceremony is about. The oath I have affirmed, identical to the one taken by everyone serving the Federal Reserve, is a public promise to carry out my duties guided by no interest other than the public's interest.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="
       Today's event comes, as many of you know, a busy month after I began my duties as Chair. In that short time, the Board has taken significant steps to further strengthen financial regulation, and I have discharged one of my most important responsibilities, accounting for the Fed's actions and explaining its policies in our semi-annual report to Congress.", theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='
       Such communication is vital in a democracy and especially important for the Federal Reserve, which relies on the confidence of the public to be effective in carrying out its mission. Chairman Bernanke initiated press conferences in 2011 as one of a number of steps to make the Federal Reserve more transparent and accountable, and I promise to build on his legacy.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='
       Since 2010, when Chairman Bernanke stood where I stand today, we have made considerable progress. The economy is stronger and the financial system is sounder. We have come a long way, but we have farther to go.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="
       More work lies ahead to complete implementation of Congress' plan for strengthening financial regulation, the Dodd-Frank Act. I promise to stay focused on moving that process forward as quickly and responsibly as possible and to verify that these reforms are meeting the goal of safeguarding the financial system.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="
       I will also continue the work of helping repair the damage done by the financial crisis to the economy. Too many Americans still can't find a job or are forced to work part-time.", theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='
       The goals set by Congress for the Federal Reserve are clear: maximum employment and stable prices. It is equally clear that the economy continues to operate considerably short of these objectives.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='
       I promise to do all that I can, working with my fellow policymakers, to achieve the very important goals Congress has assigned to the Federal Reserve.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='
       Congress has entrusted the Federal Reserve with great responsibilities. The tools we deploy, to guide the financial system and influence our vast economy, can seem far removed from the lives and concerns of average Americans.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='
       And yet the decisions we make affect the welfare and shape the future of every American. I promise to never forget the individual lives, experiences and challenges that lie behind the statistics we use to gauge the health of the economy.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='
       The unemployment rate represents millions of individuals who are eager to work but struggling to provide for themselves and their families. When we make progress toward our goals, each job that is created lifts this burden for someone who is better equipped to be a good parent, to build a stronger community, and to contribute to a more prosperous nation.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='
       Let me close by offering my heartfelt thanks for the many messages I have received since my nomination from individuals around the country who have written to wish me well and offer their support. I pledge to do my very best to meet the challenges that lie ahead.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='
       Thank you all for coming today.', theme='other')]

title: Monetary Policy and Financial Stability
speaker: Governor Daniel K. Tarullo
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph='This is a comprehensive speech by Daniel K. Tarullo, the then-Unders Secretary for Domestic Finance at the U.S. Department of the Treasury, on the relationship between financial stability considerations and monetary policy.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The speech can be summarized as follows:', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='1. **Monetary Policy Cannot Be Ignored**: Tarullo emphasizes that monetary policy cannot be taken off the table as a response to broad and sustained systemic risk, but notes that there are other tools available that could help reduce the number of occasions on which a difficult tradeoff between financial stability considerations and near-term growth or price stability aims will need to be made.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='2. **Existing Supervisory Tools**: He discusses how existing supervisory tools can be developed further to address potential systemic risk, including macroprudential measures such as countercyclical capital buffers and minimum margins on securities financing transactions.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='3. **Macroprudential Measures**: Tarullo notes that macroprudential measures can complement monetary policy in managing systemic risk, citing the example of the countercyclical capital buffer and minimum margins on securities financing transactions.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='4. **Monetary Policy Refinements**: He suggests refining monetary policy tools to address concurrent concerns about macroeconomic sluggishness and excessive maturity transformation by lowering the target (short-term) interest rate and simultaneously flattening the yield curve through swapping shorter duration assets for longer-term ones.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='5. **Systemic Risk Considerations**: Tarullo highlights that the explosive growth of short-term wholesale funding is a direct financial stability concern, which has motivated him to devote attention to measures such as minimum margins on securities financing transactions.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='6. **Macroprudential Regulation**: He discusses macroprudential regulation, citing previous speeches and emphasizing its importance in managing systemic risk without removing monetary policy accommodation to advance one or both dual mandate goals.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph="7. **Financial Stability Concerns**: Tarullo notes that the conduct of monetary policy has become more complicated in recent years due to changes in the financial system, and suggests considering refinements to monetary policy tools, such as altering the composition of a central bank's balance sheet.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='8. **Shared or Complementary Authorities**: He highlights the issue of shared or complementary authorities, grounded in constitutional considerations such as democratic accountability and avoiding too much concentration of power in any one part of government, which is already a factor in the context of monetary policy and regulatory authority.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='9. **Macroprudential Policies like Countercyclical Capital Buffer**: Tarullo notes that macroprudential policies like countercyclical capital buffers also bolster resilience in the financial sector by increasing bank and dealer loss absorbency, and suggests considering such policies as a complement to monetary policy.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='10. **International Cooperation**: He emphasizes the importance of international cooperation in addressing systemic risk, citing examples from other countries and institutions.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='11. **Recommendations for Central Banks**: Tarullo offers recommendations for central banks, including developing existing supervisory tools, adopting macroprudential measures, considering structural changes affecting certain forms of financing, and refining monetary policy tools to address concurrent concerns about macroeconomic sluggishness and excessive maturity transformation.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='12. **Conclusion**: He concludes by noting that the development of existing supervisory tools, the judicious use of macroprudential measures, the adoption of some structural measures affecting certain forms of financing, and perhaps some refinements of monetary policy tools can together reduce the number of occasions on which a difficult tradeoff between financial stability considerations and near-term growth or price stability aims will need to be made.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The speech is notable for its comprehensive overview of the relationship between financial stability considerations and monetary policy, as well as its emphasis on the importance of developing existing supervisory tools, adopting macroprudential measures, and refining monetary policy tools to address concurrent concerns about macroeconomic sluggishness and excessive maturity transformation.', theme='other')]

title: Concluding Remarks
speaker: Chairman Ben S. Bernanke
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph='The values that have sustained and served the Federal Reserve at its best, and have permitted it to make critical contributions to the economic health of our nation during the past century, will continue to serve it and the nation well in the century ahead.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="the ideal we seek is a combination of the researcher's intellectual rigor and the ability of the effective policymaker to navigate the messiness of the real world, a world that includes complex institutions and markets, imperfect and incomplete data, and often-unpredictable human behavior.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Maintaining that quality and commitment to public service will be essential if the Fed is to have a successful second century.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="The fight against inflation during Paul and Alan's times in office was critical for the nation's longer-term prosperity, and it required perseverance in the face of heavy criticism.", theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph="Our ability to make accurate long-term forecasts is limited, to say the least. Nevertheless, I will venture one prediction that I don't think is too bold, which is this: The values that have sustained and served the Federal Reserve at its best, and have permitted it to make critical contributions to the economic health of our nation during the past century, will continue to serve it and the nation well in the century ahead.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The ability of this institution to support a healthy economy--an economy with high levels of employment, low inflation, and a stable financial system--will require our continued efforts to engage in two-way communication--explaining our actions and, importantly, listening to what our fellow citizens have to say.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Of course, we will continue to talk to economists and market participants, but that is not enough. Ultimately, the legitimacy of our policies rests on the understanding and support of the broader American public, whose interests we are working to serve.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="But one value that strikes me as having been at least as important as any other has been the Federal Reserve's willingness, during its finest hours, to stand up to political pressure and make tough but necessary decisions.", theme='other')]

title: Opening Remarks
speaker: Chairman Ben S. Bernanke
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph="The Federal Reserve's extraordinary response to the financial crisis and the Great Recession that followed was, in one sense, nothing new. We did what central banks have done for many years and what they were designed to do: We served as a source of liquidity and stability in financial markets, and, in the broader economy, we worked to foster economic recovery and price stability.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='When the financial system teetered near collapse in 2008 and 2009, we responded as the 19th century British essayist Walter Bagehot advised, by serving as liquidity provider of last resort to stressed financial firms and markets.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The Fed has also worked to draw the appropriate lessons from the crisis and to take the steps necessary to help avoid a similar event in the future. As those assembled here well know, the deliberations that led to the founding of the Federal Reserve were precipitated by a financial panic, the Panic of 1907.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='We have also had to be innovative in finding ways to use monetary policy to help the economy recover from the deep recession that followed the crisis. Providing adequate monetary accommodation has not been a straightforward task because our principal monetary policy tool, the target for the federal funds rate, has been stuck near zero since the end of 2008.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='A significant aspect of finding innovative ways to execute our duties as a central bank in a new, more complex environment has been the ongoing revolution in communication and transparency. Part of that effort has involved formally defining our goals under the mandate for maximum employment and price stability given to us by the Congress.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='One of my personal objectives since I became Chairman has been to increase the transparency of the Fed--to more clearly explain how our policies are intended to work and the thinking behind our decisions.', theme='other')]

title: Shadow Banking and Systemic Risk Regulation
speaker: Governor Daniel K. Tarullo
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph='This lengthy document is a discussion on the vulnerabilities in the financial system related to short-term wholesale funding, specifically securities financing transactions (SFTs). The author highlights the importance of addressing these vulnerabilities through regulatory measures.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Key points from the document:', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='1. **Shadow banking system**: Large firms that rely on SFTs for a significant proportion of their funding are outside the perimeter of prudential regulation.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='2. **Vulnerabilities in short-term wholesale funding**: Runs can occur, leading to fire sales and reducing capital levels.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='3. **Current regulatory measures**: Capital and liquidity standards have been adopted since the crisis, but they do not fully address the systemic risks associated with SFTs.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='4. **Need for more comprehensive reform agenda**: A sounder, more stable financial system requires a more comprehensive reform agenda that includes addressing vulnerabilities in short-term wholesale funding.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The author proposes several regulatory options to mitigate these risks:', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='1. **Capital surcharge based on short-term wholesale funding usage**: This would add an incentive to use more stable funding and increase the loss absorbency of firms.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='2. **Increased capital charges applicable to SFT assets or modified liquidity standards**: These measures would require firms with large amounts of SFTs to hold larger liquidity buffers or maintain more stable funding structures.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='3. **Universal margin requirements for SFTs**: This would set minimum excess margin levels that vary depending on the asset class of collateral, limiting leverage at the security level and mitigating procyclical margin calls.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The author also notes that a framework of universal margin requirements for SFTs might be evaded through disintermediation or alternative transactional structures. However, they suggest that addressing these vulnerabilities is essential to maintaining a sound financial system.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Overall, this document highlights the importance of regulatory measures to address vulnerabilities in short-term wholesale funding and prevent contagious runs.', theme='other')]

title: Teaching and Learning about the Federal Reserve
speaker: Chairman Ben S. Bernanke
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph='', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='President Woodrow Wilson signed the Federal Reserve Act, which established the Federal Reserve System, on December 23, 1913. As the 100th anniversary of that event approaches, we have several reasons to look back at an eventful century.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph="Beyond the insights that the study of the Federal Reserve's first 100 years offer to economists, historians, and policymakers about how the Fed can best meet its objectives today and in the future, a second reason to mark the centennial is the opportunity it affords to educate young people about the Federal Reserve and its important role in promoting a healthy economy and stable financial system.", theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Economics also complements and enriches the study of history. When I took history classes in high school, we spent much of our time memorizing dates and important events--revolutions, wars, elections, the passage of laws, and so on.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='By the same token, understanding history also requires an appreciation of the role of key economic institutions, including central banks like the Federal Reserve. When I was in graduate school, my teacher, Stanley Fischer, introduced me to the work of Milton Friedman and Anna Schwartz, which demonstrated that monetary policy can have enormous effects on how the economy performs, for good or for ill.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Learning about the Federal Reserve and about economics more generally will help students in their daily lives, by helping them make better financial or career decisions, for example, and by helping them become more informed citizens and voters.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Traditionally, like other central banks, the Fed was reluctant to explain its policy decisions or otherwise engage with the public, partly based on a belief that this approach increased the effectiveness of monetary policy.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='It is often said--alas, accurately--that teaching is a thankless profession, so let me close by thanking you for what you give to your students. Our country and our economy need informed citizens who can think independently and critically.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="Thank you for participating in today's event. I look forward to your questions and to an interesting discussion of the Federal Reserve's past, present, and future.", theme='other')]

title: The Crisis as a Classic Financial Panic
speaker: Chairman  Ben S. Bernanke
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph='An expert on financial crises, Stan has written prolifically on the subject and has also served on the front lines, so to speak--notably, in his role as the first deputy managing director of the International Monetary Fund during the emerging market crises of the 1990s.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Fundamentally, the Panic of 1907 and the Panic of 2008 were instances of the same phenomenon, as I have discussed today.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The responses to the panics of 1907 and 2008 also provide instructive comparisons. In both cases, the provision of liquidity in the early stages was crucial.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph="Full stabilization requires the restoration of public confidence. Three basic tools for restoring confidence are temporary public or private guarantees, measures to strengthen financial institutions' balance sheets, and public disclosure of the conditions of financial firms.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Regulatory and supervisory reforms, such as higher capital and liquidity standards or restriction on certain activities, can directly limit risk-taking.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The absence of an adequate resolution process for dealing with a failing SIFI left policymakers with only the terrible choices of a bailout or allowing a potentially destabilizing collapse.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Our continuing challenge is to make financial crises far less likely and, if they happen, far less costly.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The task of making the financial system safer must inevitably confront the problem of moral hazard.', theme='other')]

title: Lean, Clean, and In-Between
speaker: Governor Jeremy C. Stein
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph='The traditional, pre-crisis framing of the question went something like this: Should policymakers rely on ex ante measures to lean against potential financial imbalances as they build up, and thereby lower the probability of a bad event ever happening, or should they do most of their work ex post, focusing on the clean-up?', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Discussion these days tends to focus instead on which ex ante measures are best suited to safeguard financial stability.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='There is considerably less agreement about the desirability and effectiveness of ex ante measures that seek to lean against the wind in an explicitly time-varying fashion--that is, measures that can be adapted in response to changing economic or financial conditions.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The second school is more comfortable with the idea of time-varying leans, but invokes what amounts to a separation principle: It takes the view that any financial-stability-motivated leans should come largely, if not entirely, from time-variation in the application of regulatory and supervisory tools, while monetary policy should stick to its traditional dual-mandate objectives of fostering full employment and maintaining price stability.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The third school is more heterodox. Like the first, it acknowledges that there are a variety of practical limitations associated with discretionary time-varying regulation, though the severity of these limitations may vary considerably across different countries, markets, and institutional arrangements.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='But precisely for these reasons, the whole lean-versus-clean debate runs the risk of drawing attention away from other crisis-derived lessons that do not make as good fodder for academic discussion, but that are no less relevant from a practical policy perspective.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Recall that problems with subprime mortgages were already surfacing in late 2006.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='During normal times, when banks are relatively healthy, the CCAR process functions as an important complement to more conventional capital regulation and, like capital regulation, it can be thought of as an ex ante instrument to increase the general resilience of the banking system to as-yet-unknown shocks.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='On the one hand, there is some reason for optimism on this score. After all, the original stress tests--the Supervisory Capital Assessment Program (SCAP) in May 2009--provided the impetus for a significant recapitalization of the banking system.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The Federal Reserve conducts the CCAR annually to help ensure that companies have forward-looking capital planning processes that account for their unique risks and that result in sufficient capital to enable the institutions to continue lending to households and businesses during times of economic and financial stress.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='A firm that is told that it needs to improve its capital position will, given the interests of its shareholders, strongly prefer to do so by reducing assets rather than by engaging in a dilutive share issue, even though the latter is more desirable from the perspective of aggregate credit provision.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='So if we are serious about taking a macroprudential approach to regulation--one which aims to protect not just the solvency of individual firms, but the health of the financial system as a whole and its ability to continue to perform its intermediation role in times of stress--it is incumbent on us as regulators to do all that we can to develop both the intellectual case, and the institutional resolve, to be able to push back with equal force when the time comes.', theme='other')]

title: Toward Building a More Effective Resolution Regime: Progress and Challenges
speaker: Governor Daniel K. Tarullo
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph='The main points are:', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='1. **Key Attributes**: In November 2011, the Financial Stability Board adopted Key Attributes of Effective Resolution Regimes for Financial Institutions, an international standard setting out core elements for effective special resolution regimes.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='2. **Single-Point-of-Entry Approach**: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (FDIC) is developing a single-point-of-entry approach to resolving systemically important financial institutions, which would prioritize the preservation of critical functions and prevent a systemic crisis.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='3. **Resolution Mechanism**: Title II establishes an orderly liquidation authority for systemically important financial institutions, providing a third option between bailout or bankruptcy. The resolution mechanism has gained operational credibility as the FDIC builds out its single-point-of-entry approach.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='4. **Cross-Border Matters**: Resolving globally active financial institutions is challenging due to differences in regulatory frameworks and jurisdictional boundaries. However, efforts are being made to address these issues through cross-border agreements and regulatory reforms.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='5. **Future Work**: Significant work remains to build and communicate a credible resolution mechanism that will allow investors, creditors, and counterparties of large financial firms to form reasonable expectations about how a resolution would be conducted.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='6. **Bankruptcy Code Amendments**: There are ongoing discussions about adapting the Bankruptcy Code to address the unique challenges posed by systemically important financial institutions. A proposal for a new Chapter 14 has been put forward, which would provide for a more streamlined and efficient process for resolving these firms.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='7. **Reducing Too-Big-to-Fail Risks**: Stronger capital and liquidity requirements are crucial in reducing the risk of systemically important firm failures that would require the special resolution mechanism.', theme='employment')]

title: Celebrating 20 Years of the Bank of Mexico's Independence
speaker: Chairman Ben S. Bernanke
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph="It is a pleasure to offer a few remarks at this conference marking the 20th anniversary of the Bank of Mexico's independence. In August 1993, Mexico's congress approved changes to the country's constitution that granted policy autonomy to the Bank of Mexico and made price stability its primary mandate. Over the past two decades, these actions, along with a number of other constructive steps taken by Mexican policymakers, have paid substantial dividends in terms of improved economic performance.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="At the time that the Mexican congress changed the status and mandate of the central bank, the nation's economy had been suffering periodic bouts of economic instability for many years. The 1970s through the mid-1990s in particular were marked by episodes of high inflation, boom-and-bust cycles, and financial crises.", theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='However, the changes to the monetary policy framework, along with greater fiscal discipline and the adoption of a more flexible exchange rate, soon bore fruit. Notably, inflation fell to single-digit levels by the early 2000s.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph="Importantly, the improved monetary policy framework, together with other reforms, has thus far helped reduce Mexico's susceptibility to financial crises.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Strong countercyclical policy actions of this type were unlikely to have been feasible in Mexico a few decades ago; with little in the way of inflation-fighting credibility and an immature financial sector, the monetary authority in earlier years was often forced to respond to a crisis by tightening monetary conditions, rather than loosening them, in an effort to limit capital flight, exchange rate depreciation, and increases in inflation.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph="Of course, we should not be surprised that central bank independence has contributed to Mexico's improved macroeconomic stability over the past two decades. A broad consensus among economists--supported by considerable empirical evidence--holds that a central bank's credibility and effectiveness are enhanced when it is able to make monetary policy based on its assessment of what is in the economy's long-run interest rather than in response to short-term political pressures.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='As you probably know, the Federal Reserve is also celebrating an anniversary this year--the centennial of its founding. Like the Bank of Mexico, the Federal Reserve is an independent central bank, and, as in the case of the Bank of Mexico, that independence has evolved and gradually strengthened over time.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Indeed, during the recent financial crisis and the ensuing recession, the Fed has been able to take aggressive monetary policy actions to help stabilize the economy without dislodging longer-term inflation expectations.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='We should recognize, though, that in democratic societies, central bank independence must be accompanied by accountability to the public and its representatives. In this regard, transparency is key.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The strong links between our economies have led to close cooperation between our central banks. An example is the bilateral currency swap arrangement between the Federal Reserve and the Bank of Mexico that was set up during the global financial crisis.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='This swap line was one of 14 that the Fed established with foreign central banks around the world. These swap arrangements proved their value as they helped alleviate dollar funding pressures, reduce interbank borrowing rates, and calm market fears during some of the worst phases of the crisis.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='I would be remiss if, before ending, I did not note the strong leadership that Governor Agustín Carstens continues to provide at the Bank of Mexico. His leadership in economic policy, in several key roles, has been instrumental in solidifying the progress that Mexico has made over the past two decades.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='To conclude, I would like to congratulate the Bank of Mexico on the 20th anniversary of its independence. I wish you a productive conference marking this auspicious occasion.', theme='other')]

title: Communications Challenges and Quantitative Easing
speaker: Governor Jerome H. Powell
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph='It is an honor to be here today with such distinguished panelists to discuss the communications challenges associated with quantitative easing.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="I'll start with the FOMC's commitment, when the current asset purchase program was launched in September 2012, to continue purchases until the Committee sees a substantial improvement in the outlook for the labor market, a term the Committee left undefined.", theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Economic conditions have improved since the program was launched. Consumer and business confidence moved higher, and sectors such as housing and autos have performed well. Despite strong, ongoing headwinds from fiscal policy, there has been significant progress in the labor market.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph="In March 2013, the Committee began noting in its postmeeting statement that it would consider 'the extent of progress toward its economic objectives' in judging 'the size, pace, and composition of its asset purchases.'", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="Under the most recent articulation of that framework, in considering when to reduce purchases, the Committee will 'assess whether incoming information continues to support [its] expectation of ongoing improvement in labor market conditions and inflation moving back toward its longer-run objective.'", theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Many factors may have contributed to this market reaction. Among them, I would argue that market expectations began to lose touch with Committee intentions in two ways.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="Second, the expected path of the federal funds rate, as reflected in various market prices, increased significantly, implying an earlier liftoff from the zero lower bound than suggested by the Committee's forward guidance.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The September decision not to reduce purchases clearly took some market participants by surprise.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="I would like to push back against the narrative that the decision at the September meeting has damaged the Committee's communications strategy.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="The September decision underscored the Committee's intention to determine the pace of purchases in a data-dependent way based on progress toward our objectives.", theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph="Short term rates have fallen back since the September meeting, and are now better aligned with the Committee's forward rate guidance.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='To wrap up, let me emphasize that what matters is the overall stance of policy, not the pace of asset purchases.', theme='other')]

title: The Fire-Sales Problem and Securities Financing Transactions
speaker: Governor Jeremy C. Stein
tags:
[ThemeTag(paragraph='This is a long document that discusses the concept of "fire sales" in financial markets, particularly in the context of securities lending and repurchase agreements (repos). Fire sales refer to situations where assets are sold at distressed prices due to a rapid decline in market value, leading to a cascade of selling pressure and exacerbating market instability. The author argues that fire sales can have broader macroeconomic consequences, including credit contractions and economic downturns.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The document surveys various regulatory tools that could be used to mitigate the risk of fire sales, including:
1. Capital surcharges: Imposing additional capital requirements on financial institutions that engage in repos or securities lending.
2. Modifications to the liquidity regulation framework: Revising existing regulations, such as the Liquidity Coverage Ratio (LCR) and Net Stable Funding Ratio (NSFR), to better capture the risks associated with fire sales.
3. Universal margin requirements: Imposing minimum haircut requirements on all parties involved in repos or securities lending, regardless of their regulatory status.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The author notes that these tools are not mutually exclusive and could be combined to achieve a more effective mitigation of fire sale risk. However, they also acknowledge that finding the right balance between regulation and market efficiency is crucial.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Additionally, the document highlights the importance of addressing another area of fragility in financial markets: the money market fund sector. The author suggests that reforms aimed at reducing the vulnerability of money funds to runs and improving their capital structures could help mitigate the risk of fire sales.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The document concludes by emphasizing the need for a comprehensive approach to regulating fire sale risk, involving multiple regulatory tools and a coordinated effort among different stakeholders in the financial system.', theme='other')]

title: Brief Welcoming Remarks
speaker: Chairman Ben S. Bernanke
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph='I would like to welcome everyone to the inaugural Community Banking Research and Policy Conference, co-sponsored by the Federal Reserve System and the Conference of State Bank Supervisors (CSBS). I particularly want to thank the Federal Reserve and CSBS staff members who worked hard to organize this event. By bringing together community bankers, bank regulators, and researchers from academic institutions and government agencies, the conference will help us all to better understand the issues that are most important to the future of community banking.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The U.S. banking system has undergone significant consolidation over the past two decades or so, with very large banking organizations increasing their market shares.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Community banking is fundamentally a local, relationship-based business. Community bankers live in the localities they serve; their customers are their neighbors and friends.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Although community banks have some natural advantages, such as local knowledge and relationships, they also face significant challenges.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The best way to understand the challenges that community bankers face is to talk to the bankers themselves, and we at the Federal Reserve do that regularly. For example, to ensure that we remain mindful of the unique characteristics of community banks, the Federal Reserve Board established the Community Depository Institutions Advisory Council.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Of course, understanding those concerns is of limited value unless we use what we have learned in the process of rulemaking. To make that connection, we also established a subcommittee of the Board that reviews all regulatory and supervisory proposals for their potential effects on community banks.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='One of the strengths of the Federal Reserve System is the quality of the research done by our economists and other professionals. The research we do on community banking helps guide our thinking on regulatory matters and on broader economic trends.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The range of topics that will be covered over the next day and a half is impressive. The first research session this afternoon will focus on the role of community banks in our financial and economic system.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='As you can see, the papers at this conference cover a variety of important topics, and I expect they will provoke spirited discussions among the many experts in attendance.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='To close the conference, CSBS Chairman Charles Vice will present a report summarizing information gathered from more than 1,500 community bankers attending town hall sessions across the country over the past several months.', theme='employment')]

title: International Financial Regulatory Reform
speaker: Governor Jerome H. Powell
tags:
[ThemeTag(paragraph='Governor Jerome H. Powell
At the Deutsche Bundesbank Reception, New York, New York

       Thank you so much for inviting me to speak today.1 I join others in thanking Mr. Stephan for his service, and in welcoming Ms. Stirbock to her new role as Chief Representative of the Deutsche Bundesbank in the United States. I look forward to working with both of you, and with your colleagues, in the coming years. The Federal Reserve places great importance on our relations with the Bundesbank. Few such relationships have been as important, over the decades, in promoting financial stability and prosperity around the world.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Governor Jerome H. Powell
At the Deutsche Bundesbank Reception, New York, New York

       Governments, central bankers, and financial regulators labor today in the long shadow cast by the global financial crisis, and that likely will remain the case for many years. Against that background, I will touch briefly on fiscal and monetary policy here in the United States, before turning to financial regulatory issues.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Governor Jerome H. Powell
At the Deutsche Bundesbank Reception, New York, New York

       It has long been clear that, starting in this decade, the United States would begin to face longer-term fiscal challenges due to the aging of our population and our high and fast-rising per capita health-care costs. Over the next 20 years, it is projected that the ratio of our retired elderly to our working-age population will increase sharply from about 23 percent to about 36 percent. And, as you surely know, our per capita health care costs are far higher than those of other advanced economies, and have risen over time at a faster pace than per capita income. The combination of these two factors will put the U.S. federal budget on an unsustainable path if appropriate measures are not taken.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="Governor Jerome H. Powell
At the Deutsche Bundesbank Reception, New York, New York

       At the end of 2007, just prior to the onset of the last recession, the United States had federal government debt equal to about 36 percent of the size of our annual gross domestic product (GDP)--a moderate level. Since 2007, and largely as a consequence of the recession and policy actions to help alleviate its effects, the U.S. federal government's debt-to-GDP ratio has increased to around 75 percent. It is projected to remain near this level for the remainder of the decade under current federal budget policies. This high level of federal government debt leaves U.S. policymakers with less 'fiscal space' than may be required to deal with expected increases in retirement and health-care costs, or with unanticipated economic shocks.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Governor Jerome H. Powell
At the Deutsche Bundesbank Reception, New York, New York

       Over the last few years, the fiscal authorities have cut federal spending and raised taxes, and our Congressional Budget Office estimates that these fiscal headwinds will reduce real GDP growth by about 1.5 percentage points this year from what it otherwise would have been. Nevertheless, as a nation, we have not yet addressed in a fundamental way our longer-term budget challenges, particularly those associated with federal health-care programs. So I have no doubt that fiscal policy issues will retain an important and highly contentious place on the political agenda for many years here in the United States, as in Europe.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Governor Jerome H. Powell
At the Deutsche Bundesbank Reception, New York, New York

       I will turn for a moment to monetary policy. The Congress has tasked the Federal Reserve with conducting monetary policy to foster stable prices and full employment. Today, inflation is well below our 2 percent longer-term objective, as measured by prices for personal consumption expenditures. And although the unemployment rate has declined notably since its peak in 2010, it remains well above our estimate of a longer-run, more normal level. I expect that inflation will return gradually to our 2 percent objective, and that we will continue to make progress in reducing unemployment. In the meantime, the case for continued support for our economy from monetary policy remains strong.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Governor Jerome H. Powell
At the Deutsche Bundesbank Reception, New York, New York

       With these fiscal headwinds and the lingering effects of the recession, growth has remained in the range of 2 percent since 2009. But today, our private sector shows real signs of underlying improvement. Auto sales are strong, as is activity in our energy sector. Our housing market, which was at the heart of the crisis, is now recovering strongly. House prices are rising, and that is supporting improvement in household net worth and consumer attitudes. Homebuilders are responding to this price signal with rising housing starts, which will support job growth. Together, these and other factors give grounds to hope for the kind of self-reinforcing cycle of economic growth that we have been waiting to see.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Governor Jerome H. Powell
At the Deutsche Bundesbank Reception, New York, New York

       And as our economy has gradually improved, it has become possible, and appropriate, for the Federal Reserve to provide clearer guidance on the path of monetary policy. In all likelihood, this path will involve continued support from accommodative monetary policy for quite some time.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Governor Jerome H. Powell
At the Deutsche Bundesbank Reception, New York, New York

       Meanwhile, financial regulators around the world are engaged in a historic and sweeping renovation of the global financial architecture. The scope of this global regulatory project is enormous, and I will touch on only a few of its elements. One of the most important goals is to ensure that banks have adequate capital to withstand severe financial stress.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Governor Jerome H. Powell
At the Deutsche Bundesbank Reception, New York, New York

       Both in the United States and in Europe, some parts of the reform agenda will take longer to complete. For example, I note the ongoing progress toward achieving one of the most ambitious and important regulatory goals: the creation of a European banking union.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Governor Jerome H. Powell
At the Deutsche Bundesbank Reception, New York, New York

       Another reform that will take time to complete is the establishment of a global framework for resolving large, systemically important banks.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Governor Jerome H. Powell
At the Deutsche Bundesbank Reception, New York, New York

       Under the SPOE approach, the home country resolution authority for a failing banking firm would effect a creditor-funded parent company recapitalization of the failed firm.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Governor Jerome H. Powell
At the Deutsche Bundesbank Reception, New York, New York

       Reaching agreement on a cross-border resolution process will be challenging. Our financial services industries and our economies differ in many ways.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="Governor Jerome H. Powell
At the Deutsche Bundesbank Reception, New York, New York

       On that note, I will briefly discuss the Fed's proposal for oversight of foreign banks operating in the United States...", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Governor Jerome H. Powell
At the Deutsche Bundesbank Reception, New York, New York

       I will close by observing that the international effort to strengthen financial regulation cannot succeed unless each nation understands the goals and challenges faced by its partners.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Governor Jerome H. Powell
At the Deutsche Bundesbank Reception, New York, New York

       Thank you.', theme='other')]

title: Economic Prospects for the Long Run

tags:
[ThemeTag(paragraph="May 18, 2013
Chairman Ben S. Bernanke
At Bard College at Simon's Rock, Great Barrington, Massachusetts", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="
       I think everyone here appreciates what a special privilege each of you has enjoyed in attending a unique institution like Simon's Rock.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="

       What's so important about creativity and critical thinking? There are many answers.
", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="

       Many factors affect the development of the economy, notably among them a nation's economic and political institutions, but over long periods probably the most important factor is the pace of scientific and technological progress.", theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='

       The purpose of these comparisons is to make concrete the argument made by some economists, that the economic and technological transformation of the past 50 years, while significant, does not match the changes of the 50 years--or, for that matter, the 100 years--before that.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='

       First, innovation, almost by definition, involves ideas that no one has yet had, which means that forecasts of future technological change can be, and often are, wildly wrong.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='

       Second, not only are scientific and technical innovation themselves inherently hard to predict, so are the long-run practical consequences of innovation for our economy and our daily lives.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='

       Finally, pessimists may be paying too little attention to the strength of the underlying economic and social forces that generate innovation in the modern world.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='

title: Shadow Banking After the Financial Crisis
speaker: Governor Daniel K. Tarullo
tags:
[ThemeTag(paragraph='This is a lengthy document discussing the shadow banking system and its vulnerabilities in the financial sector. Here are some key points:', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='**The Shadow Banking System**
* The shadow banking system refers to non-traditional banks and financial institutions that provide credit and liquidity outside of traditional banking channels.
* These entities include money market mutual funds, repurchase agreement (repo) markets, securities lending markets, and other unregulated or lightly regulated financial intermediaries.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='**Vulnerabilities in the Shadow Banking System**
* The shadow banking system creates risks through implicit commitments to investors that low-risk assets are free of credit and liquidity risk.
* These commitments create an assumption among sophisticated investors that these money-like instruments are effectively cash, but with a slightly higher return.
* This risk illusion leads to pervasive underpricing of the risks embedded in these money-like instruments and makes them an artificially cheap source of funding.
* The consequent oversupply of these instruments contributes importantly to systemic risk.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='**Consequences of the Shadow Banking System**
* The unwinding of this risk illusion helped transform a dramatic correction in real estate valuations into a crisis that threatened the entire financial system.
* The shadow banking system has caused the volume of money-like instruments created outside the purview of central bank and regulatory control to grow markedly.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='**Recommendations for Regulatory Reform**
* Create greater transparency with respect to various transactions and markets that comprise the shadow banking system.
* Reduce the risk of runs on money market mutual funds through additional measures to address structural vulnerabilities.
* Address the settlement process for triparty repurchase agreements, which has not yet achieved the key risk reduction goal of eliminating intraday credit.
* In the medium term, a broader reform agenda for shadow banking will need to address the fact that there is little constraint on the use of leverage in some key types of transactions.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='**Conclusion**
* The shadow banking system today is smaller than at its peak during the housing bubble six or seven years ago, but it is likely to grow again without policy changes.
* A two-pronged agenda is suggested: near-term action to address current channels where mispricing, run risk, and potential moral hazard are evident, and continuation of the academic and policy debate on more fundamental measures to address these issues more broadly and proactively.', theme='other')]

tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph="I'm glad to have the chance to speak again to the Independent Community Bankers of America, even if it's by way of prerecorded remarks. This will be the first time in quite a few years that I haven't been with you in person, but, as you may know, the Federal Open Market Committee met just yesterday in Washington, so I am unable to join you in Nashville. I have very much enjoyed attending these annual ICBA get-togethers, especially since I get the chance to hear directly from you about what's happening in your local economies and in community banking more generally. It's a tradition I hope to reestablish in the future.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Community banks remain a critical component of our financial system and our economy. They help keep their local economies vibrant and growing by taking on and managing the risks of local lending, which larger banks may be unwilling or unable to do. They often respond with greater agility to lending requests than their national competitors because of their detailed knowledge of the needs of their customers and their close ties to the communities they serve.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='As you well know, however, community banks are also facing difficult challenges. Their close ties to local economies are, on balance, a source of strength, but a drawback of those ties is that the fortunes of communities and their banks tend to rise and fall together. Another concern for community banks is the narrowing of the range of their profitable lending activities: Because larger banks have used their scale to gain a pricing advantage in volume-driven businesses such as consumer lending, community banks have tended to specialize in other areas, such as loans secured by commercial real estate. That said, I know that community banks are continuing to look for ways to prudently diversify their revenue sources.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Like larger banks, community banks are also being affected by the state of the national economy. Despite some recent signs of improvement, the recovery has been frustratingly slow, constraining opportunities for profitable lending. And, as I will discuss momentarily, actual and prospective changes in the regulatory landscape have also raised concerns among community bankers.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The good news is that, for the most part, community banks appear to be meeting their challenges. Profits of smaller banks were considerably higher in 2011 than in the previous year, nonperforming assets were lower, provisions for loan losses fell appreciably, and capital ratios improved.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="As I noted, together with economic conditions, regulation and supervision are among the top concerns for community banks. In that regard, I think we would all agree that two-way communication between regulators and community banks is critical. Banks need to understand supervisors' policies and expectations, but supervisors must also listen to and understand banks' concerns.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="At the Federal Reserve, we pursue our dialogue with community bankers through many channels. One important channel is the recently established Community Depository Institutions Advisory Council (CDIAC).1 The council's membership is drawn from smaller banks, credit unions, and savings associations. Each of the 12 Reserve Banks around the country has a local advisory council, and one representative from each local council serves on the national council that meets with the Board in Washington twice a year.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The Regulation and Supervision of Community Banks Bank supervision requires a delicate balance--particularly now. The weak economy, together with loose lending standards in the past, has put pressure on the entire banking industry, including community banks. To protect banks from new problems down the road, and to safeguard the Deposit Insurance Fund, supervisors must insist on high standards for lending, risk management, and governance.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph="We also know that supervision imposes costs on institutions, and we recognize that new regulations and supervisory requirements may impose disproportionate costs on community banks. Thus, we take quite seriously the importance of evaluating the costs and benefits of new rules. Supervision is conducted through the Federal Reserve's decentralized structure of 12 regional Reserve Banks, which helps us tailor our examinations and supervision to the size, complexity, risk profile, and business model of each institution.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="Community bankers tell us repeatedly that they are concerned about the changing regulatory environment. One particular worry is the implementation of the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (Dodd-Frank Act). It is important to emphasize that the Congress enacted the Dodd-Frank Act largely in response to the 'too big to fail' problem, and that most of its provisions--regarding, for example, capital, liquidity, and risk management--apply only, or principally, to the largest, most complex, and internationally active banks.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The Regulation and Supervision of Community Banks Bank supervision requires a delicate balance--particularly now. The weak economy, together with loose lending standards in the past, has put pressure on the entire banking industry, including community banks. To protect banks from new problems down the road, and to safeguard the Deposit Insurance Fund, supervisors must insist on high standards for lending, risk management, and governance.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph="To conclude, I would like to reemphasize the importance that my colleagues on the Board and I place on the Federal Reserve's relationship with community banks. The Fed is committed to fair, consistent, and informed examinations that take into account the size, complexity, and individual circumstances of each bank we oversee.", theme='other')]

title: Creating and Implementing an Enforcement Response to the Foreclosure Crisis
speaker: Governor Sarah Bloom Raskin
tags:
[ThemeTag(paragraph='At the Association of American Law Schools Annual Meeting, Washington, D.C.

       Thank you and happy New Year. It is a pleasure to be with you today as you meet to discuss so many pressing and important issues.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The failure of timely enforcement leads to the entrenchment of bad practices and an increase in the costs of correction.

       For example, turning to what will be the focus of my comments today--the role of mortgage servicers in the foreclosure crisis--the longer it takes for mortgage servicers to make the operational adjustments necessary to fix their sloppy and deceptive practices, the costlier and more difficult it becomes for them to sort them out and correct them.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='More fundamentally, a failure by regulators to enforce the laws and regulations as strong antidotes to financial misconduct and unsafe and unsound practices by the institutions they regulate establishes de facto acquiescence to the dominant norms of the financial marketplace.

       At that point, our laws become the resting place for unfair practices and broad disrespect for the law generally.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='For sure, different regulatory regimes could have different answers regarding the best way to enforce laws and regulations.

       As law professors teaching both the substance of law and the practice of law, I imagine you find ways within your courses and scholarship to discuss theories of enforcement--for example, the use of private rights of action versus enforcement by regulatory agencies;', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='In answering all of these questions, there is consensus that public enforcement should be used in addressing pervasive regulatory problems.

       Today I want to talk about how home mortgage foreclosures hurt the pace of an economic recovery, and how important it is that the severe misconduct that has been uncovered in the mortgage servicing sector be addressed through intensified public enforcement of the law as part of the overarching effort to rebuild our damaged communities and neighborhoods.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The economic downturn that began in late 2007 and worsened considerably in the autumn of that year resulted in the worst recession in many decades.

       Although recovery from the recession officially began in the third quarter of 2009, the pace of recovery has been modest, resulting in an unemployment rate that has remained at or above 8.5 percent since mid-2009.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='This wave of foreclosures is one of the factors hindering a rapid recovery in the economy.

       Traditionally, the housing sector, buoyed by low interest rates and pent-up demand, has played an important role in propelling economic recoveries.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The increase in housing sales and construction often is accompanied by purchases of complementary goods, like furniture and appliances, which magnify the effect of the housing recovery.

       However, six years after house prices first began to fall, the pace of the economic recovery remains slow.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Nationally, house prices have fallen from a peak in 2006.

       During this period, foreclosures increased significantly due to subprime mortgage borrowers failing to meet their loan payments.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The number of homes that have been foreclosed is currently very high by historical standards.

       It has become a major concern for policymakers and regulators, who are worried about the impact on households and on economic growth.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph="Too many of the practices in the mortgage servicing industry have been developed and defended solely on the basis of 'standard industry practice,' but many practices were not only standard, but shoddy.

       Appropriately tailored enforcement against these mortgage servicing practices is necessary as one way to rebuild an important sector of the housing market.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="We should not forget that effective enforcement of our laws can animate our efforts as policymakers, regulators, business innovators, legal educators, and lawyers in creating the conditions that must exist for the emergence of an improved mortgage-servicing model that hinders neither economic growth nor homeowners' legal security.

       If a law is worth having, the law is worth enforcing.", theme='other')]

title: The Evolution of Capital Regulation
speaker: Governor Daniel K. Tarullo
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph='The passage discusses the reform efforts in capital regulation to prevent another financial crisis like the one that occurred in 2008. The reforms are divided into three threads: (1) strengthening the Basel III capital standards for all banks; (2) introducing a capital surcharge for systemically important banks (SIBs); and (3) establishing regular stress testing and capital planning requirements.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The first thread involves implementing the new, higher global minimum capital standards set by the Basel Committee on Banking Supervision. This includes the phased-in introduction of a countercyclical capital buffer to help mitigate systemic risk.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The second thread introduces a capital surcharge for SIBs, which will be calculated based on data collected in 2014 and phased in from 2016 to 2019. The list of covered banks will not be finalized until the surcharge begins to take effect, but an updated list will be published each November.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The third thread involves regular stress testing and capital planning requirements for bank holding companies with $50 billion or more in assets. This includes annual supervisory stress tests conducted by the Federal Reserve Board, as well as internal stress tests required of these companies. The disclosure of stress test results allows investors to better understand the profiles of each institution.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The reforms aim to increase the safety and soundness of the financial system and make it less likely that a future crisis will require another Troubled Asset Relief Program (TARP) program, which was implemented in 2008 to bail out large banks. While some details are still lacking, the direction of these reforms is now clear, and they command broad support among policymakers, policy analysts, and the public.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The key points discussed in this passage include:', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='*   Strengthening the Basel III capital standards for all banks.*   Introducing a capital surcharge for systemically important banks (SIBs).*   Establishing regular stress testing and capital planning requirements.*   Increasing the safety and soundness of the financial system.*   Reducing the likelihood of another TARP program.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The reforms aim to provide more clarity to banks, markets, and the public on the details of capital requirements while ensuring that the final regulations and requirements are well-crafted.', theme='other')]

title: The International Agenda for Financial Regulation
speaker: Governor Daniel K. Tarullo
tags:
[ThemeTag(paragraph='The article discusses the current state of international financial regulation and identifies key areas that require attention in the future.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='**Key Points:**
1. **Basel III implementation:** The Basel Committee on Banking Supervision (BCBS) has made progress in implementing the Basel III capital standards, but more work is needed to ensure their effective implementation.
2. **Resolution mechanisms:** A strong resolution mechanism for systemically important financial institutions is necessary to prevent too-big-to-fail perceptions and contain harm to the financial system.
3. **Wholesale funding channels:** The breakdown of wholesale funding channels can lead to systemic risk, and further measures are needed to mitigate these risks.
4. **OTC derivatives:** Strong capital standards alone are not enough to contain systemic risks in OTC derivatives markets; central clearing and margin requirements are necessary.
5. **Institutional changes:** The international regulatory reform agenda has primarily focused on generating regulatory rules, but more attention is needed to establish effective monitoring mechanisms and foster supervisory cooperation.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='**Conclusion:**
The article concludes that the pursuit of efficient and effective regulation requires priority-setting by, and rationalization of, the web of international arrangements dealing with these issues.', theme='other')]
