title: Remarks on historically black colleges and universities
speaker: Chairman Ben S. Bernanke
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph="Education is vital to our prosperity. It fundamentally supports advances in productivity, upon which our ability to generate continuing improvement in our standard of living depends. As our economy becomes more and more technologically advanced and globally interconnected, the skills, knowledge, and analytical ability that education develops are becoming ever more crucial to each individual's success. A substantial body of research demonstrates that investments in education--higher education, certainly, but also lifelong education, from preschool to mid-career training and adult education--pay high rates of return both to individuals and to our society as a whole. Moreover, the benefits of education are more than economic. By providing us with a broader view of the world, education helps each of us become the most complete person we can be. Research suggests that more-highly-educated individuals are happier on average, make better personal financial decisions, suffer fewer spells of unemployment, and enjoy better health. Educated individuals also are more likely to participate in civic affairs, volunteer their time to charities, and subscribe to personal values--such as tolerance and an appreciation of cultural differences--that are increasingly crucial for the healthy functioning of our diverse society.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Given our responsibilities at the Federal Reserve as a central bank and financial institution regulator, we see financial education in particular as a vital part of our mission. In our increasingly complex financial marketplace, choosing a credit card, saving for education and retirement, and buying a home now require more financial savvy than ever before. To help meet these needs, the Federal Reserve supports a variety of programs and initiatives to increase financial literacy. At the regional level, many of our economic education specialists offer training seminars to help educators teach economic and personal finance topics in their classrooms.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='In general, higher education is one of the strong points of the U.S. educational system. We must work diligently to maintain the quality of our educational system where it is strong and strive to improve it where it is not. In particular, we must find ways to move more of our students, especially minorities and those from disadvantaged backgrounds, into education after high school.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="The historically black colleges and universities have long played a vital role in this regard. They have proud record of accomplishment, dating back to 1837 with the founding of what is now Cheyney University of Pennsylvania. Slavery and segregation cast long dark shadows on our nation's history and our society, and the historically black colleges and universities served as beacons of knowledge in the darkness. Today, they are no longer the only places a young African American woman or man can obtain an education, but they are very fine choices for many students, and not just African Americans--indeed, 90 four-year and 13 two-year institutions enroll more than 300,000 students, including more than 50,000 who are not African Americans. In 2006, these institutions conferred more than 30,000 undergraduate degrees and nearly 9,000 advanced degrees. They have maintained their relevance by building on their tradition of educational excellence and by harnessing the loyalty and support of alumni. There are indeed many distinguished alumni of HBCUs, including media personality and philanthropist Oprah Winfrey, professor and Nobel Prize-winning author Toni Morrison, former U.S. Surgeon General David Satcher, Brown University President Ruth J. Simmons, and Major General Dennis Via, among many others.", theme='other')]

title: The United States in the International Financial System:  A Separate Reality? Resolving Two Puzzles in the International Accounts
speaker: Governor Randall S. Kroszner
tags:
[ThemeTag(paragraph='The main points of the text are:
1. The global economy is bound together by strong trade and financial linkages, which connect the US to the rest of the world.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='2. Two apparent puzzles in international finance - the willingness of foreigners to lend to the US despite a large current account deficit, and the ability of the US to borrow without increasing its debt - can be explained by differences in portfolio returns, composition, and size.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='3. Kroszner emphasizes that getting the fundamentals of sound risk management right is essential for financial institutions, especially during times of market turbulence. He highlights three fundamental areas:

1. **Governance and Risk Control**: Strong governance and risk control mechanisms are crucial for identifying, monitoring, and managing lending concentrations.

2. **Risk Identification and Measurement**: Financial institutions must have a good understanding of their risks, including off-balance-sheet risks, and conduct regular stress testing to identify potential concentrations.

3. **Liquidity Risk Management**: Liquidity risk requires rigorous management, as it can impact capital adequacy during times of financial stress.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='**Market Turbulence and Concentrations**

He encourages financial institutions to re-check their stress tests in light of recent events, consider broader scenarios, and design potential shocks creatively.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='**Liquidity Risk Management**

title: The Federal Reserve's Tools for Responding to Financial Disruptions
speaker: Governor Frederic S. Mishkin
tags:
[ThemeTag(paragraph='The article discusses the challenges faced by the Federal Reserve in addressing financial market disruptions and its efforts to mitigate macroeconomic risk through various policy tools.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='**Four Policy Tools**

1.  **Open Market Operations**: The Fed has increased the supply of reserves and kept demands for liquidity from causing sharp interest rate increases.
2.  **Discount Window**: The Fed provided liquidity by lowering the spread between the discount rate and the federal funds rate, making it easier for banks to borrow at a lower cost.
3.  **Term Auction Facility (TAF)**: A new source of liquidity was created, providing a fixed amount of funds for a one-month term at a competitively determined interest rate.
4.  **Monetary Policy**: The Fed has lowered the target federal funds rate in a timely, decisive, and flexible manner to help mitigate macroeconomic risk.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='**Key Principles**

1.  **Timeliness**: The Fed has acted promptly in response to financial market developments that could threaten economic or financial stability.
2.  **Decisiveness**: Policymakers have taken decisive action by lowering the federal funds rate target to reflect the evolution of the balance of risks to the macroeconomy.
3.  **Flexibility**: The Fed is prepared to act flexibly in adjusting the federal funds rate in response to incoming information, recognizing that financial and economic conditions can change quickly.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='**References**

*   Bernanke, B.S. (2008). Financial Markets, the Economic Outlook, and Monetary Policy
*   Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System (2005). The Implementation of Monetary Policy
*   Mishkin, F.S. (1991). Asymmetric Information and Financial Crises: A Historical Perspective
*   Mishkin, F.S. (2007a). Financial Instability and the Federal Reserve as a Liquidity Provider', theme='other')]

title: The Housing Market and Subprime Lending

tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph='Over the past four quarters, the U.S. real gross domestic product (GDP) has increased at an average rate of about 2 percent.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='As expected, we have also seen a gradual ebbing of core inflation, although its level remains somewhat elevated.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='In my brief remarks today I will focus on some recent developments in housing, including the emergence of some serious stresses in subprime mortgage markets.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Developments in the Housing MarketAs you know, the downturn in the housing market has been sharp. Single-family housing starts have declined by a third since early 2006, sufficient to subtract about 1 percentage point from real GDP growth over the past four quarters.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Recent developments in the subprime mortgage market add somewhat to the usual uncertainty in forecasting housing demand.  Subprime mortgage borrowing nearly tripled during the housing boom years of 2004 and 2005.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Tighter lending standards in the subprime mortgage market--together with the possibility that the well-publicized problems in this market may dissuade potentially eligible borrowers from applying--will serve to restrain housing demand, although the magnitude of these effects is difficult to quantify.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='We will follow developments in the subprime market closely. how credit derivatives might be affecting systemic risk.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='There are good reasons to think that these developments have made the financial system more resilient title: Financial Regulation and the Invisible Hand
speaker: Chairman Ben S. Bernanke
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph='This article discusses the role of market-based regulation, also known as "market discipline," in controlling excessive risk-taking by financial institutions such as commercial banks and hedge funds. The author argues that regulation can rely on the invisible hand of market-based incentives, which can complement direct government regulation.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The article highlights several key points:', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='1. **Market discipline is a powerful tool**: Market discipline can constrain excessive risk-taking by financial institutions, as investors and counterparties have an incentive to monitor and limit the risk-taking of these firms.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='2. **Sophisticated investors are essential**: Effective market discipline requires sophisticated investors who can understand and monitor the financial condition of the firm and be persuaded that they will experience significant losses in the event of a failure.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='3. **Hedge funds are not regulated like banks**: Hedge funds are subject to relatively light regulation, but they have a similar risk profile to commercial banks and can pose systemic risks if they fail.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='4. **Counterparties play an important role**: Counterparties such as large commercial and investment banks have an incentive to monitor and limit the risk-taking of hedge funds, and regulators seek to ensure that these counterparties protect themselves and the broader financial system.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The article also discusses the regulatory approach taken in response to the collapse of Long-Term Capital Management (LTCM), a hedge fund that suffered severe losses in 1998. Instead of imposing a more intrusive regulatory regime on private pools of capital, regulators chose to rely on market discipline, which has proven effective in constraining excessive risk-taking by hedge funds.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The author concludes that regulation can effectively rely on the invisible hand of market-based incentives, and that market discipline is a powerful tool for controlling excessive risk-taking. However, he also notes that there are areas where improvements can be made, particularly with regard to the regulation of hedge funds.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Overall, this article provides a comprehensive analysis of the role of market-based regulation in controlling excessive risk-taking by financial institutions, and highlights the importance of sophisticated investors, counterparties, and effective market discipline in achieving this goal.', theme='other')]

title: Monetary Policy and the Dual Mandate
speaker: Governor Frederic S. Mishkin
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph='In a democratic society like our own, the ultimate purpose of the central bank is to promote the public good by pursuing a course of monetary policy that fosters economic prosperity and social welfare.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The ultimate purpose of the central bank is to promote the public good by pursuing a course of monetary policy that fosters economic prosperity and social welfare. In the United States, as in virtually every other country, the central bank has a more specific set of objectives that have been established by the government.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="The central bank's mandate is to promote effectively the goals of maximum employment, stable prices, and moderate long-term interest rates. Because long-term interest rates can remain low only in a stable macroeconomic environment, these goals are often referred to as the dual mandate;", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="the central bank's ability to control inflation is crucial for achieving maximum employment.", theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='However, the level of maximum sustainable employment is not something that can be chosen by the Federal Reserve because no central bank can control the level of real economic activity or employment over the longer run.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='In fact, attempting to use stimulative monetary policy to maintain employment above its long-run sustainable level will inevitably lead to an upward spiral of inflation and therefore will actually undermine the productive capacity of the economy, with severe adverse consequences for household income and employment.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='A strong commitment to price stability helps reduce fluctuations in employment and output in other ways. First, when inflation expectations are well anchored, a central bank will not have to worry that expansionary policy to counter a negative demand shock will lead to a sharp rise in expected inflation--a so-called inflation scare.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Moreover, with a strong commitment to a nominal anchor, supply shocks to inflation, such as a rise in relative energy prices, are likely to have only a temporary effect on inflation.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Now that we see the benefits of maintaining a commitment to a nominal anchor, one might naturally think that there would also be benefits to establishing a similar sort of anchor for the maximum level of employment. But that thought would be incorrect.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Indeed, attempting to anchor a particular rate of growth of output and employment in the longer term could therefore lead to seriously flawed policies.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="To be sure, central banks need to form some views about the economy's potential to produce on a sustained basis. After all, as I have already noted, the amount of slack in the economy is a key determinant of inflation.", theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Finally, central banks should respond aggressively to output and employment fluctuations on those (hopefully rare) occasions when the economy is very far below any reasonable measure of its potential.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='It should be clear from my remarks today that although as a Federal Reserve official I am legally obligated to fulfill the dual mandate, I am actually an enthusiastic supporter.', theme='employment')]

title: Comments on “Understanding the Evolving Inflation Process” by Cecchetti, Hooper, Kasman, Schoenholtz, and Watson
speaker: Vice Chairman Donald L. Kohn
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph='This was an interesting paper with an important objective--to contribute to our understanding of inflation dynamics, with a particular focus on the so-called Great Inflation of the 1970s.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The authors’ principal empirical finding is that the onset and, to a lesser degree, the end of the Great Inflation were closely synchronized across a number of countries.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='I certainly agree with the authors that high inflation could not have emerged and then persisted without an accommodative policy regime and that a period of tight policy was required to produce the sustained moderation in inflation that followed.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='My impulse when it comes to selecting from the list of causative factors in the paper is to say “all of the above.” Policymakers in the 1970s--the Federal Reserve among them--were dealt a very bad hand that, for a variety of reasons, they played poorly.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Not only were the output costs of disinflation seen to be high but also the monetary policy needed to bring inflation down was consistently miscalculated--economists during the 1970s persistently overestimated both the speed and magnitude of the slowdown in real activity and inflation that would result from a given rise in the federal funds rate.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='But, in addition, the size of the output gap was not correctly perceived. I agree with the authors that this misperception could not have been the whole story;', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='These experiences formed the backdrop for the FOMC’s October 6, 1979, adoption of a policy targeting the monetary aggregates, a policy whose particular characteristics can be seen as originating from three observations about the 1970s.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The memory of the 1970s and the subsequent disinflation are very much alive at the Federal Reserve and, I suspect, at every other central bank. What major lessons have we drawn from that era?', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Low inflation reduces distortions from signals in market prices and facilitates longer-term planning.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='That brings me to my second major lesson: Expectations are critical to policy success. Expectations about future policy help to determine the financial conditions that affect spending and inflation.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='As a consequence, I do not agree with the authors’ assertion that central banks pay too much attention to inflation expectations.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='I think a third lesson is humility--we should always keep in mind how little we know about the economy.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Even today, we face a number of sources of uncertainty about the nature of the inflation process. Interestingly, we can draw several examples from the paper.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='In addition, we do not yet have a consensus structural model of inflation dynamics that satisfactorily explains all the important aspects of the empirical data.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The issue of expectations illustrates our ignorance. As I have already indicated, inflation expectations are among the most important variables policymakers monitor, but we do not have answers to our most basic questions about them:', theme='other')]

title: Liquidity and monetary policy

title: An Update on Basel II Implementation in the United States
speaker: Governor Susan Schmidt Bies
tags:
[ThemeTag(paragraph='This is a lengthy speech by a member of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, discussing various aspects of Basel II implementation in the United States. Here are the key points:', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="**Basel II Implementation**
* The speaker acknowledges that differences across countries may arise due to national discretion allowed under Basel II.
* The US version of Basel II is likely to be more conservative than other countries' versions in some areas, and less conservative in others.
* Banks will have to consider whether their current cushion of actual capital above regulatory minimums is still appropriate with a more risk-sensitive approach to capital.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="**Market-Risk Rule**
* The Federal Reserve has issued an NPR to amend the market-risk capital rules.
* The proposed amendments aim to enhance the rule's risk sensitivity and reflect changes in banks' trading books and risk-management practices over the last ten years.
* A new definition of a trading position is proposed, which would include only positions held for short-term resale or hedging other positions.
* Incremental default risk on covered positions would be measured using a one-year time horizon and a one-tailed 99.9 percent confidence level.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="**International Aspects**
* The US version of Basel II may differ from other countries' versions, which could create challenges for banking organizations operating in multiple jurisdictions.
* The Federal Reserve is committed to working with international supervisors to resolve home-host issues.
* Dialogue with foreign supervisory authorities has been encouraging, and the Federal Reserve continues to participate in supervisory working groups.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='**Quantitative Impact Studies**
* Findings from QIS4 and QIS5 have identified similar issues across countries.
* The US NPR includes a proposed supervisory mapping function for downturn estimates of loss given default, which was not available to European supervisors when drafting their rules.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="Overall, the speech highlights the complexities and challenges associated with implementing Basel II in the United States, including differences with other countries' approaches.", theme='other')]

title: Remarks
speaker: Chairman Ben S. Bernanke
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph='Although the idea of leaving Dillon to attend college was exciting for me, I realize now that I learned a lot from living here for seventeen years. I learned, among many other lessons, a few things about work.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The second thing I learned in Dillon is that Americans are economically ambitious; they seek opportunity and advancement.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='I try not to forget what underlies all those data: millions of Americans working hard, trying to better themselves economically, struggling to manage their family finances, and worrying about the price of gas and college tuition.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='I saw the long hours and persistent effort my parents put in to make their independent small business successful. After I graduated from high school I spent the summer as a construction worker helping to build Dillon’s Saint Eugene hospital, and during the summers of my college years, I waited tables six days a week at the South of the Border.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='I took two lessons from those experiences: First, in small towns like Dillon and in communities all across the United States, people work very hard every day to support themselves and their families.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Our family moved to Dillon when I was very small, and all my childhood memories are here. I went to East Elementary, J.V. Martin Junior High, and Dillon High School. Quite a few friends were classmates for all twelve grades.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='I made many other friends playing saxophone in the high-school marching band. My family and I attended Dillon’s small synagogue, Ohav Shalom, which is unfortunately no longer in existence.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='As a teenager, like many other teenagers, I itched to get away from the small town in which I was raised to see the bright lights of the big city. I got my wish, leaving when I was seventeen to attend college and graduate school in Boston.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='I met my wife in Boston, and we have lived in Palo Alto, California; Princeton, New Jersey; and now Washington. We have two children, a son and a daughter, now in graduate school and college, respectively.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='My family’s connection with Dillon goes back about sixty years. My grandfather Jonas Bernanke and his wife, Lina, moved here in the 1940s when Jonas purchased a local drugstore.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The original store was on Main Street, but when the chain stores entered the local market, my dad and uncle built a new, larger, and more modern store a block off Main. They competed by offering personal, first-name service, by delivering prescriptions without charge, and by coming down to the store at any time, nights or Sundays, to fill an emergency prescription.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Dillon had very few doctors at the time, and lots of people came to my dad and uncle for advice on basic health matters. My mother, who gave up a job teaching elementary school when I was born, often helped out in the store.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='As a child, I was supposed to help out as well, but I usually ended up in the store’s comic book section.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Now I am an economic policy maker, and I sit in a nice office in Washington looking at reports and tables of data and following the fluctuations of the financial markets.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='However, I try not to forget what underlies all those data: millions of Americans working hard, trying to better themselves economically, struggling to manage their family finances, and worrying about the price of gas and college tuition.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Let me thank you all again for inviting me back to Dillon and for sharing this morning with me.', theme='other')]

title: Energy and the Economy
speaker: Chairman Ben S. Bernanke
tags:
[ThemeTag(paragraph='**Supply and Demand Factors**
* Energy prices have increased significantly since 2002 due to strong world economic growth and a limited ability to increase energy supplies.
* The supply-demand fundamentals suggest that cheap oil and natural gas days are behind us.
* Options exist for improving energy efficiency, increasing conservation, and substituting other energy sources.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='**Economic Implications**
* Higher energy prices will reduce the productive capacity of the US economy in the long run by making businesses less willing to invest and existing capital obsolete.
* The higher cost of imported oil will adversely affect the US terms of trade, leading to a greater need for foreign financing.
* However, these effects are manageable, and ongoing productivity gains from technological improvements are likely to exceed the losses caused by high energy prices.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='**Short-Run Challenges**
* Sharply higher energy prices can slow economic growth while raising inflation.
* The first-round effect on inflation is direct, with energy costs passed through to consumers. The second-round effect occurs when firms pass on increased production costs in the form of higher consumer prices or workers demand higher nominal wages.
* Core inflation, which excludes energy and food price effects, provides a useful indicator of second-round effects.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph="**Policy Implications**
* Policymakers need to be aware of the short-run challenges posed by high energy prices.
* The Fed's credibility in keeping inflation low has helped reduce the second-round effect of energy price increases on core inflation.
* However, the cumulative increase in energy and commodity prices may account for some recent pickup in core inflation.
* Government can contribute to conservation efforts by creating a regulatory environment that encourages the growth in energy supplies consistent with environmental and other objectives.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='**Conclusion**
* Energy prices are likely to remain high in the short run due to strong world economic growth and limited excess capacity to produce crude oil or natural gas.
* However, market forces will respond in the long run, creating incentives for businesses to develop new technologies and consumers to adopt them.
* The US economy is resilient, and with government support, it can meet this challenge.', theme='other')]

* Financial innovations, such as dollarization, have reduced the costs of switching away from a local currency for small-value transactions, making it more difficult for governments to implement an inflationary policy.

* Institutional reforms, such as central bank independence with a mandate that includes price stability, have increased the credibility of monetary policy and made it harder for governments to pursue inflationary policies.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The author also highlights several benefits of price stability in emerging markets, including:

* Increasing financial market confidence and development, which further boosts growth and reinforces prospects for continued price stability', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='However, the author also notes some risks to this scenario, including:

title: Implementing Basel II: Choices and Challenges
speaker: Governor Susan Schmidt Bies
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph="However, since there is no specific information about inflation, I have modified the categorization to be 'Unemployment' (related to economy), 'Regulatory Capital' (which includes discussions on economy), and 'Uncategorized'.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='**Unemployment**\n- None of the text matches this category.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='* As you know, risk managers need to be able to discern whether fluctuations in risk exposures and capital are due to external effects, such as changes in the economy and the point in the economic cycle where decisions are being made, or are more related to their individual business decisions, including product characteristics, customer mix and underwriting criteria.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='* We will continue to expect bankers to anticipate the effects of such economic fluctuations and business decisions, not just analyze them after the fact. As we move toward greater risk sensitivity in our regulatory capital framework, and greater alignment with what banks are doing internally to manage risk, the way in which we as supervisors assess the adequacy of capital levels must consider the sources of these fluctuations more than ever before.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='* For example, data should contain enhanced look-back capabilities, so that we and bankers will be able to assess fluctuations within an institution over time. Unfortunately, in our QIS4 analysis we were unable to decompose changes we observed into those attributable to the economic cycle and those attributable to a bank’s individual portfolio composition because the QIS4 data were collected at a single point in time.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='* As part of the move toward greater risk sensitivity, and noting that different institutions have different risk profiles, we expect to place increased emphasis on sound economic analysis that focuses on changes observed at a single institution over time, as well as more traditional analysis across institutions.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='* Some Aspects of U.S. ProposalsAs you know, the draft U.S. Basel II NPR is based on the 2004 framework issued by the Basel Committee and adheres to the main elements of that framework. But the U.S. agencies have exercised national discretion and tailored the Basel II framework to fit the U.S. banking system and U.S. financial environment, as have their counterparts in other countries.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='* For example, as I have just mentioned, the U.S. agencies continue to propose that we implement only the advanced approaches of Basel II, namely the advanced internal-ratings-based approach (AIRB) for credit risk and the advanced measurement approaches (AMA) for operational risk.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='* The QIS4 exercise identified some areas requiring further clarification by regulators and additional work by bankers on risk models and databases. One of the key areas in the NPR influenced by these results pertains to banks’ estimates of loss given default (LGD).', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='* Another key area in the U.S. Basel II proposals relates to regulatory reporting and data requirements. The agencies expect to issue information about this aspect of our proposals soon, so I will offer only a few general thoughts here.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='* As you are aware, the Accord Implementation Group has been working for the past few years identifying issues arising from differences in national standards of the Basel II framework.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='* We have heard from bankers that they are concerned about home-host issues. The U.S. banking agencies all encourage regular meetings between bankers and supervisors. These meetings provide a forum for bankers to make supervisors aware of implementation plans and progress at individual banks, and for supervisors to make bankers aware of current supervisory expectations.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='* ConclusionIn conclusion, we are encouraged by the progress that international supervisors and banking organizations have made in preparing for the implementation of Basel II, and we look forward to the continuing dialogue which will help inform further refinements to our approach.', theme='other')]

title: Remarks
speaker: Vice Chairman Roger W. Ferguson, Jr.
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph='The focus of the roundtable--international financial reporting and auditing--continues to gain increased attention from members of the international regulatory community such as the Financial Stability Forum, the International Organization of Securities Commissions (IOSCO), the International Association of Insurance Supervisors (IAIS), and the Basel Committee as well as from national supervisors, standards setters, banks, investors, analysts, auditors, and many others.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='All of these positive efforts by regulators and supervisors reflect a growing recognition that sound accounting policies and meaningful public disclosure by banking and other financial organizations and by nonbanking companies can improve market discipline. The quality of management information and supervisory and financial reporting is dramatically affected by internal control systems, including internal audit programs and reviews by external auditors.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='This shared understanding of the importance of sound audit and control practices led to an unprecedented level of cooperation among the international regulatory community--in this case, IOSCO, the Basel Committee, the IAIS, the European Commission (EC), the World Bank, and the Financial Stability Forum, which came to be known as the Monitoring Group.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The Financial Stability Forum has taken a close interest in national and international efforts to strengthen confidence in financial reporting frameworks. Some of the key points made by the author include:', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='* Price stability is both an important goal of monetary policy and a prerequisite for achieving other goals, such as high employment and moderate long-term interest rates.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='* The notion of a permanent tradeoff between inflation and unemployment has been discredited by subsequent experience.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='* Low and stable inflation is associated with stronger economic growth and greater financial market efficiency.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='* Institutional commitment to price stability is essential for anchoring expectations and promoting financial market stability.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='* Sustained economic analysis and policy leadership are necessary for shaping our understanding of monetary policy and its role in promoting price stability.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Overall, the essay provides a clear and well-supported argument for the importance of price stability in monetary policy, highlighting both its intrinsic value as an important goal of policy and its instrumental value in achieving other goals.', theme='other')]

title: Globalization, Insurers, and Regulators: Shared Challenges Call for Collaborative Solutions
speaker: Vice Chairman Roger W. Ferguson, Jr.
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph="An important element of the FSF's work is to assess risks to financial stability that might arise from current economic and financial developments, to discuss risk scenarios, and to consider the capacity of the financial sector to absorb shocks.", theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Consider, for example, the effect of low long-term interest rates on the insurance sector. Low interest rates may have induced some firms to take on extra exposure through investment in higher-risk assets, including complex or less highly-rated credit products.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='But there are other potential explanations for the low long-term rates now prevailing in many countries. These other explanations include an excess of desired global saving over desired global investment spending and a decline in the risk premia demanded by investors, with the latter likely due in part to a marked decline in the volatility of economic activity and inflation.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Some observers have expressed concern about the possibility of a steep rise in long-term rates from their currently low levels. Were such a move to occur, the implications for the economy and asset prices would depend on the source of the rate increase.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='In addition to their exposure from unexpected developments in financial markets, insurers face a variety of other significant risks, including the potential liability arising from acts of terrorism and natural disasters.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Effective collaboration among financial authoritiesGlobalization is creating new business opportunities, opening new markets, increasing efficiency, decreasing the cost of capital, and enabling well-managed companies to deliver expanded services and greater shareholder value.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='In the United States, the nationwide reach of the largest insurers has led to an increasing emphasis on interstate cooperation among insurance supervisors through the NAIC. Now the development of financial conglomerates has rightly prompted increased links with supervisors in other sectors.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Regulators must sustain work in this direction as insurance activity continues to expand internationally, resulting in large, internationally active insurance groups.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The FSF takes an active interest in this area. Its interest is not just to the narrow question of determining which data items to disclose but in the whole process of information disclosure.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='As a result, the FSF encouraged and supported efforts by the IAIS and its working groups (Task Force Re and the Reinsurance Transparency Group) to shed light on these issues.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The first and second Global Reinsurance Market reports have since been released and have been well received by FSF members and other users of information.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='One area that is now receiving attention in both the private and the official communities is the perception that the financial industry is suffering from regulatory overload.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Of course, regulations that improve the strength and integrity of the financial system justify an element of regulatory burden.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The NAIC has been active in monitoring discussions and reviewing and commenting on insurance regulatory and supervisory papers.', theme='other')]

title: Remarks at ceremonial swearing-in by President Bush
speaker: Chairman Ben S. Bernanke
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph='Our mission, as set forth by the Congress, is a critical one: to preserve price stability, to foster maximum sustainable growth in output and employment, and to promote a stable and efficient financial system that serves all Americans well and fairly.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph="In his remarks in this building in 1937, President Roosevelt described as our purpose 'to gain for all of our people the greatest attainable measure of economic well-being, the largest degree of economic security and stability.'", theme='inflation')]
